text: The Ethics
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Ethica Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Benedict de Spinoza
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Translated from the Latin by R. H. M. Elwes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PART I. CONCERNING GOD.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITIONS.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  By that which is self--caused, I mean that of which the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence involves existence, or that of which the nature is only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceivable as existent.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  A thing is called finite after its kind, when it can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: limited by another thing of the same nature; for instance, a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body is called finite because we always conceive another greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body.  So, also, a thought is limited by another thought, but a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body is not limited by thought, nor a thought by body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  By substance, I mean that which is in itself, and is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived through itself: in other words, that of which a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception can be formed independently of any other conception.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  By attribute, I mean that which the intellect perceives as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituting the essence of substance.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  By mode, I mean the modifications[1] of substance, or that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which exists in, and is conceived through, something other than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [1] "Affectiones"
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI.  By God, I mean a being absolutely infinite--that is, a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance consisting in infinite attributes, of which each
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expresses eternal and infinite essentiality.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--I say absolutely infinite, not infinite after its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kind: for, of a thing infinite only after its kind, infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes may be denied; but that which is absolutely infinite,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contains in its essence whatever expresses reality, and involves
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no negation.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VII.  That thing is called free, which exists solely by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of its own nature, and of which the action is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined by itself alone.  On the other hand, that thing is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary, or rather constrained, which is determined by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something external to itself to a fixed and definite method of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence or action.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VIII.  By eternity, I mean existence itself, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived necessarily to follow solely from the definition of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which is eternal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Existence of this kind is conceived as an eternal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth, like the essence of a thing, and, therefore, cannot be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explained by means of continuance or time, though continuance may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be conceived without a beginning or end.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOMS.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  Everything which exists, exists either in itself or in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something else.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  That which cannot be conceived through anything else must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived through itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  From a given definite cause an effect necessarily follows;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, on the other hand, if no definite cause be granted, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible that an effect can follow.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  The knowledge of an effect depends on and involves the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of a cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  Things which have nothing in common cannot be understood, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one by means of the other; the conception of one does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involve the conception of the other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI.  A true idea must correspond with its ideate or object.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VII.  If a thing can be conceived as non--existing, its essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not involve existence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROPOSITIONS.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. I.  Substance is by nature prior to its modifications.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is clear from Deff. iii. and v.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. II.  Two substances, whose attributes are different, have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing in common.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Also evident from Def. iii.  For each must exist in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, and be conceived through itself; in other words, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception of one does not imply the conception of the other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. III.  Things which have nothing in common cannot be one the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of the other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If they have nothing in common, it follows that one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be apprehended by means of the other (Ax. v.), and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, one cannot be the cause of the other (Ax. iv.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IV.  Two or more distinct things are distinguished one from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other, either by the difference of the attributes of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substances, or by the difference of their modifications.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Everything which exists, exists either in itself or in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something else (Ax. i.),--that is (by Deff. iii. and v.), nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is granted in addition to the understanding, except substance and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its modifications.  Nothing is, therefore, given besides the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, by which several things may be distinguished one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the other, except the substances, or, in other words (see
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ax. iv.), their attributes and modifications.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. V.  There cannot exist in the universe two or more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substances having the same nature or attribute.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If several distinct substances be granted, they must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be distinguished one from the other, either by the difference of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their attributes, or by the difference of their modifications
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Prop. iv.).  If only by the difference of their attributes, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be granted that there cannot be more than one with an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: identical attribute.  If by the difference of their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications--as substance is naturally prior to its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications (Prop. i.),--it follows that setting the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications aside, and considering substance in itself, that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truly, (Deff. iii. and vi.), there cannot be conceived one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance different from another,--that is (by Prop. iv.), there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be granted several substances, but one substance only.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VI.  One substance cannot be produced by another substance.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--It is impossible that there should be in the universe
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two substances with an identical attribute, i.e. which have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything common to them both (Prop. ii.), and, therefore (Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iii.), one cannot be the cause of the other, neither can one be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: produced by the other.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that a substance cannot be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: produced by anything external to itself.  For in the universe
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing is granted, save substances and their modifications (as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appears from Ax. i. and Deff. iii. and v.).  Now (by the last
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.) substance cannot be produced by another substance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore it cannot be produced by anything external to itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.  This is shown still more readily by the absurdity of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contradictory.  For, if substance be produced by an external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause, the knowledge of it would depend on the knowledge of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause (Ax. iv.), and (by Def. iii.) it would itself not be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VII.  Existence belongs to the nature of substances.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Substance cannot be produced by anything external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Corollary, Prop vi.), it must, therefore, be its own cause--that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, its essence necessarily involves existence, or existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belongs to its nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VIII.  Every substance is necessarily infinite.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--There can only be one substance with an identical
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute, and existence follows from its nature (Prop. vii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its nature, therefore, involves existence, either as finite or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite.  It does not exist as finite, for (by Def. ii.) it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would then be limited by something else of the same kind, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would also necessarily exist (Prop. vii.); and there would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two substances with an identical attribute, which is absurd
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Prop. v.).  It therefore exists as infinite.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note I.--As finite existence involves a partial negation, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite existence is the absolute affirmation of the given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, it follows (solely from Prop. vii.) that every substance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is necessarily infinite.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note II.--No doubt it will be difficult for those who think
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about things loosely, and have not been accustomed to know them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by their primary causes, to comprehend the demonstration of Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii.: for such persons make no distinction between the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of substances and the substances themselves, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are ignorant of the manner in which things are produced; hence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they may attribute to substances the beginning which they observe
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in natural objects.  Those who are ignorant of true causes, make
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: complete confusion--think that trees might talk just as well as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men--that men might be formed from stones as well as from seed;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and imagine that any form might be changed into any other. So,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also, those who confuse the two natures, divine and human,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readily attribute human passions to the deity, especially so long
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they do not know how passions originate in the mind.  But, if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people would consider the nature of substance, they would have no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt about the truth of Prop. vii.  In fact, this proposition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be a universal axiom, and accounted a truism.  For, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, would be understood that which is in itself, and is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived through itself--that is, something of which the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception requires not the conception of anything else; whereas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications exist in something external to themselves, and a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception of them is formed by means of a conception of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing in which they exist.  Therefore, we may have true ideas of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: non--existent modifications; for, although they may have no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual existence apart from the conceiving intellect, yet their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence is so involved in something external to themselves that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they may through it be conceived.  Whereas the only truth
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substances can have, external to the intellect, must consist in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their existence, because they are conceived through themselves.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, for a person to say that he has a clear and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinct--that is, a true--idea of a substance, but that he is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sure whether such substance exists, would be the same as if he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said that he had a true idea, but was not sure whether or no it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was false (a little consideration will make this plain); or if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone affirmed that substance is created, it would be the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as saying that a false idea was true--in short, the height of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurdity.  It must, then, necessarily be admitted that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of substance as its essence is an eternal truth.  And
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we can hence conclude by another process of reasoning--that there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is but one such substance.  I think that this may profitably be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done at once; and, in order to proceed regularly with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstration, we must premise:----
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 1.  The true definition of a thing neither involves nor
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expresses anything beyond the nature of the thing defined.  From
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this it follows that----
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 2.  No definition implies or expresses a certain number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals, inasmuch as it expresses nothing beyond the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the thing defined.  For instance, the definition of a triangle
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expresses nothing beyond the actual nature of a triangle: it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not imply any fixed number of triangles.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 3.  There is necessarily for each individual existent thing a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause why it should exist.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 4.  This cause of existence must either be contained in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature and definition of the thing defined, or must be postulated
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: apart from such definition.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It therefore follows that, if a given number of individual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things exist in nature, there must be some cause for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of exactly that number, neither more nor less.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: example, if twenty men exist in the universe (for simplicity's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sake, I will suppose them existing simultaneously, and to have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had no predecessors), and we want to account for the existence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these twenty men, it will not be enough to show the cause of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human existence in general; we must also show why there are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exactly twenty men, neither more nor less: for a cause must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assigned for the existence of each individual.  Now this cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be contained in the actual nature of man, for the true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of man does not involve any consideration of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number twenty.  Consequently, the cause for the existence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these twenty men, and, consequently, of each of them, must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily be sought externally to each individual. Hence we may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lay down the absolute rule, that everything which may consist of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: several individuals must have an external cause.  And, as it has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been shown already that existence appertains to the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, existence must necessarily be included in its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition; and from its definition alone existence must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deducible.  But from its definition (as we have shown, notes ii.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iii.), we cannot infer the existence of several substances;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore it follows that there is only one substance of the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IX.  The more reality or being a thing has, the greater the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of its attributes (Def. iv.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. X.  Each particular attribute of the one substance must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived through itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--An attribute is that which the intellect perceives of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, as constituting its essence (Def. iv.), and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, must be conceived through itself (Def. iii.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note--It is thus evident that, though two attributes are, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, conceived as distinct--that is, one without the help of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other--yet we cannot, therefore, conclude that they constitute two
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entities, or two different substances.  For it is the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance that each of its attributes is conceived through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, inasmuch as all the attributes it has have always existed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneously in it, and none could be produced by any other;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but each expresses the reality or being of substance.  It is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then, far from an absurdity to ascribe several attributes to one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance: for nothing in nature is more clear than that each
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and every entity must be conceived under some attribute, and that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its reality or being is in proportion to the number of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes expressing necessity or eternity and infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Consequently it is abundantly clear, that an absolutely infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being must necessarily be defined as consisting in infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes, each of which expresses a certain eternal and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite essence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If anyone now ask, by what sign shall he be able to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguish different substances, let him read the following
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: propositions, which show that there is but one substance in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universe, and that it is absolutely infinite, wherefore such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sign would be sought in vain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XI.  God, or substance, consisting of infinite attributes,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of which each expresses eternal and infinite essentiality,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily exists.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If this be denied, conceive, if possible, that God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not exist: then his essence does not involve existence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But this (Prop. vii.) is absurd.  Therefore God necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exists.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Another proof.--Of everything whatsoever a cause or reason
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must be assigned, either for its existence, or for its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: non--existence--e.g. if a triangle exist, a reason or cause must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: granted for its existence; if, on the contrary, it does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exist, a cause must also be granted, which prevents it from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing, or annuls its existence.  This reason or cause must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either be contained in the nature of the thing in question, or be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external to it.  For instance, the reason for the non--existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a square circle is indicated in its nature, namely, because it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would involve a contradiction.  On the other hand, the existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of substance follows also solely from its nature, inasmuch as its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature involves existence.  (See Prop. vii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But the reason for the existence of a triangle or a circle
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not follow from the nature of those figures, but from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of universal nature in extension.  From the latter it must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow, either that a triangle necessarily exists, or that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible that it should exist.  So much is self--evident.  It
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows therefrom that a thing necessarily exists, if no cause or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason be granted which prevents its existence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If, then, no cause or reason can be given, which prevents the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of God, or which destroys his existence, we must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainly conclude that he necessarily does exist.  If such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason or cause should be given, it must either be drawn from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very nature of God, or be external to him--that is, drawn from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another substance of another nature.  For if it were of the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, God, by that very fact, would be admitted to exist.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance of another nature could have nothing in common with God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Prop. ii.), and therefore would be unable either to cause or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to destroy his existence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As, then, a reason or cause which would annul the divine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence cannot be drawn from anything external to the divine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, such cause must perforce, if God does not exist, be drawn
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from God's own nature, which would involve a contradiction.  To
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: make such an affirmation about a being absolutely infinite and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supremely perfect is absurd; therefore, neither in the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, nor externally to his nature, can a cause or reason be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assigned which would annul his existence.  Therefore, God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily exists.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Another proof.--The potentiality of non--existence is a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negation of power, and contrariwise the potentiality of existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a power, as is obvious.  If, then, that which necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exists is nothing but finite beings, such finite beings are more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: powerful than a being absolutely infinite, which is obviously
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd; therefore, either nothing exists, or else a being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely infinite necessarily exists also.  Now we exist either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in ourselves, or in something else which necessarily exists (see
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Axiom. i. and Prop. vii.).  Therefore a being absolutely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite--in other words, God (Def. vi.)--necessarily exists.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--In this last proof, I have purposely shown God's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence a posteriori, so that the proof might be more easily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: followed, not because, from the same premises, God's existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not follow a priori.  For, as the potentiality of existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a power, it follows that, in proportion as reality increases
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the nature of a thing, so also will it increase its strength
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for existence.  Therefore a being absolutely infinite, such as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, has from himself an absolutely infinite power of existence,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and hence he does absolutely exist.  Perhaps there will be many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who will be unable to see the force of this proof, inasmuch as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are accustomed only to consider those things which flow from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external causes.  Of such things, they see that those which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quickly come to pass--that is, quickly come into existence--quickly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also disappear; whereas they regard as more difficult of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accomplishment--that is, not so easily brought into
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence--those things which they conceive as more complicated.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, to do away with this misconception, I need not here
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show the measure of truth in the proverb, "What comes quickly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: goes quickly," nor discuss whether, from the point of view of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universal nature, all things are equally easy, or otherwise: I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need only remark that I am not here speaking of things, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: come to pass through causes external to themselves, but only of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substances which (by Prop. vi.) cannot be produced by any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external cause.  Things which are produced by external causes,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether they consist of many parts or few, owe whatsoever
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection or reality they possess solely to the efficacy of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their external cause;  and therefore their existence arises
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely from the perfection of their external cause, not from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their own.  Contrariwise, whatsoever perfection is possessed by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance is due to no external cause; wherefore the existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of substance must arise solely from its own nature, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing else but its essence.  Thus, the perfection of a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not annul its existence, but, on the contrary, asserts it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Imperfection, on the other hand, does annul it; therefore we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be more certain of the existence of anything, than of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of a being absolutely infinite or perfect--that is, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God.  For inasmuch as his essence excludes all imperfection, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves absolute perfection, all cause for doubt concerning his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence is done away, and the utmost certainty on the question
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is given.  This, I think, will be evident to every moderately
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attentive reader.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XII.  No attribute of substance can be conceived from which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it would follow that substance can be divided.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The parts into which substance as thus conceived would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be divided either will retain the nature of substance, or they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will not.  If the former, then (by Prop. viii.) each part will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily be infinite, and (by Prop. vi.) self--caused, and (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. v.) will perforce consist of a different attribute, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that, in that case, several substances could be formed out of one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, which (by Prop. vi.) is absurd.  Moreover, the parts
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Prop. ii.) would have nothing in common with their whole, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the whole (by Def. iv. and Prop. x.) could both exist and be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived without its parts, which everyone will admit to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.  If we adopt the second alternative--namely, that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts will not retain the nature of substance--then, if the whole
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance were divided into equal parts, it would lose the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of substance, and would cease to exist, which (by Prop. vii.) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIII.  Substance absolutely infinite is indivisible.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If it could be divided, the parts into which it was
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divided would either retain the nature of absolutely infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, or they would not.  If the former, we should have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: several substances of the same nature, which (by Prop. v.) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.  If the latter, then (by Prop. vii.) substance absolutely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite could cease to exist, which (by Prop. xi.) is also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--It follows, that no substance, and consequently no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extended substance, in so far as it is substance, is divisible.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The indivisibility of substance may be more easily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood as follows.  The nature of substance can only be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived as infinite, and by a part of substance, nothing else
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be understood than finite substance, which (by Prop. viii)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves a manifest contradiction.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIV.  Besides God no substance can be granted or conceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--As God is a being absolutely infinite, of whom no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute that expresses the essence of substance can be denied
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Def. vi.), and he necessarily exists (by Prop. xi.); if any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance besides God were granted, it would have to be explained
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by some attribute of God, and thus two substances with the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute would exist, which (by Prop. v.) is absurd; therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: besides God no substance can be granted, or, consequently, be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived.  If it could be conceived, it would necessarily have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be conceived as existent; but this (by the first part of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proof) is absurd.  Therefore, besides God no substance can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: granted or conceived.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--Clearly, therefore: 1.  God is one, that is (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Def. vi.) only one substance can be granted in the universe, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that substance is absolutely infinite, as we have already
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicated (in the note to Prop. x.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--It follows:  2.  That extension and thought
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are either attributes of God or (by Ax. i.) accidents
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (affectiones) of the attributes of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XV.  Whatsoever is, is in God, and without God nothing can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be, or be conceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Besides God, no substance is granted or can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived (by Prop. xiv.), that is (by Def. iii.) nothing which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in itself and is conceived through itself.  But modes (by Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: v.) can neither be, nor be conceived without substance;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore they can only be in the divine nature, and can only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through it be conceived.  But substances and modes form the sum
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: total of existence (by Ax. i.), therefore, without God nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be, or be conceived.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Some assert that God, like a man, consists of body and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, and is susceptible of passions.  How far such persons have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strayed from the truth is sufficiently evident from what has been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said.  But these I pass over.  For all who have in anywise
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reflected on the divine nature deny that God has a body.  Of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they find excellent proof in the fact that we understand by body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a definite quantity, so long, so broad, so deep, bounded by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain shape, and it is the height of absurdity to predicate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such a thing of God, a being absolutely infinite.  But meanwhile
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by other reasons with which they try to prove their point, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show that they think corporeal or extended substance wholly apart
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the divine nature, and say it was created by God.  Wherefrom
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the divine nature can have been created, they are wholly ignorant;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus they clearly show, that they do not know the meaning of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their own words.  I myself have proved sufficiently clearly, at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any rate in my own judgment (Coroll. Prop. vi, and note 2, Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: viii.), that no substance can be produced or created by anything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other than itself.  Further, I showed (in Prop. xiv.), that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: besides God no substance can be granted or conceived.  Hence we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: drew the conclusion that extended substance is one of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite attributes of God.  However, in order to explain more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fully, I will refute the arguments of my adversaries, which all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: start from the following points:----
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Extended substance, in so far as it is substance, consists,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they think, in parts, wherefore they deny that it can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, or consequently, that it can appertain to God.  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they illustrate with many examples, of which I will take one or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two.  If extended substance, they say, is infinite, let it be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived to be divided into two parts; each part will then be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either finite or infinite.  If the former, then infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance is composed of two finite parts, which is absurd.  If
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the latter, then one infinite will be twice as large as another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, which is also absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, if an infinite line be measured out in foot lengths,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it will consist of an infinite number of such parts; it would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally consist of an infinite number of parts, if each part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: measured only an inch: therefore, one infinity would be twelve
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: times as great as the other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, if from a single point there be conceived to be drawn
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two diverging lines which at first are at a definite distance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: apart, but are produced to infinity, it is certain that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distance between the two lines will be continually increased,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: until at length it changes from definite to indefinable.  As
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these absurdities follow, it is said, from considering quantity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as infinite, the conclusion is drawn, that extended substance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must necessarily be finite, and, consequently, cannot appertain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the nature of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The second argument is also drawn from God's supreme
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection.  God, it is said, inasmuch as he is a supremely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect being, cannot be passive; but extended substance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insofar as it is divisible, is passive.  It follows, therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that extended substance does not appertain to the essence of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the arguments I find on the subject in writers, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by them try to prove that extended substance is unworthy of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divine nature, and cannot possibly appertain thereto.  However, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think an attentive reader will see that I have already answered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their propositions; for all their arguments are founded on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hypothesis that extended substance is composed of parts, and such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a hypothesis I have shown (Prop. xii., and Coroll. Prop. xiii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be absurd.  Moreover, anyone who reflects will see that all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these absurdities (if absurdities they be, which I am not now
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discussing), from which it is sought to extract the conclusion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that extended substance is finite, do not at all follow from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notion of an infinite quantity, but merely from the notion that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an infinite quantity is measurable, and composed of finite parts
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, the only fair conclusion to be drawn is that:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite quantity is not measurable, and cannot be composed of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: finite parts.  This is exactly what we have already proved (in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. xii.).  Wherefore the weapon which they aimed at us has in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality recoiled upon themselves.  If, from this absurdity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theirs, they persist in drawing the conclusion that extended
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance must be finite, they will in good sooth be acting like
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man who asserts that circles have the properties of squares,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, finding himself thereby landed in absurdities, proceeds to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deny that circles have any center, from which all lines drawn to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the circumference are equal.  For, taking extended substance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which can only be conceived as infinite, one, and indivisible
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Props. viii., v., xii.) they assert, in order to prove that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is finite, that it is composed of finite parts, and that it can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be multiplied and divided.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: So, also, others, after asserting that a line is composed of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: points, can produce many arguments to prove that a line cannot be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinitely divided.  Assuredly it is not less absurd to assert
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that extended substance is made up of bodies or parts, than it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be to assert that a solid is made up of surfaces, a surface
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of lines, and a line of points.  This must be admitted by all who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: know clear reason to be infallible, and most of all by those who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deny the possibility of a vacuum.  For if extended substance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could be so divided that its parts were really separate, why
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should not one part admit of being destroyed, the others
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remaining joined together as before?  And why should all be so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fitted into one another as to leave no vacuum?  Surely in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case of things, which are really distinct one from the other, one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can exist without the other, and can remain in its original
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: condition.  As, then,  there does not exist a vacuum in nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (of which anon), but all parts are bound to come together to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prevent it, it follows from this that the parts cannot really be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguished, and that extended substance in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance cannot be divided.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If anyone asks me the further question, Why are we naturally
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so prone to divide quantity?  I answer, that quantity is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived by us in two ways; in the abstract and superficially,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we imagine it; or as substance, as we conceive it solely by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the intellect.  If, then, we regard quantity as it is represented
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in our imagination, which we often and more easily do, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: find that it is finite, divisible, and compounded of parts; but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if we regard it as it is represented in our intellect, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive it as substance, which it is very difficult to do, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall then, as I have sufficiently proved, find that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, one, and indivisible.  This will be plain enough to all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who make a distinction between the intellect and the imagination,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially if it be remembered, that matter is everywhere the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same, that its parts are not distinguishable, except in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we conceive matter as diversely modified, whence its parts are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguished, not really, but modally.  For instance, water, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as it is water, we conceive to be divided, and its parts
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be separated one from the other; but not in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extended substance; from this point of view it is neither
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: separated nor divisible.  Further, water, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: water, is produced and corrupted; but, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, it is neither produced nor corrupted.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I think I have now answered the second argument; it is, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, founded on the same assumption as the first--namely, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matter, in so far as it is substance, is divisible, and composed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of parts.  Even if it were so, I do not know why it should be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considered unworthy of the divine nature, inasmuch as besides God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Prop. xiv.) no substance can be granted, wherefrom it could
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: receive its modifications.  All things, I repeat, are in God, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all things which come to pass, come to pass solely through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of the infinite nature of God, and follow (as I will shortly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show) from the necessity of his essence.  Wherefore it can in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nowise be said, that God is passive in respect to anything other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than himself, or that extended substance is unworthy of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine nature, even if it be supposed divisible, so long as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: granted to be infinite and eternal.  But enough of this for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVI.  From the necessity of the divine nature must follow
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an infinite number of things in infinite ways--that is, all things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which can fall within the sphere of infinite intellect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition will be clear to everyone, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remembers that from the given definition of any thing the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect infers several properties, which really necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow therefrom (that is, from the actual essence of the thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: defined); and it infers more properties in proportion as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of the thing expresses more reality, that is, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as the essence of the thing defined involves more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality.  Now, as the divine nature has absolutely infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes (by Def. vi.), of which each expresses infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence after its kind, it follows that from the necessity of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature an infinite number of things (that is, everything which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can fall within the sphere of an infinite intellect) must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follow.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--Hence it follows, that God is the efficient
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of all that can fall within the sphere of an infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--It also follows that God is a cause in himself,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and not through an accident of his nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary III.--It follows, thirdly, that God is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely first cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVII.  God acts solely by the laws of his own nature, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not constrained by anyone.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We have just shown (in Prop. xvi.), that solely from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the necessity of the divine nature, or, what is the same thing,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely from the laws of his nature, an infinite number of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely follow in an infinite number of ways; and we proved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (in Prop. xv.), that without God nothing can be nor be conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but that all things are in God.  Wherefore nothing can exist;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: outside himself, whereby he can be conditioned or constrained to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: act.  Wherefore God acts solely by the laws of his own nature,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and is not constrained by anyone.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--It follows: 1.  That there can be no cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which, either extrinsically or intrinsically, besides the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection of his own nature, moves God to act.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--It follows: 2.  That God is the sole free
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause.  For God alone exists by the sole necessity of his nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Prop. xi. and Prop. xiv., Coroll. i.), and acts by the sole
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of his own nature, wherefore God is (by Def. vii.) the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sole free cause.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Others think that God is a free cause, because he can,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they think, bring it about, that those things which we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said follow from his nature--that is, which are in his power,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should not come to pass, or should not be produced by him.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this is the same as if they said, that God could bring it about,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it should follow from the nature of a triangle that its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: three interior angles should not be equal to two right angles;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or that from a given cause no effect should follow, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moreover, I will show below, without the aid of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition, that neither intellect nor will appertain to God's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature.  I know that there are many who think that they can show,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that supreme intellect and free will do appertain to God's nature;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for they say they know of nothing more perfect, which they can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute to God, than that which is the highest perfection in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves.  Further, although they conceive God as actually
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supremely intelligent, they yet do not believe that he can bring
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into existence everything which he actually understands, for they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think that they would thus destroy God's power.  If, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contend, God had created everything which is in his intellect, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would not be able to create anything more, and this, they think,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would clash with God's omnipotence; therefore, they prefer to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: asset that God is indifferent to all things, and that he creates
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing except that which he has decided, by some absolute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exercise of will, to create.  However, I think I have shown
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sufficiently clearly (by Prop. xvi.), that from God's supreme
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power, or infinite nature, an infinite number of things--that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all things have necessarily flowed forth in an infinite number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways, or always flow from the same necessity; in the same way as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the nature of a triangle it follows from eternity and for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity, that its three interior angles are equal to two right
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: angles.  Wherefore the omnipotence of God has been displayed from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all eternity, and will for all eternity remain in the same state
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of activity.  This manner of treating the question attributes to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God an omnipotence, in my opinion, far more perfect.  For,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: otherwise, we are compelled to confess that God understands an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of creatable things, which he will never be able
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to create, for, if he created all that he understands, he would,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to this showing, exhaust his omnipotence, and render
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself imperfect.  Wherefore, in order to establish that God is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect, we should be reduced to establishing at the same time,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he cannot bring to pass everything over which his power
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extends; this seems to be a hypothesis most absurd, and most
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repugnant to God's omnipotence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further (to say a word here concerning the intellect and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will which we attribute to God), if intellect and will appertain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the eternal essence of God, we must take these words in some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: significance quite different from those they usually bear.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect and will, which should constitute the essence of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would perforce be as far apart as the poles from the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect and will, in fact, would have nothing in common with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them but the name; there would be about as much correspondence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: between the two as there is between the Dog, the heavenly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constellation, and a dog, an animal that barks.  This I will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prove as follows.  If intellect belongs to the divine nature, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be in nature, as ours is generally thought to be,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: posterior to, or simultaneous with the things understood,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as God is prior to all things by reason of his causality
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Prop. xvi., Coroll. i.).  On the contrary, the truth and formal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of things is as it is, because it exists by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: representation as such in the intellect of God.  Wherefore the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect of God, in so far as it is conceived to constitute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's essence, is, in reality, the cause of things, both of their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence and of their existence.  This seems to have been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: recognized by those who have asserted, that God's intellect,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's will, and God's power, are one and the same.  As,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, God's intellect is the sole cause of things, namely,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: both of their essence and existence, it must necessarily differ
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from them in respect to its essence, and in respect to its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence.  For a cause differs from a thing it causes, precisely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the quality which the latter gains from the former.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For example, a man is the cause of another man's existence,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but not of his essence (for the latter is an eternal truth), and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, the two men may be entirely similar in essence, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must be different in existence; and hence if the existence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one of them cease, the existence of the other will not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily cease also; but if the essence of one could be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed, and be made false, the essence of the other would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed also.  Wherefore, a thing which is the cause both of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence and of the existence of a given effect, must differ
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from such effect both in respect to its essence, and also in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to its existence.  Now the intellect of God is the cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: both of the essence and the existence of our intellect;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, the intellect of God in so far as it is conceived to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitute the divine essence, differs from our intellect both in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to essence and in respect to existence, nor can it in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anywise agree therewith save in name, as we said before.  The
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasoning would be identical in the case of the will, as anyone
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can easily see.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVIII.  God is the indwelling and not the transient cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of all things.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All things which are, are in God, and must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived through God (by Prop. xv.), therefore (by Prop. xvi.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll. i.) God is the cause of those things which are in him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This is our first point.  Further, besides God there can be no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance (by Prop. xiv.), that is nothing in itself external to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God.  This is our second point.  God, therefore, is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indwelling and not the transient cause of all things.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIX.  God, and all the attributes of God, are eternal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--God (by Def. vi.) is substance, which (by Prop. xi.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily exists, that is (by Prop. vii.) existence appertains
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to its nature, or (what is the same thing) follows from its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition; therefore, God is eternal (by Def. viii.).  Further,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the attributes of God we must understand that which (by Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iv.) expresses the essence of the divine substance--in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, that which appertains to substance: that, I say, should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be involved in the attributes of substance.  Now eternity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appertains to the nature of substance (as I have already shown in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. vii.); therefore, eternity must appertain to each of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes, and thus all are eternal.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition is also evident from the manner in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which (in Prop. xi.) I demonstrated the existence of God; it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident, I repeat, from that proof, that the existence of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like his essence, is an eternal truth.  Further (in Prop. xix. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: my "Principles of the Cartesian Philosophy"), I have proved the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity of God, in another manner, which I need not here repeat.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XX.  The existence of God and his essence are one and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--God (by the last Prop.) and all his attributes are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal, that is (by Def. viii.) each of his attributes expresses
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence.  Therefore the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes of God which explain his eternal essence, explain at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same time his eternal existence--in other words, that which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitutes God's essence constitutes at the same time his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence.  Wherefore God's existence and God's essence are one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the same.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll. I.--Hence it follows that God's existence, like his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence, is an eternal truth.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll. II--Secondly, it follows that God, and all the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes of God, are unchangeable.  For if they could be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changed in respect to existence, they must also be able to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changed in respect to essence--that is, obviously, be changed from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true to false, which is absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXI.  All things which follow from the absolute nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any attribute of God must always exist and be infinite, or, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, are eternal and infinite through the said attribute.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Conceive, if it be possible (supposing the proposition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be denied), that something in some attribute of God can follow
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the absolute nature of the said attribute, and that at the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same time it is finite, and has a conditioned existence or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: duration; for instance, the idea of God expressed in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute thought.  Now thought, in so far as it is supposed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be an attribute of God, is necessarily (by Prop. xi.) in its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature infinite. But, in so far as it possesses the idea of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is supposed finite.  It cannot, however, be conceived as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: finite, unless it be limited by thought (by Def. ii.); but it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not limited by thought itself, in so far as it has constituted
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of God (for so far it is supposed to be finite);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
