text: therefore, it is limited by thought, in so far as it has not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituted the idea of God, which nevertheless (by Prop. xi.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must necessarily exist.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We have now granted, therefore, thought not constituting the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of God, and, accordingly, the idea of God does not naturally
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow from its nature in so far as it is absolute thought (for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is conceived as constituting, and also as not constituting,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of God), which is against our hypothesis.  Wherefore, if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of God expressed in the attribute thought, or, indeed,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything else in any attribute of God (for we may take any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: example, as the proof is of universal application) follows from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the necessity of the absolute nature of the said attribute, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said thing must necessarily be infinite, which was our first
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Furthermore, a thing which thus follows from the necessity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of any attribute cannot have a limited duration.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if it can, suppose a thing, which follows from the necessity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of some attribute, to exist in some attribute of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for instance, the idea of God expressed in the attribute thought,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and let it be supposed at some time not to have existed, or to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about not to exist.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now thought being an attribute of God, must necessarily exist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unchanged (by Prop. xi., and Prop. xx., Coroll. ii.); and beyond
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the limits of the duration of the idea of God (supposing the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter at some time not to have existed, or not to be going to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exist) thought would perforce have existed without the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, which is contrary to our hypothesis, for we supposed that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought being given, the idea of God necessarily flowed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom.  Therefore the idea of God expressed in thought, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything which necessarily follows from the absolute nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some attribute of God, cannot have a limited duration, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through the said attribute is eternal, which is our second point.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bear in mind that the same proposition may be affirmed of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything, which in any attribute necessarily follows from God's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolute nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXII.  Whatsoever follows from any attribute of God, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is modified by a modification, which exists necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and as infinite, through the said attribute, must also exist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily and as infinite.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The proof of this proposition is similar to that of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the preceding one.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIII.  Every mode, which exists both necessarily and as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, must necessarily follow either from the absolute nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of some attribute of God, or from an attribute modified by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification which exists necessarily, and as infinite.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A mode exists in something else, through which it must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be conceived (Def. v.), that is (Prop. xv.), it exists solely in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, and solely through God can be conceived. If therefore a mode
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is conceived as necessarily existing and infinite, it must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily be inferred or perceived through some attribute of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, in so far as such attribute is conceived as expressing the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinity and necessity of existence, in other words (Def. viii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity; that is, in so far as it is considered absolutely.  A
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mode, therefore, which necessarily exists as infinite, must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow from the absolute nature of some attribute of God, either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: immediately (Prop. xxi.) or through the means of some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification, which follows from the absolute nature of the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute; that is (by Prop. xxii.), which exists necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and as infinite.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIV.  The essence of things produced by God does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involve existence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from Def. i.  For that of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which the nature (considered in itself) involves existence is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--caused, and exists by the sole necessity of its own nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that God is not only the cause of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things coming into existence, but also of their continuing in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence, that is, in scholastic phraseology, God is cause of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the being of things (essendi rerum).  For whether things exist,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or do not exist, whenever we contemplate their essence, we see
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it involves neither existence nor duration; consequently,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it cannot be the cause of either the one or the other.  God must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be the sole cause, inasmuch as to him alone does existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appertain.  (Prop. xiv. Coroll. i.) Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXV.  God is the efficient cause not only of the existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things, but also of their essence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If this be denied, then God is not the cause of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of things; and therefore the essence of things can (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ax. iv.) be conceived without God.  This (by Prop. xv.) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.  Therefore, God is the cause of the essence of things.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition follows more clearly from Prop. xvi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For it is evident thereby that, given the divine nature, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of things must be inferred from it, no less than their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence--in a word, God must be called the cause of all things,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the same sense as he is called the cause of himself.  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be made still clearer by the following corollary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Individual things are nothing but modifications of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the attributes of God, or modes by which the attributes of God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are expressed in a fixed and definite manner.  The proof appears
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from Prop. xv. and Def. v.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVI.  A thing which is conditioned to act in a particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner, has necessarily been thus conditioned by God; and that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which has not been conditioned by God cannot condition itself to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: act.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--That by which things are said to be conditioned to act
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in a particular manner is necessarily something positive (this is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obvious); therefore both of its essence and of its existence God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the necessity of his nature is the efficient cause (Props.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxv. and xvi.); this is our first point.  Our second point is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plainly to be inferred therefrom.  For if a thing, which has not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been conditioned by God, could condition itself, the first part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of our proof would be false, and this, as we have shown is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVII.  A thing, which has been conditioned by God to act
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in a particular way, cannot render itself unconditioned.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from the third axiom.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVIII.  Every individual thing, or everything which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: finite and has a conditioned existence, cannot exist or be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned to act, unless it be conditioned for existence and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action by a cause other than itself, which also is finite, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has a conditioned existence; and likewise this cause cannot in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its turn exist, or be conditioned to act, unless it be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned for existence and action by another cause, which also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is finite, and has a conditioned existence, and so on to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever is conditioned to exist and act, has been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus conditioned by God (by Prop. xxvi. and Prop. xxiv.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But that which is finite, and has a conditioned existence,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be produced by the absolute nature of any attribute of God;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for whatsoever follows from the absolute nature of any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute of God is infinite and eternal (by Prop. xxi.).  It
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must, therefore, follow from some attribute of God, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the said attribute is considered as in some way modified; for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance and modes make up the sum total of existence (by Ax. i.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and Def. iii., v.), while modes are merely modifications of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes of God.  But from God, or from any of his attributes,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as the latter is modified by a modification infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and eternal, a conditioned thing cannot follow.  Wherefore it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must follow from, or be conditioned for, existence and action by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God or one of his attributes, in so far as the latter are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modified by some modification which is finite, and has a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned existence.  This is our first point.  Again, this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause or this modification (for the reason by which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: established the first part of this proof) must in its turn be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned by another cause, which also is finite, and has a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned existence, and, again, this last by another (for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same reason); and so on (for the same reason) to infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--As certain things must be produced immediately by God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely those things which necessarily follow from his absolute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, through the means of these primary attributes, which,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless, can neither exist nor be conceived without God, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows:--1. That God is absolutely the proximate cause of those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things immediately produced by him.  I say absolutely, not after
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his kind, as is usually stated.  For the effects of God cannot
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either exist or be conceived without a cause (Prop. xv. and Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiv. Coroll.).  2. That God cannot properly be styled the remote
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of individual things, except for the sake of distinguishing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these from what he immediately produces, or rather from what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows from his absolute nature.  For, by a remote cause, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand a cause which is in no way conjoined to the effect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But all things which are, are in God, and so depend on God, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without him they can neither be nor be conceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIX.  Nothing in the universe is contingent, but all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things are conditioned to exist and operate in a particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner by the necessity of the divine nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever is, is in God (Prop. xv.).  But God cannot
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be called a thing contingent.  For (by Prop. xi.) he exists
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily, and not contingently.  Further, the modes of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divine nature follow therefrom necessarily, and not contingently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Prop. xvi.); and they thus follow, whether we consider the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divine nature absolutely, or whether we consider it as in any way
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned to act (Prop. xxvii.).  Further, God is not only the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of these modes, in so far as they simply exist (by Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiv, Coroll.), but also in so far as they are considered as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned for operating in a particular manner (Prop. xxvi.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If they be not conditioned by God (Prop. xxvi.), it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible, and not contingent, that they should condition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves; contrariwise, if they be conditioned by God, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible, and not contingent, that they should render
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves unconditioned. Wherefore all things are conditioned by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the necessity of the divine nature, not only to exist, but also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to exist and operate in a particular manner, and there is nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is contingent.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Before going any further, I wish here to explain, what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we should understand by nature viewed as active (natura
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: naturans), and nature viewed as passive (natura naturata).  I say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to explain, or rather call attention to it, for I think that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from what has been said, it is sufficiently clear, that by nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: viewed as active we should understand that which is in itself,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and is conceived through itself, or those attributes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, which express eternal and infinite essence, in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words (Prop. xiv., Coroll. i., and Prop. xvii., Coroll. ii) God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he is considered as a free cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: By nature viewed as passive I understand all that which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows from the necessity of the nature of God, or of any of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes of God, that is, all the modes of the attributes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, in so far as they are considered as things which are in God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and which without God cannot exist or be conceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXX.  Intellect, in function (actu) finite, or in function
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, must comprehend the attributes of God and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of God, and nothing else.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A true idea must agree with its object (Ax. vi.); in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words (obviously), that which is contained in the intellect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in representation must necessarily be granted in nature.  But in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature (by Prop. xiv., Coroll. i.) there is no substance save
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, nor any modifications save those (Prop. xv.) which are in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, and cannot without God either be or be conceived.  Therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the intellect, in function finite, or in function infinite, must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comprehend the attributes of God and the modifications of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and nothing else.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXI.  The intellect in function, whether finite or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, as will, desire, love, &c., should be referred to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive nature and not to active nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--By the intellect we do not (obviously) mean absolute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought, but only a certain mode of thinking, differing from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other modes, such as love, desire, &c., and therefore (Def. v.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: requiring to be conceived through absolute thought.  It must (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. xv. and Def. vi.), through some attribute of God which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expresses the eternal and infinite essence of thought, be so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived, that without such attribute it could neither be nor be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived.  It must therefore be referred to nature passive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than to nature active, as must also the other modes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--I do not here, by speaking of intellect in function,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admit that there is such a thing as intellect in potentiality:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but, wishing to avoid all confusion, I desire to speak only of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is most clearly perceived by us, namely, of the very act of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, than which nothing is more clearly perceived.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we cannot perceive anything without adding to our knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the act of understanding.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXII.  Will cannot be called a free cause, but only a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Will is only a particular mode of thinking, like
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect; therefore (by Prop. xxviii.) no volition can exist,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor be conditioned to act, unless it be conditioned by some cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other than itself, which cause is conditioned by a third cause,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and so on to infinity.  But if will be supposed infinite, it must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also be conditioned to exist and act by God, not by virtue of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being substance absolutely infinite, but by virtue of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessing an attribute which expresses the infinite and eternal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of thought (by Prop. xxiii.).  Thus, however it be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived, whether as finite or infinite, it requires a cause by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it should be conditioned to exist and act.  Thus (Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii.) it cannot be called a free cause, but only a necessary or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constrained cause.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll. I.--Hence it follows, first, that God does not act
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to freedom of the will.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll. II.--It follows, secondly, that will and intellect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stand in the same relation to the nature of God as do motion, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest, and absolutely all natural phenomena, which must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned by God (Prop. xxix.) to exist and act in a particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner.  For will, like the rest, stands in need of a cause, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it is conditioned to exist and act in a particular manner.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: And although, when will or intellect be granted, an infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of results may follow, yet God cannot on that account be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said to act from freedom of the will, any more than the infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of results from motion and rest would justify us in saying
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that motion and rest act by free will.  Wherefore will no more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appertains to God than does anything else in nature, but stands
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the same relation to him as motion, rest, and the like, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we have shown to follow from the necessity of the divine nature,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to be conditioned by it to exist and act in a particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIII.  Things could not have been brought into being by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God in any manner or in any order different from that which has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in fact obtained.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof--All things necessarily follow from the nature of God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Prop. xvi.), and by the nature of God are conditioned to exist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and act in a particular way (Prop. xxix.).  If things, therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could have been of a different nature, or have been conditioned
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to act in a different way, so that the order of nature would have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been different, God's nature would also have been able to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from what it now is; and therefore (by Prop. xi.) that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different nature also would have perforce existed, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently there would have been able to be two or more Gods.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This (by Prop. xiv., Coroll. i.) is absurd.  Therefore things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could not have been brought into being by God in any other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note I.--As I have thus shown, more clearly than the sun at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: noonday, that there is nothing to justify us in calling things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent, I wish to explain briefly what meaning we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attach to the word contingent; but I will first explain the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words necessary and impossible.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: A thing is called necessary either in respect to its essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or in respect to its cause; for the existence of a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follows, either from its essence and definition, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from a given efficient cause.  For similar reasons a thing is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said to be impossible; namely, inasmuch as its essence or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition involves a contradiction, or because no external cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is granted, which is conditioned to produce such an effect; but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a thing can in no respect be called contingent, save in relation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the imperfection of our knowledge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: A thing of which we do not know whether the essence does or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not involve a contradiction, or of which, knowing that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not involve a contradiction, we are still in doubt
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the existence, because the order of causes escapes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us,--such a thing, I say, cannot appear to us either necessary or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible.  Wherefore we call it contingent or possible.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note II.--It clearly follows from what we have said, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things have been brought into being by God in the highest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection, inasmuch as they have necessarily followed from a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most perfect nature.  Nor does this prove any imperfection in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, for it has compelled us to affirm his perfection.  From its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary proposition, we should clearly gather (as I have just
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown), that God is not supremely perfect, for if things had been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brought into being in any other way, we should have to assign to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God a nature different from that, which we are bound to attribute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to him from the consideration of an absolutely perfect being.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I do not doubt, that many will scout this idea as absurd, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will refuse to give their minds up to contemplating it, simply
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because they are accustomed to assign to God a freedom very
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from that which we (Def. vii.) have deduced.  They
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assign to him, in short, absolute free will.  However, I am also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: convinced that if such persons reflect on the matter, and duly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: weigh in their minds our series of propositions, they will reject
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such freedom as they now attribute to God, not only as nugatory,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but also as a great impediment to organized knowledge.  There is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no need for me to repeat what I have said in the note to Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii.  But, for the sake of my opponents, I will show further,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that although it be granted that will pertains to the essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, it nevertheless follows from his perfection, that things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could not have been by him created other than they are, or in a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different order; this is easily proved, if we reflect on what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our opponents themselves concede, namely, that it depends solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the decree and will of God, that each thing is what it is.  If
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it were otherwise, God would not be the cause of all things.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, that all the decrees of God have been ratified from all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity by God himself.  If it were otherwise, God would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: convicted of imperfection or change.  But in eternity there is no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such thing as when, before, or after; hence it follows solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the perfection of God, that God never can decree, or never
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could have decreed anything but what is; that God did not exist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before his decrees, and would not exist without them.  But, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said, supposing that God had made a different universe, or had
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordained other decrees from all eternity concerning nature and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: her order, we could not therefore conclude any imperfection in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God.  But persons who say this must admit that God can change his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decrees.  For if God had ordained any decrees concerning nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and her order, different from those which he has ordained--in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, if he had willed and conceived something different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning nature--he would perforce have had a different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect from that which he has, and also a different will.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if it were allowable to assign to God a different intellect and a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different will, without any change in his essence or his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection, what would there be to prevent him changing the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decrees which he has made concerning created things, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless remaining perfect?  For his intellect and will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning things created and their order are the same, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to his essence and perfection, however they be conceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, all the philosophers whom I have read admit that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's intellect is entirely actual, and not at all potential; as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they also admit that God's intellect, and God's will, and God's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence are identical, it follows that, if God had had a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different actual intellect and a different will, his essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would also have been different; and thus, as I concluded at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first, if things had been brought into being by God in a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different way from that which has obtained, God's intellect and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will, that is (as is admitted) his essence would perforce have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been different, which is absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As these things could not have been brought into being by God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in any but the actual way and order which has obtained; and as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the truth of this proposition follows from the supreme perfection
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God; we can have no sound reason for persuading ourselves to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe that God did not wish to create all the things which were
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in his intellect, and to create them in the same perfection as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had understood them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, it will be said, there is in things no perfection nor
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfection; that which is in them, and which causes them to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called perfect or imperfect, good or bad, depends solely on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will of God.  If God had so willed, he might have brought it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about that what is now perfection should be extreme imperfection,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and vice versa.  What is such an assertion, but an open
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: declaration that God, who necessarily understands that which he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wishes, might bring it about by his will, that he should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand things differently from the way in which he does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand them?  This (as we have just shown) is the height of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurdity.  Wherefore, I may turn the argument against its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: employers, as follows:--All things depend on the power of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In order that things should be different from what they are,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's will would necessarily have to be different.  But God's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will cannot be different (as we have just most clearly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstrated) from God's perfection.  Therefore neither can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things be different.  I confess, that the theory which subjects
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all things to the will of an indifferent deity, and asserts that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are all dependent on his fiat, is less far from the truth
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than the theory of those, who maintain that God acts in all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things with a view of promoting what is good.  For these latter
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persons seem to set up something beyond God, which does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: depend on God, but which God in acting looks to as an exemplar,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or which he aims at as a definite goal.  This is only another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: name for subjecting God to the dominion of destiny, an utter
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurdity in respect to God, whom we have shown to be the first
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and only free cause of the essence of all things and also of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their existence.  I need, therefore, spend no time in refuting
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such wild theories.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIV.  God's power is identical with his essence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--From the sole necessity of the essence of God it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows that God is the cause of himself (Prop. xi.) and of all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things (Prop. xvi. and Coroll.).  Wherefore the power of God, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he and all things are and act, is identical with his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXV.  Whatsoever we conceive to be in the power of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily exists.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever is in God's power, must (by the last Prop.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be comprehended in his essence in such a manner, that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follows therefrom, and therefore necessarily exists.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVI.  There is no cause from whose nature some effect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not follow.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever exists expresses God's nature or essence in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a given conditioned manner (by Prop. xxv., Coroll.); that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Prop. xxxiv.), whatsoever exists, expresses in a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned manner God's power, which is the cause of all things,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore an effect must (by Prop. xvi.) necessarily follow.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: APPENDIX:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In the foregoing I have explained the nature and properties
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God.  I have shown that he necessarily exists, that he is one:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he is, and acts solely by the necessity of his own nature;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he is the free cause of all things, and how he is so;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that all things are in God, and so depend on him, that without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him they could neither exist nor be conceived; lastly, that all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things are predetermined by God, not through his free will or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolute fiat, but from the very nature of God or infinite power.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have further, where occasion afforded, taken care to remove the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prejudices, which might impede the comprehension of my
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstrations.  Yet there still remain misconceptions not a few,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which might and may prove very grave hindrances to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding of the concatenation of things, as I have explained
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it above.  I have therefore thought it worth while to bring these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: misconceptions before the bar of reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: All such opinions spring from the notion commonly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entertained, that all things in nature act as men themselves act,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, with an end in view.  It is accepted as certain, that God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself directs all things to a definite goal (for it is said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God made all things for man, and man that he might worship
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him).  I will, therefore, consider this opinion, asking first,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: why it obtains general credence, and why all men are naturally so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prone to adopt it? secondly, I will point out its falsity; and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lastly, I will show how it has given rise to prejudices about
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good and bad, right and wrong, praise and blame, order and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confusion, beauty and ugliness, and the like.  However, this is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not the place to deduce these misconceptions from the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human mind: it will be sufficient here, if I assume as a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: starting point, what ought to be universally admitted, namely,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that all men are born ignorant of the causes of things, that all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have the desire to seek for what is useful to them, and that they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are conscious of such desire.  Herefrom it follows, first, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men think themselves free inasmuch as they are conscious of their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: volitions and desires, and never even dream, in their ignorance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the causes which have disposed them so to wish and desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Secondly, that men do all things for an end, namely, for that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is useful to them, and which they seek.  Thus it comes to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pass that they only look for a knowledge of the final causes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: events, and when these are learned, they are content, as having
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no cause for further doubt.  If they cannot learn such causes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from external sources, they are compelled to turn to considering
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves, and reflecting what end would have induced them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: personally to bring about the given event, and thus they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily judge other natures by their own.  Further, as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: find in themselves and outside themselves many means which assist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them not a little in the search for what is useful, for instance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eyes for seeing, teeth for chewing, herbs and animals for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yielding food, the sun for giving light, the sea for breeding
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fish, &c., they come to look on the whole of nature as a means
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for obtaining such conveniences.  Now as they are aware, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they found these conveniences and did not make them, they think
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have cause for believing, that some other being has made
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them for their use.  As they look upon things as means, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot believe them to be self--created; but, judging from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means which they are accustomed to prepare for themselves, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are bound to believe in some ruler or rulers of the universe
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endowed with human freedom, who have arranged and adapted
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything for human use.  They are bound to estimate the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of such rulers (having no information on the subject) in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with their own nature, and therefore they assert that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the gods ordained everything for the use of man, in order to bind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man to themselves and obtain from him the highest honor.  Hence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also it follows, that everyone thought out for himself, according
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to his abilities, a different way of worshipping God, so that God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: might love him more than his fellows, and direct the whole course
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of nature for the satisfaction of his blind cupidity and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insatiable avarice.  Thus the prejudice developed into
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: superstition, and took deep root in the human mind; and for this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason everyone strove most zealously to understand and explain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the final causes of things; but in their endeavor to show that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature does nothing in vain, i.e. nothing which is useless to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, they only seem to have demonstrated that nature, the gods,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and men are all mad together.  Consider, I pray you, the result:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: among the many helps of nature they were bound to find some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hindrances, such as storms, earthquakes, diseases, &c.: so they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: declared that such things happen, because the gods are angry at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some wrong done to them by men, or at some fault committed in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their worship.  Experience day by day protested and showed by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite examples, that good and evil fortunes fall to the lot of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pious and impious alike; still they would not abandon their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inveterate prejudice, for it was more easy for them to class such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contradictions among other unknown things of whose use they were
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorant, and thus to retain their actual and innate condition of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorance, than to destroy the whole fabric of their reasoning
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and start afresh.  They therefore laid down as an axiom, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's judgments far transcend human understanding.  Such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine might well have sufficed to conceal the truth from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human race for all eternity, if mathematics had not furnished
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another standard of verity in considering solely the essence and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: properties of figures without regard to their final causes.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: There are other reasons (which I need not mention here) besides
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mathematics, which might have caused men's minds to be directed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to these general prejudices, and have led them to the knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the truth.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have now sufficiently explained my first point.  There is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no need to show at length, that nature has no particular goal in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: view, and that final causes are mere human figments.  This, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think, is already evident enough, both from the causes and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foundations on which I have shown such prejudice to be based, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also from Prop. xvi., and the Corollary of Prop. xxxii., and, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, all those propositions in which I have shown, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything in nature proceeds from a sort of necessity, and with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the utmost perfection.  However, I will add a few remarks, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order to overthrow this doctrine of a final cause utterly.  That
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is really a cause it considers as an effect, and vice versa:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it makes that which is by nature first to be last, and that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is highest and most perfect to be most imperfect.  Passing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over the questions of cause and priority as self--evident, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plain from Props. xxi., xxii., xxiii. that the effect is most
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect which is produced immediately by God; the effect which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: requires for its production several intermediate causes is, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that respect, more imperfect.  But if those things which were
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made immediately by God were made to enable him to attain his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: end, then the things which come after, for the sake of which the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first were made, are necessarily the most excellent of all.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, this doctrine does away with the perfection of God:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for, if God acts for an object, he necessarily desires something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he lacks.  Certainly, theologians and metaphysicians draw a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinction between the object of want and the object of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assimilation; still they confess that God made all things for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sake of himself, not for the sake of creation.  They are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unable to point to anything prior to creation, except God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, as an object for which God should act, and are therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: driven to admit (as they clearly must), that God lacked those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things for whose attainment he created means, and further that he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desired them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We must not omit to notice that the followers of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine, anxious to display their talent in assigning final
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes, have imported a new method of argument in proof of their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theory--namely, a reduction, not to the impossible, but to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorance; thus showing that they have no other method of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exhibiting their doctrine.  For example, if a stone falls from a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: roof on to someone's head, and kills him, they will demonstrate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by their new method, that the stone fell in order to kill the man;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for, if it had not by God's will fallen with that object, how
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could so many circumstances (and there are often many concurrent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstances) have all happened together by chance?  Perhaps you
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will answer that the event is due to the facts that the wind was
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blowing, and the man was walking that way.  "But why," they will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insist, "was the wind blowing, and why was the man at that very
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time walking that way?"  If you again answer, that the wind had
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then sprung up because the sea had begun to be agitated the day
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before, the weather being previously calm, and that the man had
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been invited by a friend, they will again insist: "But why was
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sea agitated, and why was the man invited at that time?"
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: So they will pursue their questions from cause to cause, till at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last you take refuge in the will of God--in other words, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sanctuary of ignorance.  So, again, when they survey the frame of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human body, they are amazed; and being ignorant of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes of so great a work of art, conclude that it has been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fashioned, not mechanically, but by divine and supernatural
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: skill, and has been so put together that one part shall not hurt
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hence anyone who seeks for the true causes of miracles, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strives to understand natural phenomena as an intelligent being,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and not to gaze at them like a fool, is set down and denounced as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an impious heretic by those, whom the masses adore as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreters of nature and the gods.  Such persons know that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the removal of ignorance, the wonder which forms their only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: available means for proving and preserving their authority would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vanish also.  But I now quit this subject, and pass on to my
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: third point.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: After men persuaded themselves, that everything which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: created is created for their sake, they were bound to consider as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the chief quality in everything that which is most useful to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves, and to account those things the best of all which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have the most beneficial effect on mankind.  Further, they were
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound to form abstract notions for the explanation of the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things, such as goodness, badness, order, confusion, warmth,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cold, beauty, deformity, and so on; and from the belief that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are free agents arose the further notions of praise and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blame, sin and merit.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I will speak of these latter hereafter, when I treat of human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature; the former I will briefly explain here.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Everything which conduces to health and the worship of God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have called good, everything which hinders these objects
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have styled bad; and inasmuch as those who do not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand the nature of things do not verify phenomena in any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way, but merely imagine them after a fashion, and mistake their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination for understanding, such persons firmly believe that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is an order in things, being really ignorant both of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and their own nature.  When phenomena are of such a kind, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the impression they make on our senses requires little effort of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination, and can consequently be easily remembered, we say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they are well--ordered; if the contrary, that they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ill--ordered or confused.  Further, as things which are easily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagined are more pleasing to us, men prefer order to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confusion--as though there were any order in nature, except in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: relation to our imagination--and say that God has created all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things in order; thus, without knowing it, attributing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination to God, unless, indeed, they would have it that God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foresaw human imagination, and arranged everything, so that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be most easily imagined.  If this be their theory, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would not, perhaps, be daunted by the fact that we find an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of phenomena, far surpassing our imagination, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very many others which confound its weakness.  But enough has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been said on this subject.  The other abstract notions are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing but modes of imagining, in which the imagination is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differently affected: though they are considered by the ignorant
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the chief attributes of things, inasmuch as they believe that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything was created for the sake of themselves; and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according as they are affected by it, style it good or bad,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: healthy or rotten and corrupt.  For instance, if the motion which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects we see communicate to our nerves be conducive to health,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the objects causing it are styled beautiful; if a contrary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion be excited, they are styled ugly.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Things which are perceived through our sense of smell are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: styled fragrant or fetid; if through our taste, sweet or bitter,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: full--flavored or insipid; if through our touch, hard or soft,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rough or smooth, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whatsoever affects our ears is said to give rise to noise,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sound, or harmony.  In this last case, there are men lunatic
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enough to believe, that even God himself takes pleasure in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony; and philosophers are not lacking who have persuaded
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves, that the motion of the heavenly bodies gives rise to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony--all of which instances sufficiently show that everyone
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judges of things according to the state of his brain, or rather
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mistakes for things the forms of his imagination.  We need no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longer wonder that there have arisen all the controversies we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have witnessed, and finally skepticism: for, although human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies in many respects agree, yet in very many others they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differ; so that what seems good to one seems bad to another;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what seems well ordered to one seems confused to another; what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is pleasing to one displeases another, and so on.  I need not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further enumerate, because this is not the place to treat the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject at length, and also because the fact is sufficiently well
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: known.  It is commonly said: "So many men, so many minds;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone is wise in his own way; brains differ as completely as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: palates."  All of which proverbs show, that men judge of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to their mental disposition, and rather imagine than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand: for, if they understood phenomena, they would, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mathematicians attest, be convinced, if not attracted, by what I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have urged.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We have now perceived, that all the explanations commonly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given of nature are mere modes of imagining, and do not indicate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the true nature of anything, but only the constitution of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination; and, although they have names, as though they were
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entities, existing externally to the imagination, I call them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entities imaginary rather than real; and, therefore, all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arguments against us drawn from such abstractions are easily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rebutted.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Many argue in this way.  If all things follow from a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of the absolutely perfect nature of God, why are there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so many imperfections in nature? such, for instance, as things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corrupt to the point of putridity, loathsome deformity,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confusion, evil, sin, &c.  But these reasoners are, as I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said, easily confuted, for the perfection of things is to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reckoned only from their own nature and power; things are not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more or less perfect, according as they delight or offend human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: senses, or according as they are serviceable or repugnant to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mankind.  To those who ask why God did not so create all men,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they should be governed only by reason, I give no answer but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this: because matter was not lacking to him for the creation of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: every degree of perfection from highest to lowest; or, more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strictly, because the laws of his nature are so vast, as to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suffice for the production of everything conceivable by an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite intelligence, as I have shown in Prop. xvi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the misconceptions I have undertaken to note; if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there are any more of the same sort, everyone may easily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dissipate them for himself with the aid of a little reflection.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Part II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ON THE NATURE AND ORIGIN OF THE MIND
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PREFACE
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I now pass on to explaining the results, which must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follow from the essence of God, or of the eternal and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite being; not, indeed, all of them (for we proved in Part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: i., Prop. xvi., that an infinite number must follow in an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of ways), but only those which are able to lead
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, as it were by the hand, to the knowledge of the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and its highest blessedness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITIONS
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITION I.  By body I mean a mode which expresses in a certain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determinate manner the essence of God, in so far as he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considered as an extended thing.  (See Pt. i., Prop. xxv.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITION II.  I consider as belonging to the essence of a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that, which being given, the thing is necessarily given also,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, which being removed, the thing is necessarily removed also;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in other words, that without which the thing, and which itself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without the thing, can neither be nor be conceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITION III. By idea, I mean the mental conception which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: formed by the mind as a thinking thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation.--I say conception rather than perception, because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the word perception seems to imply that the mind is passive in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to the object; whereas conception seems to express an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity of the mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITION IV.  By an adequate idea, I mean an idea which, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is considered in itself, without relation to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object, has all the properties or intrinsic marks of a true idea.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation.--I say intrinsic, in order to exclude that mark
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is extrinsic, namely, the agreement between the idea and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its object (ideatum).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITION V.  Duration is the indefinite continuance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation.--I say indefinite, because it cannot be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined through the existence itself of the existing thing, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by its efficient cause, which necessarily gives the existence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thing, but does not take it away.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITION VI.  Reality and perfection I use as synonymous terms.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITION VII.  By particular things, I mean things which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: finite and have a conditioned existence; but if several
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual things concur in one action, so as to be all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneously the effect of one cause, I consider them all, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far, as one particular thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOMS
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  The essence of man does not involve necessary existence, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, it may, in the order of nature, come to pass that this or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that man does or does not exist.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  Man thinks.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  Modes of thinking, such as love, desire, or any other of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the passions, do not take place, unless there be in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual an idea of the thing loved, desired, &c.  But the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can exist without the presence of any other mode of thinking.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  We perceive that a certain body is affected in many ways.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  We feel and perceive no particular things, save bodies and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modes of thought.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
