text: N.B.  The Postulates are given after the conclusion of Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xiii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROPOSITIONS
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. I.  Thought is an attribute of God, or God is a thinking
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Particular thoughts, or this and that thought, are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modes which, in a certain conditioned manner, express the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God (Pt. i., Prop. xxv., Coroll.).  God therefore possesses
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the attribute (Pt. i., Def. v.) of which the concept is involved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in all particular thoughts, which latter are conceived thereby.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thought, therefore, is one of the infinite attributes of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which express God's eternal and infinite essence (Pt. i., Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vi.).  In other words, God is a thinking thing.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition is also evident from the fact, that we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are able to conceive an infinite thinking being.  For, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as a thinking being is conceived as thinking more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thoughts, so is it conceived as containing more reality or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection.  Therefore a being, which can think an infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of things in an infinite number of ways, is, necessarily,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in respect of thinking, infinite.  As, therefore, from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consideration of thought alone, we conceive an infinite being,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought is necessarily (Pt. i., Deff. iv. and vi.) one of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite attributes of God, as we were desirous of showing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. II.  Extension is an attribute of God, or God is an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extended thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The proof of this proposition is similar to that of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the last.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. III.  In God there is necessarily the idea not only of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence, but also of all things which necessarily follow from his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--God (by the first Prop. of this Part) can think an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of things in infinite ways, or (what is the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, by Prop. xvi., Part i.) can form the idea of his essence,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and of all things which necessarily follow therefrom.  Now all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is in the power of God necessarily is (Pt. i., Prop. xxxv.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, such an idea as we are considering necessarily is, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in God alone.  Q.E.D.  (Part i., Prop. xv.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The multitude understand by the power of God the free
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will of God, and the right over all things that exist, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter are accordingly generally considered as contingent.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is said that God has the power to destroy all things, and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reduce them to nothing.  Further, the power of God is very often
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: likened to the power of kings.  But this doctrine we have refuted
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Pt. i., Prop. xxxii., Corolls. i. and ii.), and we have shown
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Part i., Prop. xvi.) that God acts by the same necessity, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that by which he understands himself; in other words, as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows from the necessity of the divine nature (as all admit),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God understands himself, so also does it follow by the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity, that God performs infinite acts in infinite ways.  We
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further showed (Part i., Prop. xxxiv.), that God's power is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: identical with God's essence in action; therefore it is as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible for us to conceive God as not acting, as to conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him as non--existent.  If we might pursue the subject further, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could point out, that the power which is commonly attributed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God is not only human (as showing that God is conceived by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: multitude as a man, or in the likeness of a man), but involves a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negation of power.  However, I am unwilling to go over the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ground so often.  I would only beg the reader again and again, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: turn over frequently in his mind what I have said in Part I from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. xvi. to the end.  No one will be able to follow my meaning,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless he is scrupulously careful not to confound the power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God with the human power and right of kings.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IV.  The idea of God, from which an infinite number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things follow in infinite ways, can only be one.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Infinite intellect comprehends nothing save the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes of God and his modifications (Part i., Prop. xxx.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now God is one (Part i., Prop. xiv., Coroll.).  Therefore the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of God, wherefrom an infinite number of things follow in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite ways, can only be one.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. V.  The actual being of ideas owns God as its cause, only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he is considered as a thinking thing, not in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he is unfolded in any other attribute; that is, the ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: both of the attributes of God and of particular things do not own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as their efficient cause their objects (ideata) or the things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived, but God himself in so far as he is a thinking thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from Prop. iii. of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Part.  We there drew the conclusion, that God can form the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of his essence, and of all things which follow necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom, solely because he is a thinking thing, and not because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is the object of his own idea.  Wherefore the actual being of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas owns for cause God, in so far as he is a thinking thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It may be differently proved as follows: the actual being of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas is (obviously) a mode of thought, that is (Part i., Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxv., Coroll.) a mode which expresses in a certain manner the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of God, in so far as he is a thinking thing, and therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Part i., Prop. x.) involves the conception of no other attribute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, and consequently (by Part i., Ax. iv.) is not the effect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of any attribute save thought.  Therefore the actual being of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas owns God as its cause, in so far as he is considered as a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking thing, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VI.  The modes of any given attribute are caused by God, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as he is considered through the attribute of which they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are modes, and not in so far as he is considered through any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other attribute.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Each attribute is conceived through itself, without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any other (Part i., Prop. x.); wherefore the modes of each
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute involve the conception of that attribute, but not of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any other.  Thus (Part i., Ax. iv.) they are caused by God, only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he is considered through the attribute whose modes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are, and not in so far as he is considered through any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence the actual being of things, which are not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modes of thought, does not follow from the divine nature, because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that nature has prior knowledge of the things.  Things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: represented in ideas follow, and are derived from their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular attribute, in the same manner, and with the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity as ideas follow (according to what we have shown) from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the attribute of thought.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VII.  The order and connection of ideas is the same as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order and connection of things.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from Part i., Ax. iv.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of everything that is caused depends on a knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the cause, whereof it is an effect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence God's power of thinking is equal to his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: realized power of action--that is, whatsoever follows from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite nature of God in the world of extension (formaliter),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows without exception in the same order and connection from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of God in the world of thought (objective).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Before going any further, I wish to recall to mind what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has been pointed out above--namely, that whatsoever can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived by the infinite intellect as constituting the essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of substance, belongs altogether only to one substance:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, substance thinking and substance extended are one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the same substance, comprehended now through one attribute,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now through the other.  So, also, a mode of extension and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of that mode are one and the same thing, though expressed in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two ways.  This truth seems to have been dimly recognized by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those Jews who maintained that God, God's intellect, and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things understood by God are identical.  For instance, a circle
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing in nature, and the idea of a circle existing, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also in God, are one and the same thing displayed through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different attributes.  Thus, whether we conceive nature under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute of extension, or under the attribute of thought, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under any other attribute, we shall find the same order, or one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the same chain of causes--that is, the same things following
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in either case.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I said that God is the cause of an idea--for instance, of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of a circle,--in so far as he is a thinking thing; and of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circle, in so far as he is an extended thing, simply because the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual being of the idea of a circle can only be perceived as a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proximate cause through another mode of thinking, and that again
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through another, and so on to infinity; so that, so long as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consider things as modes of thinking, we must explain the order
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the whole of nature, or the whole chain of causes, through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute of thought only.  And, in so far as we consider things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as modes of extension, we must explain the order of the whole of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature through the attributes of extension only; and so on, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the case of the other attributes.  Wherefore of things as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are in themselves God is really the cause, inasmuch as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consists of infinite attributes.  I cannot for the present
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain my meaning more clearly.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VIII.  The ideas of particular things, or of modes, that do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not exist, must be comprehended in the infinite idea of God, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same way as the formal essences of particular things or modes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are contained in the attributes of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from the last; it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood more clearly from the preceding note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence, so long as particular things do not exist,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except in so far as they are comprehended in the attributes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, their representations in thought or ideas do not exist,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except in so far as the infinite idea of God exists; and when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular things are said to exist, not only in so far as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are involved in the attributes of God, but also in so far as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are said to continue, their ideas will also involve existence,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through which they are said to continue.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--If anyone desires an example to throw more light on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this question, I shall, I fear, not be able to give him any,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which adequately explains the thing of which I here speak,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as it is unique; however, I will endeavour to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: illustrate it as far as possible.  The nature of a circle is such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that if any number of straight lines intersect within it, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rectangles formed by their segments will be equal to one another;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus, infinite equal rectangles are contained in a circle.  Yet
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: none of these rectangles can be said to exist, except in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the circle exists; nor can the idea of any of these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rectangles be said to exist, except in so far as they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comprehended in the idea of the circle.  Let us grant that, from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this infinite number of rectangles, two only exist.  The ideas of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these two not only exist, in so far as they are contained in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the circle, but also as they involve the existence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those rectangles; wherefore they are distinguished from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remaining ideas of the remaining rectangles.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IX.  The idea of an individual thing actually existing is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: caused by God, not in so far as he is infinite, but in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is considered as affected by another idea of a thing actually
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing, of which he is the cause, in so far as he is affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by a third idea, and so on to infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The idea of an individual thing actually existing is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an individual mode of thinking, and is distinct from other modes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the Corollary and note to Prop. viii. of this part); thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by Prop. vi. of this part) it is caused by God, in so far only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he is a thinking thing.  But not (by Prop. xxviii. of Part i.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he is a thing thinking absolutely, only in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is considered as affected by another mode of thinking; and he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the cause of this latter, as being affected by a third, and so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on to infinity.  Now, the order and connection of ideas is (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. vii. of this book) the same as the order and connection of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes.   Therefore of a given individual idea another individual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea, or God, in so far as he is considered as modified by that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea, is the cause; and of this second idea God is the cause, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as he is affected by another idea, and so on to infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Whatsoever takes place in the individual object of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any idea, the knowledge thereof is in God, in so far only as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has the idea of the object.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever takes place in the object of any idea, its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea is in God (by Prop. iii. of this part), not in so far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is infinite, but in so far as he is considered as affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another idea of an individual thing (by the last Prop.); but (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. vii. of this part) the order and connection of ideas is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same as the order and connection of things.  The knowledge,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, of that which takes place in any individual object
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be in God, in so far only as he has the idea of that object.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. X.  The being of substance does not appertain to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of man--in other words, substance does not constitute the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual being[2] of man.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [2] "Forma"
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The being of substance involves necessary existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Part i., Prop. vii.).  If, therefore, the being of substance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appertains to the essence of man, substance being granted, man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would necessarily be granted also (II. Def. ii.), and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, man would necessarily exist, which is absurd
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. Ax. i.).  Therefore, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition may also be proved from I.v., in which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is shown that there cannot be two substances of the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature; for as there may be many men, the being of substance is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not that which constitutes the actual being of man.  Again, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition is evident from the other properties of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance--namely, that substance is in its nature infinite,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: immutable, indivisible, &c., as anyone may see for himself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows, that the essence of man is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituted by certain modifications of the attributes of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For (by the last Prop.) the being of substance does not belong to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of man.  That essence therefore (by i.  15) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something which is in God, and which without God can neither be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor be conceived, whether it be a modification (i. 25. Coroll.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or a mode which expresses God's nature in a certain conditioned
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Everyone must surely admit, that nothing can be or be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived without God.  All men agree that God is the one and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only cause of all things, both of their essence and of their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence; that is, God is not only the cause of things in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to their being made (secundum fieri), but also in respect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to their being (secundum esse).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: At the same time many assert, that that, without which a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing cannot be nor be conceived, belongs to the essence of that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing; wherefore they believe that either the nature of God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appertains to the essence of created things, or else that created
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things can be or be conceived without God; or else, as is more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: probably the case, they hold inconsistent doctrines.  I think the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause for such confusion is mainly, that they do not keep to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proper order of philosophic thinking.  The nature of God, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be reflected on first, inasmuch as it is prior both in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of knowledge and the order of nature, they have taken to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last in the order of knowledge, and have put into the first place
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what they call the objects of sensation; hence, while they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considering natural phenomena, they give no attention at all to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the divine nature, and, when afterwards they apply their mind to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the study of the divine nature, they are quite unable to bear in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind the first hypotheses, with which they have overlaid the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of natural phenomena, inasmuch as such hypotheses are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no help towards understanding the divine nature.  So that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hardly to be wondered at, that these persons contradict
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves freely.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, I pass over this point.  My intention her was only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to give a reason for not saying, that that, without which a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be or be conceived, belongs to the essence of that thing:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual things cannot be or be conceived without God, yet God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not appertain to their essence.  I said that "I considered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as belonging to the essence of a thing that, which being given,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thing is necessarily given also, and which being removed, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing is necessarily removed also; or that without which the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, and which itself without the thing can neither be nor be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived."  (II. Def. ii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XI.  The first element, which constitutes the actual being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the human mind, is the idea of some particular thing actually
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The essence of man (by the Coroll. of the last Prop.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is constituted by certain modes of the attributes of God, namely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by II. Ax. ii.), by the modes of thinking, of all which (by II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ax. iii.) the idea is prior in nature, and, when the idea is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given, the other modes (namely, those of which the idea is prior
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in nature) must be in the same individual (by the same Axiom).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore an idea is the first element constituting the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind.  But not the idea of a non--existent thing, for then (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: viii. Coroll.) the idea itself cannot be said to exist; it must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore be the idea of something actually existing.  But not of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an infinite thing.  For an infinite thing (I. xxi., xxii.), must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always necessarily exist; this would (by II. Ax. i.) involve an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurdity.  Therefore the first element, which constitutes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual being of the human mind, is the idea of something actually
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows, that the human mind is part of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the infinite intellect of God; thus when we say, that the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind perceives this or that, we make the assertion, that God has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this or that idea, not in so far as he is infinite, but in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he is displayed through the nature of the human mind, or in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he constitutes the essence of the human mind; and when we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say that God has this or that idea, not only in so far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitutes the essence of the human mind, but also in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he, simultaneously with the human mind, has the further idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another thing, we assert that the human mind perceives a thing in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part or inadequately.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Here, I doubt not, readers will come to a stand, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will call to mind many things which will cause them to hesitate;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I therefore beg them to accompany me slowly, step by step, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not to pronounce on my statements, till they have read to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: end.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XII.  Whatsoever comes to pass in the object of the idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which constitutes the human mind, must be perceived by the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, or there will necessarily be an idea in the human mind of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the said occurrence.  That is, if the object of the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituting the human mind be a body, nothing can take place in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that body without being perceived by the mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever comes to pass in the object of any idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the knowledge thereof is necessarily in God (II. ix. Coroll.), in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as he is considered as affected by the idea of the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object, that is (II. xi.), in so far as he constitutes the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of anything.  Therefore, whatsoever takes place in the object
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituting the idea of the human mind, the knowledge thereof is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily in God, in so far as he constitutes the essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human mind; that is (by II. xi. Coroll.) the knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the said thing will necessarily be in the mind, in other words
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind perceives it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition is also evident, and is more clearly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be understood from II. vii., which see.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIII.  The object of the idea constituting the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the body, in other words a certain mode of extension which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actually exists, and nothing else.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If indeed the body were not the object of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, the ideas of the modifications of the body would not be in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God (II. ix. Coroll.) in virtue of his constituting our mind, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in virtue of his constituting the mind of something else; that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (II. xi. Coroll.) the ideas of the modifications of the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would not be in our mind: now (by II. Ax. iv.) we do possess the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the modifications of the body.  Therefore the object of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea constituting the human mind is the body, and the body as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it actually exists (II. xi.).  Further, if there were any other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of the idea constituting the mind besides body, then, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing can exist from which some effect does not follow (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvi.) there would necessarily have to be in our mind an idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which would be the effect of that other object (II. xi.); but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (I. Ax. v.) there is no such idea.  Wherefore the object of our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind is the body as it exists, and nothing else.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We thus comprehend, not only that the human mind is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: united to the body, but also the nature of the union between mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and body.  However, no one will be able to grasp this adequately
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or distinctly, unless he first has adequate knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of our body.  The propositions we have advanced hitherto
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have been entirely general, applying not more to men than to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other individual things, all of which, though in different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: degrees, are animated.[3]  For of everything there is necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an idea in God, of which God is the cause, in the same way as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is an idea of the human body; thus  whatever we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: asserted of the idea of the human body must necessarily also be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: asserted of the idea of everything else.  Still, on the other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand, we cannot deny that ideas, like objects, differ one from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other, one being more excellent than another and containing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more reality, just as the object of one idea is more excellent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than the object of another idea, and contains more reality.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [3] "Animata"
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore, in order to determine, wherein the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differs from other things, and wherein it surpasses them, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary for us to know the nature of its object, that is, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human body.  What this nature is, I am not able here to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain, nor is it necessary for the proof of what I advance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that I should do so.  I will only say generally, that in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as any given body is more fitted than others for doing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many actions or receiving many impressions at once, so also is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, of which it is the object, more fitted than others for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forming many simultaneous perceptions; and the more the actions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body depend on itself alone, and the fewer other bodies
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concur with it in action, the more fitted is the mind of which it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the object for distinct comprehension.  We may thus recognize
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the superiority of one mind over others, and may further see the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause, why we have only a very confused knowledge of our body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and also many kindred questions, which I will, in the following
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: propositions, deduce from what has been advanced.  Wherefore I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have thought it worth while to explain and prove more strictly my
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present statements.  In order to do so, I must premise a few
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: propositions concerning the nature of bodies.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOM I.  All bodies are either in motion or at rest.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOM II.  Every body is moved sometimes more slowly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sometimes more quickly.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: LEMMA I.  Bodies are distinguished from one another in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect of motion and rest, quickness and slowness, and not in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect of substance.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The first part of this proposition is, I take it,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--evident.  That bodies are not distinguished in respect of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance, is plain both from I. v. and I. viii.  It is brought
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out still more clearly from I. xv, note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: LEMMA II.  All bodies agree in certain respects.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All bodies agree in the fact, that they involve the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception of one and the same attribute (II., Def. i.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, in the fact that they may be moved less or more quickly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and may be absolutely in motion or at rest.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: LEMMA III.  A body in motion or at rest must be determined to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion or rest by another body, which other body has been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to motion or rest by a third body, and that third
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: again by a fourth, and so on to infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Bodies are individual things (II., Def. i.), which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Lemma I.) are distinguished one from the other in respect to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion and rest; thus (I. xxviii.) each must necessarily be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to motion or rest by another individual thing, namely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. vi.), by another body, which other body is also (Ax. i.) in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion or at rest.  And this body again can only have been set in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion or caused to rest by being determined by a third body to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion or rest.   This third body again by a fourth, and so on to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinity.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows, that a body in motion keeps in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion, until it is determined to a state of rest by some other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body; and a body at rest remains so, until it is determined to a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state of motion by some other body.  This is indeed self--evident.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For when I suppose, for instance, that a given body, A, is at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest, and do not take into consideration other bodies in motion,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I cannot affirm anything concerning the body A, except that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at rest.  If it afterwards comes to pass that A is in motion,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this cannot have resulted from its having been at rest, for no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other consequence could have been involved than its remaining at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest.  If, on the other hand, A be given in motion, we shall, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as we only consider A, be unable to affirm anything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning it, except that it is in motion.   If A is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subsequently found to be at rest, this rest cannot be the result
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of A's previous motion, for such motion can only have led to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continued motion; the state of rest therefore must have resulted
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from something, which was not in A, namely, from an external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause determining A to a state of rest.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Axiom I.--All modes, wherein one body is affected by another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, follow simultaneously from the nature of the body affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the body affecting; so that one and the same body may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moved in different modes, according to the difference in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of the bodies moving it; on the other hand, different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies may be moved in different modes by one and the same body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Axiom II.--When a body in motion impinges on another body at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest, which it is unable to move, it recoils, in order to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continue its motion, and the angle made by the line of motion in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the recoil and the plane of the body at rest, whereon the moving
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body has impinged, will be equal to the angle formed by the line
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of motion of incidence and the same plane.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: So far we have been speaking only of the most simple bodies,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are only distinguished one from the other by motion and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest, quickness and slowness.  We now pass on to compound bodies.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Definition.--When any given bodies of the same or different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: magnitude are compelled by other bodies to remain in contact, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if they be moved at the same or different rates of speed, so that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their mutual movements should preserve among themselves a certain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fixed relation, we say that such bodies are in union, and that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: together they compose one body or individual, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguished from other bodies by the fact of this union.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Axiom III.--In proportion as the parts of an individual, or a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compound body, are in contact over a greater or less superficies,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they will with greater or less difficulty admit of being moved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from their position; consequently the individual will, with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater or less difficulty, be brought to assume another form.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Those bodies, whose parts are in contact over large superficies,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are called hard; those, whose parts are in contact over small
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: superficies, are called soft; those, whose parts are in motion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: among one another, are called fluid.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: LEMMA IV.  If from a body or individual, compounded of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: several bodies, certain bodies be separated, and if, at the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time, an equal number of other bodies of the same nature take
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their place, the individual will preserve its nature as before,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without any change in its actuality (forma).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Bodies (Lemma i.) are not distinguished in respect of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance: that which constitutes the actuality (formam) of an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual consists (by the last Def.) in a union of bodies; but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this union, although there is a continual change of bodies, will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by our hypothesis) be maintained; the individual, therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will retain its nature as before, both in respect of substance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and in respect of mode.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: LEMMA V.  If the parts composing an individual become greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or less, but in such proportion, that they all preserve the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mutual relations of motion and rest, the individual will still
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve its original nature, and its actuality will not be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changed.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The same as for the last Lemma.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: LEMMA VI.  If certain bodies composing an individual be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compelled to change the motion, which they have in one direction,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for motion in another direction, but in such a manner, that they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be able to continue their motions and their mutual communication
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the same relations as before, the individual will retain its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own nature without any change of its actuality.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is self--evident, for the individual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is supposed to retain all that, which, in its definition, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spoke of as its actual being.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: LEMMA VII.  Furthermore, the individual thus composed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserves its nature, whether it be, as a whole, in motion or at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest, whether it be moved in this or that direction; so long as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each part retains its motion, and preserves its communication
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with other parts as before.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from the definition of an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual prefixed to Lemma iv.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We thus see, how a composite individual may be affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in many different ways, and preserve its nature notwithstanding.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus far we have conceived an individual as composed of bodies
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only distinguished one from the other in respect of motion and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest, speed and slowness; that is, of bodies of the most simple
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: character.  If, however, we now conceive another individual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: composed of several individuals of diverse natures, we shall find
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the number of ways in which it can be affected, without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: losing its nature, will be greatly multiplied.  Each of its parts
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would consist of several bodies, and therefore (by Lemma vi.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each part would admit, without change to its nature, of quicker
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or slower motion, and would consequently be able to transmit its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motions more quickly or more slowly to the remaining parts.  If
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we further conceive a third kind of individuals composed of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals of this second kind, we shall find that they may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected in a still greater number of ways without changing their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actuality.  We may easily proceed thus to infinity, and conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the whole of nature as one individual, whose parts, that is, all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies, vary in infinite ways, without any change in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual as a whole.  I should feel bound to explain and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstrate this point at more length, if I were writing a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: special treatise on body.  But I have already said that such is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not my object; I have only touched on the question, because it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enables me to prove easily that which I have in view.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: POSTULATES
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  The human body is composed of a number of individual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts, of diverse nature, each one of which is in itself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extremely complex.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  Of the individual parts composing the human body some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are fluid, some soft, some hard.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  The individual parts composing the human body, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently the human body itself, are affected in a variety of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways by external bodies.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  The human body stands in need for its preservation of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of other bodies, by which it is continually, so to speak,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regenerated.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  When the fluid part of the human body is determined by an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body to impinge often on another soft part, it changes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the surface of the latter, and, as it were, leaves the impression
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereupon of the external body which impels it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI.  The human body can move external bodies, and arrange
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them in a variety of ways.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIV.  The human mind is capable of perceiving a great
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of things, and is so in proportion as its body is capable
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of receiving a great number of impressions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The human body (by Post. iii. and vi.) is affected in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very many ways by external bodies, and is capable in very many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways of affecting external bodies.  But (II. xii.)  the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind must perceive all that takes place in the human body; the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human mind is, therefore, capable of perceiving a great number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, and is so in proportion, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XV.  The idea, which constitutes the actual being of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human mind, is not simple, but compounded of a great number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The idea constituting the actual being of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind is the idea of the body (II. xiii.), which (Post. i.) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: composed of a great number of complex individual parts.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is necessarily in God the idea of each individual part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof the body is composed (II. viii. Coroll.); therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. vii.), the idea of the human body is composed of these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: numerous ideas of its component parts.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVI.  The idea of every mode, in which the human body is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by external bodies, must involve the nature of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, and also the nature of the external body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All the modes, in which any given body is affected,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow from the nature of the body affected, and also from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of the affecting body (by Ax. i., after the Coroll. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lemma iii.), wherefore their idea also necessarily (by I. Ax.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iv.) involves the nature of both bodies; therefore, the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: every mode, in which the human body is affected by external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies, involves the nature of the human body and of the external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--Hence it follows, first, that the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceives the nature of a variety of bodies, together with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of its own.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--It follows, secondly, that the ideas, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have of external bodies, indicate rather the constitution of our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own body than the nature of external bodies.  I have amply
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: illustrated this in the Appendix to Part I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVII.  If the human body is affected in a manner which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves the nature of any external body, the human mind will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard the said external body as actually existing, or as present
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to itself, until the human body be affected in such a way, as to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exclude the existence or the presence of the said external body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is self--evident, for so long as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body continues to be thus affected, so long will the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind (II. xii.) regard this modification of the body--that is (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the last Prop.), it will have the idea of the mode as actually
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing, and this idea involves the nature of the external body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In other words, it will have the idea which does not exclude, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: postulates the existence or presence of the nature of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body; therefore the mind (by II. xvi., Coroll. i.) will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard the external body as actually existing, until it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--The mind is able to regard as present external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies, by which the human body has once been affected, even
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though they be no longer in existence or present.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--When external bodies determine the fluid parts of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body, so that they often impinge on the softer parts, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: change the surface of the last named (Post. v.); hence (Ax. ii.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after the Coroll. of Lemma iii.) they are refracted therefrom in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a different manner from that which they followed before such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: change; and, further, when afterwards they impinge on the new
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surfaces by their own spontaneous movement, they will be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: refracted in the same manner, as though they had been impelled
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards those surfaces by external bodies; consequently, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will, while they continue to be thus refracted, affect the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body in the same manner, whereof the mind (II. xii.) will again
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: take cognizance--that is (II. xvii.), the mind will again regard
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the external body as present, and will do so, as often as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fluid parts of the human body impinge on the aforesaid surfaces
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by their own spontaneous motion.  Wherefore, although the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external bodies, by which the human body has once been affected,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be no longer in existence, the mind will nevertheless regard them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as present, as often as this action of the body is repeated.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We thus see how it comes about, as is often the case,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we regard as present many things which are not.  It is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible that the same result may be brought about by other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes; but I think it suffices for me here to have indicated
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one possible explanation, just as well as if I had pointed out
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the true cause.  Indeed, I do not think I am very far from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth, for all my assumptions are based on postulates, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest, almost without exception, on experience, that cannot be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: controverted by those who have shown, as we have, that the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, as we feel it, exists (Coroll. after II. xiii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Furthermore (II. vii.  Coroll., II. xvi. Coroll. ii.), we clearly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand what is the difference between the idea, say, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Peter, which constitutes the essence of Peter's mind, and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the said Peter, which is in another man, say, Paul.  The
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: former directly answers to the essence of Peter's own body, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only  implies existence so long as Peter exists; the latter
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicates rather the disposition of Paul's body than the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Peter, and, therefore, while this disposition of Paul's body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lasts, Paul's mind will regard Peter as present to itself, even
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though he no longer exists.  Further, to retain the usual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phraseology,  the modifications of the human body, of which the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas represent external bodies as present to us, we will call
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the images of things, though they do not recall the figure of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things.  When the mind regards bodies in this fashion, we say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it imagines.  I will here draw attention to the fact, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order to indicate where error lies, that the imaginations of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, looked at in themselves, do not contain error.  The mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not err in the mere act of imagining, but only in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is regarded as being without the idea, which excludes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of such things as it imagines to be present to it.  If
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, while imagining non--existent things as present to it,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is at the same time conscious that they do not really exist, this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of imagination must be set down to the efficacy of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, and not to a fault, especially if this faculty of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination depend solely on its own nature--that is (I. Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii.), if this faculty of imagination be free.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVIII.  If the human body has once been affected by two or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more bodies at the same time, when the mind afterwards imagines
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any of them, it will straightway remember the others also.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind (II. xvii. Coroll.) imagines any given body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because the human body is affected and disposed by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impressions from an external body, in the same manner as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected when certain of its parts are acted on by the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body; but (by our hypothesis) the body was then so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposed, that the mind imagined two bodies at once; therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it will also in the second case imagine two bodies at once, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, when it imagines one, will straightway remember the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We now clearly see what Memory is.  It is simply a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain association of ideas involving the nature of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: outside the human body, which association arises in the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the order and association of the modifications
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (affectiones) of the human body.  I say, first, it is an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: association of those ideas only, which involve the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things outside the human body: not of ideas which answer to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of the said things: ideas of the modifications of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body are, strictly speaking (II. xvi.), those which involve
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature both of the human body and of external bodies.  I say,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secondly, that this association arises according to the order and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: association of the modifications of the human body, in order to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguish it from that association of ideas, which arises from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the order of the intellect, whereby the mind perceives things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through their primary causes, and which is in all men the same.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: And hence we can further clearly understand, why the mind from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thought of one thing, should straightway arrive at the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought of another thing, which has no similarity with the first;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for instance, from the thought of the word pomum (an apple), a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Roman would straightway arrive at the thought of the fruit apple,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which has no similitude with the articulate sound in question,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor anything in common with it, except that the body of the man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has often been affected by these two things; that is, that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man has often heard the word pomum, while he was looking at the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fruit; similarly every man will go on from one thought to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, according as his habit has ordered the images of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in his body.  For a soldier, for instance, when he sees the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tracks of a horse in sand, will at once pass from the thought of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a horse to the thought of a horseman, and thence to the thought
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of war, &c.; while a countryman will proceed from the thought of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a horse to the thought of a plough, a field, &c.  Thus every man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will follow this or that train of thought, according as he has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been in the habit of conjoining and associating the mental images
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things in this or that manner.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIX.  The human mind has no knowledge of the body, and does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not know it to exist, save through the ideas of the modifications
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby the body is affected.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The human mind is the very idea or knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body (II. xiii.), which (II. ix.) is in God, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is regarded as affected by another idea of a particular thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actually existing: or, inasmuch as (Post. iv.) the human body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stands in need of very many bodies whereby it is, as it were,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continually regenerated; and the order and connection of ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the same as the order and connection of causes (II. vii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this idea will therefore be in God, in so far as he is regarded
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as affected by the ideas of very many particular things.  Thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God has the idea of the human body, or knows the human body, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as he is affected by very many other ideas, and not in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he constitutes the nature of the human mind; that is (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. xi. Coroll.), the human mind does not know the human body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But the ideas of the modifications of body are in God, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as  he constitutes the nature of the human mind, or the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind perceives those modifications (II. xii.), and consequently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xvi.) the human body itself, and as actually existing;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the mind perceives thus far only the human body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XX.  The idea or knowledge of the human mind is also in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, following in God in the same manner, and being referred to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God in the same manner, as the idea or knowledge of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Thought is an attribute of God (II. i.); therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. iii.) there must necessarily be in God the idea both of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought itself and of all its modifications, consequently also of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human mind (II. xi.).  Further, this idea or knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind does not follow from God, in so far as he is infinite, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he is affected by another idea of an individual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
