text: thing (II. ix.).  But (II. vii.) the order and connection of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas is the same as the order and connection of causes;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore this idea or knowledge of the mind is in God and is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to God, in the same manner as the idea or knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXI.  This idea of the mind is united to the mind in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same way as the mind is united to the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--That the mind is united to the body we have shown from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fact, that the body is the object of the mind (II. xii. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xiii.); and so for the same reason the idea of the mind must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: united with its object, that is, with the mind in the same manner
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the mind is united to the body.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition is comprehended much more clearly from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what we have said in the note to II. vii.  We there showed that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of body and body, that is, mind and body (II. xiii.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are one and the same individual conceived now under the attribute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of thought, now under the attribute of extension; wherefore the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the mind and the mind itself are one and the same thing,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is conceived under one and the same attribute, namely,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought.  The idea of the mind, I repeat, and the mind itself are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in God by the same necessity and follow from him from the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of thinking.  Strictly speaking, the idea of the mind, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, the idea of an idea, is nothing but the distinctive quality
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (forma) of the idea in so far as it is conceived as a mode of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought without reference to the object; if a man knows
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything, he, by that very fact, knows that he knows it, and at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same time knows that he knows that he knows it, and so on to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinity.  But I will treat of this hereafter.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXII.  The human mind perceives not only the modifications
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body, but also the ideas of such modifications.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The ideas of the ideas of modifications follow in God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the same manner, and are referred to God in the same manner,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the ideas of the said modifications.  This is proved in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same way as II. xx.  But the ideas of the modifications of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body are in the human mind (II. xii.), that is, in God, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he constitutes the essence of the human mind; therefore the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas of these ideas will be in God, in so far as he has the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge or idea of the human mind, that is (II. xxi.), they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be in the human mind itself, which therefore perceives not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only the modifications of the body, but also the ideas of such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIII.  The mind does not know itself, except in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it perceives the ideas of the modifications of the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The idea or knowledge of the mind (II. xx.) follows in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God in the same manner, and is referred to God in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner, as the idea or knowledge of the body.  But since (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xix.) the human mind does not know the human body itself, that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xi. Coroll.), since the knowledge of the human body is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to God, in so far as he constitutes the nature of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human mind; therefore, neither is the knowledge of the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to God, in so far as he constitutes the essence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human mind; therefore (by the same Coroll. II. xi.), the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind thus far has no knowledge of itself.  Further the ideas of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the modifications, whereby the body is affected, involve the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of the human body itself (II. xvi.), that is (II. xiii.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they agree with the nature of the mind; wherefore the knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of these ideas necessarily involves knowledge of the mind; but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the last Prop.) the knowledge of these ideas is in the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind itself; wherefore the human mind thus far only has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of itself.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIV.  The human mind does not involve an adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of the parts composing the human body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The parts composing the human body do not belong to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of that body, except in so far as they communicate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their motions to one another in a certain fixed relation (Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after Lemma iii.), not in so far as they can be regarded as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals without relation to the human body.  The parts of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body are highly complex individuals  (Post. i.), whose
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts (Lemma iv.) can be separated from the human body without in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any way destroying the nature and distinctive quality of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter, and they can communicate their motions (Ax. i., after
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lemma iii.) to other bodies in another relation; therefore (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iii.)  the idea or knowledge of each part will be in God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch (II. ix.) as he is regarded as affected by another idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a particular thing, which particular thing is prior in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of nature to the aforesaid part (II. vii.).  We may affirm
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same thing of each part of each individual composing the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body; therefore, the knowledge of each part composing the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body is in God, in so far as he is affected by very many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas of things, and not in so far as he has the idea of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body only, in other words, the idea which constitutes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of the human mind (II. xiii); therefore (II. xi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), the human mind does not involve an adequate knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the human body.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXV.  The idea of each modification of the human body does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not involve an adequate knowledge of the external body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We have shown that the idea of a modification of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body involves the nature of an external body, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that external body conditions the human body in a given manner.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, in so far as the external body is an individual, which has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no reference to the human body, the knowledge or idea thereof is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in God (II. ix.), in so far as God is regarded as affected by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of a further thing, which (II. vii.) is naturally prior to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the said external body.  Wherefore an adequate knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body is not in God, in so far as he has the idea of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification of the human body; in other words, the idea of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification of the human body does not involve an adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of the external body.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVI.  The human mind does not perceive any external body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as actually existing, except through the ideas of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of its own body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If the human body is in no way affected by a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body, then  (II. vii.) neither is the idea of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, in other words, the human mind, affected in any way by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the existence of the said external body, nor does it in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any manner perceive its existence.  But, in so far as the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body is affected in any way by a given external body, thus far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xvi. and Coroll.) it perceives that external body.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--In so far as the human mind imagines an external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, it has not an adequate knowledge thereof.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--When the human mind regards external bodies through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the ideas of the modifications of its own body, we say that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagines (see II. xvii. note); now the mind can only imagine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external bodies as actually existing.  Therefore (by II. xxv.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as the mind imagines external bodies, it has not an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate knowledge of them.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVII.  The idea of each modification of the human body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not involve an adequate knowledge of the human body itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Every idea of a modification of the human body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves the nature of the human body, in so far as the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body is regarded as affected in a given manner (II. xvi.).  But,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as the human body is an individual which may be affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in many other ways, the idea of the said modification, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVIII.  The ideas of the modifications of the human body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as they have reference only to the human mind, are not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clear and distinct, but confused.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The ideas of the modifications of the human body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involve the nature both of the human body and of external bodies
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xvi.); they must involve the nature not only of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body but also of its parts; for the modifications are modes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Post. iii.), whereby the parts of the human body, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, the human body as a whole are affected.   But (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. xxiv., xxv.) the adequate knowledge of external bodies, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also of the parts composing the human body, is not in God, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he is regarded as affected by the human mind, but in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he is regarded as affected by other ideas.  These ideas of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications, in so far as they are referred to the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alone, are as consequences without premisses, in other words,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confused ideas.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The idea which constitutes the nature of the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, in the same manner, proved not to be, when considered in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself alone, clear and distinct; as also is the case with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the human mind, and the ideas of the ideas of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of the human body, in so far as they are referred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the mind only, as everyone may easily see.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIX.  The idea of the idea of each modification of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body does not involve an adequate knowledge of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The idea of a modification of the human body (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxvii.) does not involve an adequate knowledge of the said body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in other words, does not adequately express its nature; that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xiii.) it does not agree with the nature of the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequately; therefore (I. Ax. vi) the idea of this idea does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequately express the nature of the human mind, or does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involve an adequate knowledge thereof.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that the human mind, when it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceives things after the common order of nature, has not an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate but only a confused and fragmentary knowledge of itself,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its own body, and of external bodies.  For the mind does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: know itself, except in so far as it perceives the ideas of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of body (II. xxiii.).  It only perceives its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body (II. xix.) through the ideas of the modifications, and only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceives external bodies through the same means; thus, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it has such ideas of modification, it has not an adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of itself (II. xxix.), nor of its own body (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxvii.), nor of external bodies (II. xxv.), but only a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fragmentary and confused knowledge thereof (II. xxviii. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--I say expressly, that the mind has not an adequate but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only a confused knowledge of itself, its own body, and of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external bodies, whenever it perceives things after the common
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of nature; that is, whenever it is determined from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without, namely, by the fortuitous play of circumstance, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard this or that; not at such times as it is determined from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: within, that is, by the fact of regarding several things at once,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to understand their points of agreement, difference, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrast.  Whenever it is determined in anywise from within, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regards things clearly and distinctly, as I will show below.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXX.  We can only have a very inadequate knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: duration of our body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The duration of our body does not depend on its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence (II. Ax. i.), nor on the absolute nature of God (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxi.).  But (I. xxviii.) it is conditioned to exist and operate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by causes, which in their turn are conditioned to exist and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: operate in a fixed and definite relation by other causes, these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last again being conditioned by others, and so on to infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The duration of our body therefore depends on the common order of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, or the constitution of things.  Now, however a thing may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be constituted, the adequate knowledge of that thing is in God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he has the ideas of all things, and not in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he has the idea of the human body only.  (II. ix. Coroll.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore the knowledge of the duration of our body is in God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very inadequate, in so far as he is only regarded as constituting
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of the human mind; that is (II. xi. Coroll.), this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge is very inadequate to our mind.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXI.  We can only have a very inadequate knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: duration of particular things external to ourselves.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Every particular thing, like the human body, must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditioned by another particular thing to exist and operate in a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fixed and definite relation; this other particular thing must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: likewise be conditioned by a third, and so on to infinity.  (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxviii.)  As we have shown in the foregoing proposition, from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this common property of particular things, we have only a very
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate knowledge of the duration of our body; we must draw a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similar conclusion with regard to the duration of particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, namely, that we can only have a very inadequate knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the duration thereof.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that all particular things are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent and perishable.  For we can have no adequate idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their duration (by the last Prop.), and this is what we must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand by the contingency and perishableness of things.  (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxiii., Note i.)  For (I. xxix.), except in this sense, nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is contingent.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXII.  All ideas, in so far as they are referred to God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are true.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All ideas which are in God agree in every respect with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their objects (II. vii. Coroll.), therefore (I. Ax. vi.) they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all true.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIII.  There is nothing positive in ideas, which causes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them to be called false.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If this be denied, conceive, if possible, a positive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mode of thinking, which should constitute the distinctive quality
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of falsehood.  Such a mode of thinking cannot be in God (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxii.); external to God it cannot be or be conceived (I. xv.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore there is nothing positive in ideas which causes them to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be called false.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIV.  Every idea, which in us is absolute or adequate and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect, is true.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--When we say that an idea in us is adequate and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect, we say, in other words (II. xi. Coroll.), that the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is adequate and perfect in God, in so far as he constitutes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of our mind; consequently (II. xxxii.), we say that such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an idea is true.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXV.  Falsity consists in the privation of knowledge,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which inadequate, fragmentary, or confused ideas involve.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--There is nothing positive in ideas, which causes them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be called false (II. xxxiii.); but falsity cannot consist in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simple privation (for minds, not bodies, are said to err and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be mistaken), neither can it consist in absolute ignorance, for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorance and error are not identical; wherefore it consists in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the privation of knowledge, which inadequate, fragmentary, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confused ideas involve.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--In the note to II. xvii. I explained how error consists
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the privation of knowledge, but in order to throw more light
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the subject I will give an example.  For instance, men are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mistaken in thinking themselves free; their opinion is made up
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of consciousness of their own actions, and ignorance of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes by which they are conditioned.  Their idea of freedom,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, is simply their ignorance of any cause for their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions.  As for their saying that human actions depend on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will, this is a mere phrase without any idea to correspond
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereto.  What the will is, and how it moves the body, they none
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of them know; those who boast of such knowledge, and feign
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dwellings and habitations for the soul, are wont to provoke
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either laughter or disgust.  So, again, when we look at the sun,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we imagine that it is distant from us about two hundred feet;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this error does not lie solely in this fancy, but in the fact
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that, while we thus imagine, we do not know the sun's true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distance or the cause of the fancy.  For although we afterwards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: learn, that the sun is distant from us more than six hundred of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the earth's diameters, we none the less shall fancy it to be near;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for we do not imagine the sun as near us, because we are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorant of its true distance, but because the modification of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our body involves the essence of the sun, in so far as our said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body is affected thereby.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVI.  Inadequate and confused ideas follow by the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity, as adequate or clear and distinct ideas.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All ideas are in God (I. xv.), and in so far as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are referred to God are true (II. xxxii.) and (II. vii. Coroll.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate; therefore there are no ideas confused or inadequate,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except in respect to a particular mind (cf. II. xxiv. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxviii.); therefore all ideas, whether adequate or inadequate,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow by the same necessity (II. vi.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVII.  That which is common to all (cf. Lemma II.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above), and which is equally in a part and in the whole, does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitute the essence of any particular thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If this be denied, conceive, if possible, that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitutes the essence of some particular thing; for instance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of B.  Then (II. Def. ii.) it cannot without B either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exist or be conceived; but this is against our hypothesis.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore it does not appertain to B's essence, nor does it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitute the essence of any particular thing.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVIII.  Those things, which are common to all, and which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are equally in a part and in the whole, cannot be conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except adequately.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Let A be something, which is common to all bodies, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is equally present in the part of any given body and in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole.  I say A cannot be conceived except adequately.  For the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea thereof in God will necessarily be adequate (II. vii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), both in so far as God has the idea of the human body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and also in so far as he has the idea of the modifications of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body, which (II. xvi., xxv., xxvii.) involve in part the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of the human body and the nature of external bodies; that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (II. xii., xiii.), the idea in God will necessarily be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate, both in so far as he constitutes the human mind, and in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as he has the ideas, which are in the human mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore the mind (II. xi. Coroll.) necessarily perceives A
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequately, and has this adequate perception, both in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it perceives itself, and in so far as it perceives its own or any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body, nor can A be conceived in any other manner.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary--Hence it follows that there are certain ideas or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notions common to all men; for (by Lemma ii.) all bodies agree
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in certain respects, which (by the foregoing Prop.) must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequately or clearly and distinctly perceived by all.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIX.  That, which is common to and a property of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body and such other bodies as are wont to affect the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, and which is present equally in each part of either, or in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the whole, will be represented by an adequate idea in the mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If A be that, which is common to and a property of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body and external bodies, and equally present in the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body and in the said external bodies, in each part of each
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body and in the whole, there will be an adequate idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: A in God (II. vii. Coroll.), both in so far as he has the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human body, and in so far as he has the ideas of the given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external bodies.  Let it now be granted, that the human body is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by an external body through that, which it has in common
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therewith, namely, A; the idea of this modification will involve
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the property A (II. xvi.), and therefore (II. vii. Coroll.) the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of this modification, in so far as it involves the property
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: A, will be adequate in God, in so far as God is affected by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the human body; that is (II. xiii.), in so far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitutes the nature of the human mind; therefore (II. xi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.) this idea is also adequate in the human mind.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that the mind is fitted to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceive adequately more things, in proportion as its body has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more in common with other bodies.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XL.  Whatsoever ideas in the mind follow from ideas which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are therein adequate, are also themselves adequate.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is self--evident.  For when we say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that an idea in the human mind follows from ideas which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein adequate, we say, in other words (II. xi. Coroll.), that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an idea is in the divine intellect, whereof God is the cause, not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he is infinite, nor in so far as he is affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the ideas of very many particular things, but only in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he constitutes the essence of the human mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note I.--I have thus set forth the cause of those notions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are common to all men, and which form the basis of our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ratiocination.  But there are other causes of certain axioms or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notions, which it would be to the purpose to set forth by this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: method of ours; for it would thus appear what notions are more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useful than others, and what notions have scarcely any use at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all.  Furthermore, we should see what notions are common to all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men, and what notions are only clear and distinct to those who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are unshackled by prejudice, and we should detect those which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ill--founded.  Again we should discern whence the notions called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secondary derived their origin, and consequently the axioms on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they are founded, and other points of interest connected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with these questions.  But I have decided to pass over the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject here, partly because I have set it aside for another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treatise, partly because I am afraid of wearying the reader by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: too great prolixity.  Nevertheless, in order not to omit anything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary to be known, I will briefly set down the causes, whence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are derived the terms styled transcendental, such as Being,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thing, Something.  These terms arose from the fact, that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body, being limited, is only capable of distinctly forming
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a certain number of images (what an image is I explained in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. xvii. note) within itself at the same time; if this number
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be exceeded, the images will begin to be confused; if this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of images, of which the body is capable of forming
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly within itself, be largely exceeded, all will become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entirely confused one with another.  This being so, it is evident
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (from II. Prop. xvii. Coroll., and xviii.) that the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can distinctly imagine as many things simultaneously, as its body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can form images simultaneously.  When the images become quite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confused in the body, the mind also imagines all bodies
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confusedly without any distinction, and will comprehend them, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it were, under one attribute, namely, under the attribute of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Being, Thing, &c.  The same conclusion can be drawn from the fact
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that images are not always equally vivid, and from other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: analogous causes, which there is no need to explain here; for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the purpose which we have in view it is sufficient for us to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consider one only.  All may be reduced to this, that these terms
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: represent ideas in the highest degree confused.  From similar
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes arise those notions, which we call general, such as man,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: horse, dog, &c.  They arise, to wit, from the fact that so many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: images, for instance, of men, are formed simultaneously in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human mind, that the powers of imagination break down, not indeed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: utterly, but to the extent of the mind losing count of small
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differences between individuals (e.g. colour, size, &c.) and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their definite number, and only distinctly imagining that, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which all the individuals, in so far as the body is affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them, agree; for that is the point, in which each of the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals chiefly affected the body; this the mind expresses
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the name man, and this it predicates of an infinite number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular individuals.  For, as we have said, it is unable to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagine the definite number of individuals.  We must, however,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bear in mind, that these general notions are not formed by all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men in the same way, but vary in each individual according as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point varies, whereby the body has been most often affected and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which the mind most easily imagines or remembers.  For instance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who have most often regarded with admiration the stature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, will by the name of man understand an animal of erect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stature; those who have been accustomed to regard some other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute, will form a different general image of man, for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, that man is a laughing animal, a two--footed animal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without feathers, a rational animal, and thus, in other cases,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone will form general images of things according to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: habit of his body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is thus not to be wondered at, that among philosophers,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who seek to explain things in nature merely by the images formed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of them, so many controversies should have arisen.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note II.--From all that has been said above it is clear, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we, in many cases, perceive and form our general notions:--(1.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: From particular things represented to our intellect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fragmentarily, confusedly, and without order through our senses
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xxix. Coroll.); I have settled to call such perceptions by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the name of knowledge from the mere suggestions of experience.[4]
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [4] A Baconian phrase.  Nov. Org. Aph. 100.  [Pollock, p. 126, n.]
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (2.) From symbols, e.g., from the fact of having read or heard
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain words we remember things and form certain ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning them, similar to those through which we imagine things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xviii. note).  I shall call both these ways of regarding
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things knowledge of the first kind, opinion, or imagination.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (3.) From the fact that we have notions common to all men, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas of the properties of things (II. xxxviii. Coroll.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxix. and Coroll. and xl.); this I call reason and knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the second kind.  Besides these two kinds of knowledge, there is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as I will hereafter show, a third kind of knowledge, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will call intuition.  This kind of knowledge proceeds from an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate idea of the absolute essence of certain attributes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God to the adequate knowledge of the essence of things.  I will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: illustrate all three kinds of knowledge by a single example.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Three numbers are given for finding a fourth, which shall be to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the third as the second is to the first.  Tradesmen without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hesitation multiply the second by the third, and divide the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: product by the first; either because they have not forgotten the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rule which they received from a master without any proof, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because they have often made trial of it with simple numbers, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by virtue of the proof of the nineteenth proposition of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seventh book of Euclid, namely, in virtue of the general property
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of proportionals.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But with very simple numbers there is no need of this.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, one, two, three, being given, everyone can see that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fourth proportional is six; and this is much clearer, because we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infer the fourth number from an intuitive grasping of the ratio,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which the first bears to the second.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLI.  Knowledge of the first kind is the only source of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: falsity, knowledge of the second and third kinds is necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--To knowledge of the first kind we have (in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foregoing note) assigned all those ideas, which are inadequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and confused; therefore this kind of knowledge is the only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: source of falsity (II. xxxv.).  Furthermore, we assigned to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: second and third kinds of knowledge those ideas which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate; therefore these kinds are necessarily true (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxiv.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLII.  Knowledge of the second and third kinds, not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of the first kind, teaches us to distinguish the true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the false.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is self--evident.  He, who knows how
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to distinguish between true and false, must have an adequate idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of true and false.  That is (II. xl., note ii.), he must know the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true and the false by the second or third kind of knowledge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIII.  He, who has a true idea, simultaneously knows that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he has a true idea, and cannot doubt of the truth of the thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A true idea in us is an idea which is adequate in God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as he is displayed through the nature of the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xi. Coroll.).  Let us suppose that there is in God, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he is displayed through the human mind, an adequate idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: A.  The idea of this idea must also necessarily be in God, and be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to him in the same way as the idea A (by II. xx.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof the proof is of universal application).  But the idea A
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is supposed to be referred to God, in so far as he is displayed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through the human mind; therefore, the idea of the idea A must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be referred to God in the same manner; that is (by II. xi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), the adequate idea of the idea A will be in the mind,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which has the adequate idea A; therefore he, who has an adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea or knows a thing truly (II. xxxiv.), must at the same time
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have an adequate idea or true knowledge of his knowledge; that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, obviously, he must be assured.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--I explained in the note to II. xxi. what is meant by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of an idea; but we may remark that the foregoing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition is in itself sufficiently plain.  No one, who has a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true idea, is ignorant that a true idea involves the highest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainty.  For to have a true idea is only another expression
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for knowing a thing perfectly, or as well as possible.  No one,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indeed, can doubt of this, unless he thinks that an idea is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something lifeless, like a picture on a panel, and not a mode of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking--namely, the very act of understanding.  And who, I ask,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can know that he understands anything, unless he do first
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand it?  In other words, who can know that he is sure of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, unless he be first sure of that thing?  Further, what can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there be more clear, and more certain, than a true idea as a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: standard of truth?  Even as light displays both itself and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: darkness, so is truth a standard both of itself and of falsity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I think I have thus sufficiently answered these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: questions--namely, if a true idea is distinguished from a false
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea, only in so far as it is said to agree with its object, a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true idea has no more reality or perfection than a false idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (since the two are only distinguished by an extrinsic mark);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, neither will a man who has a true idea have any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantage over him who has only false ideas.  Further, how comes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it that men have false ideas?  Lastly, how can anyone be sure,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he has ideas which agree with their objects?  These
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: questions, I repeat, I have, in my opinion, sufficiently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answered.  The difference between a true idea and a false idea is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plain: from what was said in II. xxxv., the former is related to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the latter as being is to not--being.  The causes of falsity I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have set forth very clearly in II. xix. and II. xxxv. with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note.  From what is there stated, the difference between a man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who has true ideas, and a man who has only false ideas, is made
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: apparent.  As for the last question--as to how a man can be sure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he has ideas that agree with their objects, I have just
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pointed out, with abundant clearness, that his knowledge arises
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the simple fact, that he has an idea which corresponds with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its object--in other words, that truth is its own standard.  We
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may add that our mind, in so far as it perceives things truly, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part of the infinite intellect of God (II. xi. Coroll.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, the clear and distinct ideas of the mind are as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily true as the ideas of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIV.  It is not in the nature of reason to regard things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as contingent, but as necessary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--It is in the nature of reason to perceive things truly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xli.), namely (I. Ax. vi.), as they are in themselves--that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (I. xxix.), not as contingent, but as necessary.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--Hence it follows, that it is only through our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination that we consider things, whether in respect to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future or the past, as contingent.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--How this way of looking at things arises, I will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: briefly explain.  We have shown above (II. xvii. and Coroll.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the mind always regards things as present to itself, even
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though they be not in existence, until some causes arise which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exclude their existence and presence.  Further (II. xviii.), we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: showed that, if the human body has once been affected by two
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external bodies simultaneously, the mind, when it afterwards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagines one of the said external bodies, will straightway
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remember the other--that is, it will regard both as present to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, unless there arise causes which exclude their existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and presence.  Further, no one doubts that we imagine time, from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fact that we imagine bodies to be moved some more slowly than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others, some more quickly, some at equal speed.  Thus, let us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suppose that a child yesterday saw Peter for the first time in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the morning, Paul at noon, and Simon in the evening; then, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: today he again sees Peter in the morning.  It is evident, from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. Prop. xviii., that, as soon as he sees the morning light, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will imagine that the sun will traverse the same parts of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sky, as it did when he saw it on the preceding day; in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, he will imagine a complete day, and, together with his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination of the morning, he will imagine Peter; with noon, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will imagine Paul; and with evening, he will imagine Simon--that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, he will imagine the existence of Paul and Simon in relation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to a future time; on the other hand, if he sees Simon in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evening, he will refer Peter and Paul to a past time, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagining them simultaneously with the imagination of a past
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time.  If it should at any time happen, that on some other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evening the child should see James instead of Simon, he will, on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the following morning, associate with his imagination of evening
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sometimes Simon, sometimes James, not both together: for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: child is supposed to have seen, at evening, one or other of them,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not both together.  His imagination will therefore waver; and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the imagination of future evenings, he will associate first
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one, then the other--that is, he will imagine them in the future,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither of them as certain, but both as contingent.  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wavering of the imagination will be the same, if the imagination
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be concerned with things which we thus contemplate, standing in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: relation to time past or time present: consequently, we may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagine things as contingent, whether they be referred to time
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present, past, or future.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--It is in the nature of reason to perceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things under a certain form of eternity (sub quadam aeternitatis
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: specie).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--It is in the nature of reason to regard things, not as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent, but as necessary (II. xliv.).  Reason perceives this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of things (II. xli.) truly--that is (I. Ax. vi.), as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in itself.  But (I. xvi.) this necessity of things is the very
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of the eternal nature of God; therefore, it is in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of reason to regard things under this form of eternity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We may add that the bases of reason are the notions (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxviii.), which answer to things common to all, and which (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvii.) do not answer to the essence of any particular thing:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which must therefore be conceived without any relation to time,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under a certain form of eternity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLV.  Every idea of every body, or of every particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing actually existing, necessarily involves the eternal and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite essence of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The idea of a particular thing actually existing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily involves both the existence and the essence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said thing (II. viii.).  Now particular things cannot be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived without God (I. xv.); but, inasmuch as (II. vi.) they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have God for their cause, in so far as he is regarded under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute of which the things in question are modes, their ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must necessarily involve (I. Ax. iv.) the conception of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes of those ideas--that is (I. vi.), the eternal and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite essence of God.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--By existence I do not here mean duration--that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence in so far as it is conceived abstractedly, and as a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain form of quantity.  I am speaking of the very nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence, which is assigned to particular things, because they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow in infinite numbers and in infinite ways from the eternal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of God's nature (I. xvi.).  I am speaking, I repeat, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the very existence of particular things, in so far as they are in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God.  For although each particular thing be conditioned by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another particular thing to exist in a given way, yet the force
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby each particular thing perseveres in existing follows from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the eternal necessity of God's nature (cf. I. xxiv. Coroll.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVI.  The knowledge of the eternal and infinite essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God which every idea involves is adequate and perfect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The proof of the last proposition is universal; and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether a thing be considered as a part or a whole, the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereof, whether of the whole or of a part (by the last Prop.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will involve God's eternal and infinite essence.  Wherefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that, which gives knowledge of the eternal and infinite essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, is common to all, and is equally in the part and in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole; therefore (II. xxxviii.) this knowledge will be adequate.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVII.  The human mind has an adequate knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal and infinite essence of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The human mind has ideas (II. xxii.), from which (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiii.) it perceives itself and its own body (II. xix.) and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external bodies (II. xvi. Coroll. i. and II. xvii.) as actually
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing; therefore (II. xlv. and xlvi.) it has an adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of the eternal and infinite essence of God.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Hence we see, that the infinite essence and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity of God are known to all.  Now as all things are in God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and are conceived through God, we can from this knowledge infer
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many things, which we may adequately know, and we may form that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: third kind of knowledge of which we spoke in the note to II. xl.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and of the excellence and use of which we shall have occasion to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speak in Part V.  Men have not so clear a knowledge of God as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have of general notions, because they are unable to imagine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God as they do bodies, and also because they have associated the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: name God with images of things that they are in the habit of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seeing, as indeed they can hardly avoid doing, being, as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are, men, and continually affected by external bodies.  Many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: errors, in truth, can be traced to this head, namely, that we do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not apply names to things rightly.  For instance, when a man says
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the lines drawn from the centre of a circle to its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumference are not equal, he then, at all events, assuredly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attaches a meaning to the word circle different from that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assigned by mathematicians.  So again, when men make mistakes in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: calculation, they have one set of figures in their mind, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another on the paper.  If we could see into their minds, they do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not make a mistake; they seem to do so, because we think, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have the same numbers in their mind as they have on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: paper.  If this were not so, we should not believe them to be in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: error, any more than I thought that a man was in error, whom I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lately heard exclaiming that his entrance hall had flown into a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neighbour's hen, for his meaning seemed to me sufficiently clear.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Very many controversies have arisen from the fact, that men do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not rightly explain their meaning, or do not rightly interpret
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the meaning of others.  For, as a matter of fact, as they flatly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contradict themselves, they assume now one side, now another, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the argument, so as to oppose the opinions, which they consider
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mistaken and absurd in their opponents.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVIII.  In the mind there is no absolute or free will;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but the mind is determined to wish this or that by a cause, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has also been determined by another cause, and this last by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another cause, and so on to infinity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind is a fixed and definite mode of thought (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xi.), therefore it cannot be the free cause of its actions (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii. Coroll. ii.); in other words, it cannot have an absolute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faculty of positive or negative volition; but (by I. xxviii.) it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must be determined by a cause, which has also been determined by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another cause, and this last by another, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--In the same way it is proved, that there is in the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no absolute faculty of understanding, desiring, loving, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whence it follows, that these and similar faculties are either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entirely fictitious, or are merely abstract and general terms,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such as we are accustomed to put together from particular things.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus the intellect and the will stand in the same relation to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this or that idea, or this or that volition, as "lapidity" to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this or that stone, or as "man" to Peter and Paul.  The cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which leads men to consider themselves free has been set forth in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Appendix to Part I.  But, before I proceed further, I would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: here remark that, by the will to affirm and decide, I mean the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faculty, not the desire.  I mean, I repeat, the faculty, whereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind affirms or denies what is true or false, not the desire,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherewith the mind wishes for or turns away from any given thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: After we have proved, that these faculties of ours are general
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notions, which cannot be distinguished from the particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instances on which they are based, we must inquire whether
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: volitions themselves are anything besides the ideas of things.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We must inquire, I say, whether there is in the mind any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirmation or negation beyond that, which the idea, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is an idea, involves.  On which subject see the following
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition, and II. Def. iii., lest the idea of pictures should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suggest itself.  For by ideas I do not mean images such as are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: formed at the back of the eye, or in the midst of the brain, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the conceptions of thought.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIX.  There is in the mind no volition or affirmation and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negation, save that which an idea, inasmuch as it is an idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--There is in the mind no absolute faculty of positive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or negative volition, but only particular volitions, namely, this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or that affirmation, and this or that negation.  Now let us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive a particular volition, namely, the mode of thinking
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby the mind affirms, that the three interior angles of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: triangle are equal to two right angles.  This affirmation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves the conception or idea of a triangle, that is, without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of a triangle it cannot be conceived.  It is the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing to say, that the concept A must involve the concept B, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is to say, that A cannot be conceived without B.  Further,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this affirmation cannot be made (II. Ax. iii.) without the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a triangle.  Therefore, this affirmation can neither be nor be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived, without the idea of a triangle.  Again, this idea of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: triangle must involve this same affirmation, namely, that its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: three interior angles are equal to two right angles.  Wherefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and vice versa, this idea of a triangle can neither be nor be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived without this affirmation, therefore, this affirmation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belongs to the essence of the idea of a triangle, and is nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: besides.  What we have said of this volition (inasmuch as we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: selected it at random) may be said of any other volition, namely,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it is nothing but an idea.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Will and understanding are one and the same.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Will and understanding are nothing beyond the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual volitions and ideas (II. xlviii. and note).  But a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular volition and a particular idea are one and the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the foregoing Prop.); therefore, will and understanding are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one and the same.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We have thus removed the cause which is commonly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assigned for error.  For we have shown above, that falsity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consists solely in the privation of knowledge involved in ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are fragmentary and confused.  Wherefore, a false idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as it is false, does not involve certainty.  When we
title: Ethics
