author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say, then, that a man acquiesces in what is false, and that he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has no doubts on the subject, we do not say that he is certain,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but only that he does not doubt, or that he acquiesces in what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: false, inasmuch as there are no reasons, which should cause his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination to waver (see II. xliv. note).  Thus, although the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man be assumed to acquiesce in what is false, we shall never say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he is certain.  For by certainty we mean something positive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xliii. and note), not merely the absence of doubt.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, in order that the foregoing proposition may be fully
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explained, I will draw attention to a few additional points, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I will furthermore answer the objections which may be advanced
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against our doctrine.  Lastly, in order to remove every scruple,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have thought it worth while to point out some of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantages, which follow therefrom.  I say "some," for they will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be better appreciated from what we shall set forth in the fifth
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I begin, then, with the first point, and warn my readers to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: make an accurate distinction between an idea, or conception of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, and the images of things which we imagine.  It is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further necessary that they should distinguish between idea and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, whereby we signify things.  These three--namely, images,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, and ideas--are by many persons either entirely confused
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: together, or not distinguished with sufficient accuracy or care,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and hence people are generally in ignorance, how absolutely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary is a knowledge of this doctrine of the will, both for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: philosophic purposes and for the wise ordering of life.  Those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who think that ideas consist in images which are formed in us by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contact with external bodies, persuade themselves that the ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of those things, whereof we can form no mental picture, are not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas, but only figments, which we invent by the free decree of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our will; they thus regard ideas as though they were inanimate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pictures on a panel, and, filled with this misconception, do not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: see that an idea, inasmuch as it is an idea, involves an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirmation or negation.  Again, those who confuse words with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas, or with the affirmation which an idea involves, think that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they can wish something contrary to what they feel, affirm, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deny.  This misconception will easily be laid aside by one, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reflects on the nature of knowledge, and seeing that it in no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wise involves the conception of extension, will therefore clearly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand, that an idea (being a mode of thinking) does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consist in the image of anything, nor in words.  The essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words and images is put together by bodily motions, which in no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wise involve the conception of thought.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: These few words on this subject will suffice: I will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore pass on to consider the objections, which may be raised
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against our doctrine.  Of these, the first is advanced by those,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who think that the will has a wider scope than the understanding,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that therefore it is different therefrom.  The reason for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their holding the belief, that the will has wider scope than the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, is that they assert, that they have no need of an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increase in their faculty of assent, that is of affirmation or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negation, in order to assent to an infinity of things which we do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not perceive, but that they have need of an increase in their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faculty of understanding.  The will is thus distinguished from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the intellect, the latter being finite and the former infinite.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Secondly, it may be objected that experience seems to teach us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially clearly, that we are able to suspend our judgment
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before assenting to things which we perceive; this is confirmed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the fact that no one is said to be deceived, in so far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceives anything, but only in so far as he assents or dissents.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For instance, he who feigns a winged horse, does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore admit that a winged horse exists; that is, he is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deceived, unless he admits in addition that a winged horse does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exist.  Nothing therefore seems to be taught more clearly by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience, than that the will or faculty of assent is free and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from the faculty of understanding.  Thirdly, it may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objected that one affirmation does not apparently contain more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality than another; in other words, that we do not seem to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need for affirming, that what is true is true, any greater power
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than for affirming, that what is false is true.  We have,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: however, seen that one idea has more reality or perfection than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, for as objects are some more excellent than others, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also are the ideas of them some more excellent than others; this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also seems to point to a difference between the understanding and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the will.  Fourthly, it may be objected, if man does not act from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free will, what will happen if the incentives to action are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally balanced, as in the case of Buridan's ass?  Will he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perish of hunger and thirst?  If I say that he would, I shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seem to have in my thoughts an ass or the statue of a man rather
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than an actual man.  If I say that he would not, he would then
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determine his own action, and would consequently possess the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faculty of going and doing whatever he liked.  Other objections
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: might also be raised, but, as I am not bound to put in evidence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything that anyone may dream, I will only set myself to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: task of refuting those I have mentioned, and that as briefly as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: To the first objection I answer, that I admit that the will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has a wider scope than the understanding, if by the understanding
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be meant only clear and distinct ideas; but I deny that the will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has a wider scope than the perceptions, and the faculty of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forming conceptions; nor do I see why the faculty of volition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be called infinite, any more than the faculty of feeling:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for, as we are able by the same faculty of volition to affirm an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of things (one after the other, for we cannot
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirm an infinite number simultaneously), so also can we, by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same faculty of feeling, feel or perceive (in succession) an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of bodies.  If it be said that there is an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of things which we cannot perceive, I answer,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we cannot attain to such things by any thinking, nor,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, by any faculty of volition.  But, it may still be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: urged, if God wished to bring it about that we should perceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them, he would be obliged to endow us with a greater faculty of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception, but not a greater faculty of volition than we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: already.  This is the same as to say that, if God wished to bring
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it about that we should understand an infinite number of other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entities, it would be necessary for him to give us a greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, but not a more universal idea of entity than that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we have already, in order to grasp such infinite entities.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We have shown that will is a universal entity or idea, whereby we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain all particular volitions--in other words, that which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all such volitions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As, then, our opponents maintain that this idea, common or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universal to all volitions, is a faculty, it is little to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wondered at that they assert, that such a faculty extends itself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into the infinite, beyond the limits of the understanding: for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is universal is predicated alike of one, of many, and of an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of individuals.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: To the second objection I reply by denying, that we have a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free power of suspending our judgment: for, when we say that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone suspends his judgment, we merely mean that he sees, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he does not perceive the matter in question adequately.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Suspension of judgment is, therefore, strictly speaking, a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception, and not free will.  In order to illustrate the point,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: let us suppose a boy imagining a horse, and perceive nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else.  Inasmuch as this imagination involves the existence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: horse (II. xvii. Coroll.), and the boy does not perceive anything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which would exclude the existence of the horse, he will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily regard the horse as present: he will not be able to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt of its existence, although he be not certain thereof.  We
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have daily experience of such a state of things in dreams; and I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do not suppose that there is anyone, who would maintain that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: while he is dreaming, he has the free power of suspending his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judgment concerning the things in his dream, and bringing it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about that he should not dream those things, which he dreams that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he sees; yet it happens, notwithstanding, that even in dreams we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suspend our judgment, namely, when we dream that we are dreaming.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, I grant that no one can be deceived, so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual perception extends--that is, I grant that the mind's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imaginations, regarded in themselves, do not involve error (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii. note); but I deny, that a man does not, in the act of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception, make any affirmation.  For what is the perception of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a winged horse, save affirming that a horse has wings?  If the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind could perceive nothing else but the winged horse, it would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard the same as present to itself: it would have no reasons
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for doubting its existence, nor any faculty of dissent, unless
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the imagination of a winged horse be joined to an idea which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: precludes the existence of the said horse, or unless the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceives that the idea which it possess of a winged horse is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate, in which case it will either necessarily deny the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of such a horse, or will necessarily be in doubt on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I think that I have anticipated my answer to the third
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objection, namely, that the will is something universal which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: predicated of all ideas, and that it only signifies that which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all ideas, namely, an affirmation, whose adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence must, therefore, in so far as it is thus conceived in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abstract, be in every idea, and be, in this respect alone, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same in all, not in so far as it is considered as constituting
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea's essence: for, in this respect, particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirmations differ one from the other, as much as do ideas.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, the affirmation which involves the idea of a circle,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differs from that which involves the idea of a triangle, as much
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the idea of a circle differs from the idea of a triangle.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, I absolutely deny, that we are in need of an equal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of thinking, to affirm that that which is true is true, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to affirm that that which is false is true.  These two
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirmations, if we regard the mind, are in the same relation to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one another as being and not--being; for there is nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positive in ideas, which constitutes the actual reality of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: falsehood (II. xxxv. note, and xlvii. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We must therefore conclude, that we are easily deceived, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we confuse universals with singulars, and the entities of reason
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and abstractions with realities.  As for the fourth objection, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: am quite ready to admit, that a man placed in the equilibrium
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: described  (namely, as perceiving nothing but hunger and thirst,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a certain food and a certain drink, each equally distant from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him) would die of hunger and thirst.  If I am asked, whether such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an one should not rather be considered an ass than a man; I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answer, that I do not know, neither do I know how a man should be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considered, who hangs himself, or how we should consider
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: children, fools, madmen, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It remains to point out the advantages of a knowledge of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine as bearing on conduct, and this may be easily gathered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from what has been said.  The doctrine is good,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 1. Inasmuch as it teaches us to act solely according to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decree of God, and to be partakers in the Divine nature, and so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much the more, as we perform more perfect actions and more and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more understand God.  Such a doctrine not only completely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tranquilizes our spirit, but also shows us where our highest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happiness or blessedness is, namely, solely in the knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, whereby we are led to act only as love and piety shall bid
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us.  We may thus clearly understand, how far astray from a true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: estimate of virtue are those who expect to be decorated by God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with high rewards for their virtue, and their best actions, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for having endured the direst slavery; as if virtue and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: service of God were not in itself happiness and perfect freedom.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 2. Inasmuch as it teaches us, how we ought to conduct
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves with respect to the gifts of fortune, or matters which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are not in our power, and do not follow from our nature.  For it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shows us, that we should await and endure fortune's smiles or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: frowns with an equal mind, seeing that all things follow from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal decree of God by the same necessity, as it follows from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of a triangle, that the three angles are equal to two
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right angles.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 3. This doctrine raises social life, inasmuch as it teaches
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us to hate no man, neither to despise, to deride, to envy, or to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be angry with any.  Further, as it tells us that each should be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: content with his own, and helpful to his neighbour, not from any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: womanish pity, favour, or superstition, but solely by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guidance of reason, according as the time and occasion demand, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I will show in Part III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 4. Lastly, this doctrine confers no small advantage on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commonwealth; for it teaches how citizens should be governed and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: led, not so as to become slaves, but so that they may freely do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever things are best.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have thus fulfilled the promise made at the beginning of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this note, and I thus bring the second part of my treatise to a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: close.  I think I have therein explained the nature and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: properties of the human mind at sufficient length, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considering the difficulty of the subject, with sufficient
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearness.  I have laid a foundation, whereon may be raised many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excellent conclusions of the highest utility and most necessary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be known, as will, in what follows, be partly made plain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PART III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ON THE ORIGIN AND NATURE OF THE EMOTIONS
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Most writers on the emotions and on human conduct seem to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treating rather of matters outside nature than of natural
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phenomena following nature's general laws.  They appear to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive man to be situated in nature as a kingdom within a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kingdom: for they believe that he disturbs rather than follows
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature's order, that he has absolute control over his actions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that he is determined solely by himself.  They attribute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human infirmities and fickleness, not to the power of nature in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general, but to some mysterious flaw in the nature of man, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordingly they bemoan, deride, despise, or, as usually happens,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abuse: he, who succeeds in hitting off the weakness of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind more eloquently or more acutely than his fellows, is looked
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: upon as a seer.  Still there has been no lack of very excellent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men (to whose toil and industry I confess myself much indebted),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who have written many noteworthy things concerning the right way
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of life, and have given much sage advice to mankind.  But no one,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as I know, has defined the nature and strength of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, and the power of the mind against them for their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: restraint.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I do not forget, that the illustrious Descartes, though he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believed, that the mind has absolute power over its actions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strove to explain human emotions by their primary causes, and, at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same time, to point out a way, by which the mind might attain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to absolute dominion over them.  However, in my opinion, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accomplishes nothing beyond a display of the acuteness of his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great intellect, as I will show in the proper place.  For the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present I wish to revert to those, who would rather abuse or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deride human emotions than understand them.  Such persons will,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubtless think it strange that I should attempt to treat of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human vice and folly geometrically, and should wish to set forth
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with rigid reasoning those matters which they cry out against as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repugnant to reason, frivolous, absurd, and dreadful.  However,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such is my plan.  Nothing comes to pass in nature, which can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: set down to a flaw therein; for nature is always the same, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everywhere one and the same in her efficacy and power of action;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, nature's laws and ordinances, whereby all things come to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pass and change from one form to another, are everywhere and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always the same; so that there should be one and the same method
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of understanding the nature of all things whatsoever, namely,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through nature's universal laws and rules.  Thus the passions of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred, anger, envy, and so on, considered in themselves, follow
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from this same necessity and efficacy of nature; they answer to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain definite causes, through which they are understood, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess certain properties as worthy of being known as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: properties of anything else, whereof the contemplation in itself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affords us delight.  I shall, therefore, treat of the nature and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength of the emotions according to the same method, as I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: employed heretofore in my investigations concerning God and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind.  I shall consider human actions and desires in exactly the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same manner, as though I were concerned with lines, planes, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solids.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITIONS
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  By an adequate cause, I mean a cause through which its effect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be clearly and distinctly perceived.  By an inadequate or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: partial cause, I mean a cause through which, by itself, its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effect cannot be understood.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  I say that we act when anything takes place, either within
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us or externally to us, whereof we are the adequate cause; that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (by the foregoing definition) when through our nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something takes place within us or externally to us, which can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through our nature alone be clearly and distinctly understood.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: On the other hand, I say that we are passive as regards something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when that something takes place within us, or follows from our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature externally, we being only the partial cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  By emotion I mean the modifications of the body, whereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the active power of the said body is increased or diminished,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aided or constrained, and also the ideas of such modifications.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: N.B.  If we can be the adequate cause of any of these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications, I then call the emotion an activity, otherwise I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: call it a passion, or state wherein the mind is passive.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: POSTULATES
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  The human body can be affected in many ways, whereby its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of activity is increased or diminished, and also in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways which do not render its power of activity either greater or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: N.B.  This postulate or axiom rests on Postulate i. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lemmas v. and vii., which see after II. xiii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  The human body can undergo many changes, and, nevertheless,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retain the impressions or traces of objects (cf. II. Post. v.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, consequently, the same images of things (see note II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. I.  Our mind is in certain cases active, and in certain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cases passive.  In so far as it has adequate ideas it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily active, and in so far as it has inadequate ideas, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is necessarily passive.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In every human mind there are some adequate ideas, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some ideas that are fragmentary and confused (II. xl. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Those ideas which are adequate in the mind are adequate also in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, inasmuch as he constitutes the essence of the mind (II. xl.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), and those which are inadequate in the mind are likewise
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the same Coroll.) adequate in God, not inasmuch as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contains in himself the essence of the given mind alone, but as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he, at the same time, contains the minds of other things.  Again,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from any given idea some effect must necessarily follow (I. 36);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this effect God is the adequate cause (III. Def. i.), not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as he is infinite, but inasmuch as he is conceived as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by the given idea (II. ix.).  But of that effect whereof
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God is the cause, inasmuch as he is affected by an idea which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate in a given mind, of that effect, I repeat, the mind in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: question is the adequate cause (II. xi. Coroll.).  Therefore our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, in so far as it has adequate ideas (III. Def. ii.), is in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain cases necessarily active; this was our first point.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, whatsoever necessarily follows from the idea which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate in God, not by virtue of his possessing in himself the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind of one man only, but by virtue of his containing, together
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the mind of that one man, the minds of other things also, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such an effect (II. xi. Coroll.) the mind of the given man is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an adequate, but only a partial cause; thus (III. Def. ii.) the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, inasmuch as it has inadequate ideas, is in certain cases
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily passive; this was our second point.  Therefore our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that the mind is more or less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: liable to be acted upon, in proportion as it possesses inadequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas, and, contrariwise, is more or less active in proportion as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it possesses adequate ideas.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. II.  Body cannot determine mind to think, neither can mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determine body to motion or rest or any state different from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these, if such there be.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All modes of thinking have for their cause God, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue of his being a thinking thing, and not by virtue of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being displayed under any other attribute (II. vi.).  That,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, which determines the mind to thought is a mode of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought, and not a mode of extension; that is (II. Def. i.), it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not body.  This was our first point.  Again, the motion and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest of a body must arise from another body, which has also been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to a state of motion or rest by a third body, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely everything which takes place in a body must spring
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from God, in so far as he is regarded as affected by some mode of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extension, and not by some mode of thought (II. vi.); that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it cannot spring from the mind, which is a mode of thought.  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was our second point.  Therefore body cannot determine mind, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This is made more clear by what was said in the note to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. vii., namely, that mind and body are one and the same thing,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived first under the attribute of thought, secondly, under
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the attribute of extension.  Thus it follows that the order or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concatenation of things is identical, whether nature be conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the one attribute or the other; consequently the order of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states of activity and passivity in our body is simultaneous in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature with the order of states of activity and passivity in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind. The same conclusion is evident from the manner in which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proved II. xii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nevertheless, though such is the case, and though there be no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further room for doubt, I can scarcely believe, until the fact is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proved by experience, that men can be induced to consider the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: question calmly and fairly, so firmly are they convinced that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is merely at the bidding of the mind, that the body is set in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motion or at rest, or performs a variety of actions depending
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely on the mind's will or the exercise of thought.  However,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no one has hitherto laid down the limits to the powers of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, that is, no one has as yet been taught by experience what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body can accomplish solely by the laws of nature, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as she is regarded as extension.  No one hitherto has gained such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an accurate knowledge of the bodily mechanism, that he can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain all its functions; nor need I call attention to the fact
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that many actions are observed in the lower animals, which far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transcend human sagacity, and that somnambulists do many things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in their sleep, which they would not venture to do when awake:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these instances are enough to show, that the body can by the sole
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of its nature do many things which the mind wonders at.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, no one knows how or by what means the mind moves the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, nor how many various degrees of motion it can impart to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, nor how quickly it can move it.  Thus, when men say that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this or that physical action has its origin in the mind, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter has dominion over the body, they are using words without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meaning, or are confessing in specious phraseology that they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorant of the cause of the said action, and do not wonder at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, they will say, whether we know or do not know the means
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby the mind acts on the body, we have, at any rate,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience of the fact that unless the human mind is in a fit
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state to think, the body remains inert.  Moreover, we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience, that the mind alone can determine whether we speak or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are silent, and a variety of similar states which, accordingly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we say depend on the mind's decree.  But, as to the first point,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I ask such objectors, whether experience does not also teach,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that if the body be inactive the mind is simultaneously unfitted
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for thinking?  For when the body is at rest in sleep, the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneously is in a state of torpor also, and has no power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking, such as it possesses when the body is awake.  Again, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think everyone's experience will confirm the statement, that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind is not at all times equally fit for thinking on a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject, but according as the body is more or less fitted for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being stimulated by the image of this or that object, so also is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind more or less fitted for contemplating the said object.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, it will be urged, it is impossible that solely from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of nature considered as extended substance, we should be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: able to deduce the causes of buildings, pictures, and things of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that kind, which are produced only by human art; nor would the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body, unless it were determined and led by the mind, be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable of building a single temple.  However, I have just
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pointed out that the objectors cannot fix the limits of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body's power, or say what can be concluded from a consideration
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its sole nature, whereas they have experience of many things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being accomplished solely by the laws of nature, which they would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never have believed possible except under the direction of mind:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such are the actions performed by somnambulists while asleep, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wondered at by their performers when awake.  I would further call
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attention to the mechanism of the human body, which far surpasses
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in complexity all that has been put together by human art, not to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repeat what I have already shown, namely, that from nature, under
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatever attribute she be considered, infinite results follow.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As for the second objection, I submit that the world would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much happier, if men were as fully able to keep silence as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are to speak.  Experience abundantly shows that men can govern
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything more easily than their tongues, and restrain anything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more easily than their appetites; when it comes about that many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe, that we are only free in respect to objects which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moderately desire, because our desire for such can easily be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: controlled by the thought of something else frequently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remembered, but that we are by no means free in respect to what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we seek with violent emotion, for our desire cannot then be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: allayed with the remembrance of anything else.  However, unless
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such persons had proved by experience that we do many things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we afterwards repent of, and again that we often, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assailed by contrary emotions, see the better and follow the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worse, there would be nothing to prevent their believing that we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are free in all things.  Thus an infant believes that of its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free will it desires milk, an angry child believes that it freely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires vengeance, a timid child believes that it freely desires
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to run away; further, a drunken man believes that he utters from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the free decision of his mind words which, when he is sober, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would willingly have withheld: thus, too, a delirious man, a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: garrulous woman, a child, and others of like complexion, believe
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they speak from the free decision of their mind, when they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are in reality unable to restrain their impulse to talk.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Experience teaches us no less clearly than reason, that men
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe themselves to be free, simply because they are conscious
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of their actions, and unconscious of the causes whereby those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions are determined; and, further, it is plain that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dictates of the mind are but another name for the appetites, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore vary according to the varying state of the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Everyone shapes his actions according to his emotion, those who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are assailed by conflicting emotions know not what they wish;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who are not attacked by any emotion are readily swayed this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way or that.  All these considerations clearly show that a mental
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decision and a bodily appetite, or determined state, are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneous, or rather are one and the same thing, which we call
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decision, when it is regarded under and explained through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute of thought, and a conditioned state, when it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarded under the attribute of extension, and deduced from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of motion and rest.  This will appear yet more plainly in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sequel.  For the present I wish to call attention to another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point, namely, that we cannot act by the decision of the mind,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless we have a remembrance of having done so.  For instance, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot say a word without remembering that we have done so.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, it is not within the free power of the mind to remember or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forget a thing at will.  Therefore the freedom of the mind must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in any case be limited to the power of uttering or not uttering
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something which it remembers.  But when we dream that we speak,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we believe that we speak from a free decision of the mind, yet we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do not speak, or, if we do, it is by a spontaneous motion of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body.  Again, we dream that we are concealing something, and we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seem to act from the same decision of the mind as that, whereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we keep silence when awake concerning something we know.  Lastly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we dream that from the free decision of our mind we do something,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we should not dare to do when awake.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now I should like to know whether there be in the mind two
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sorts of decisions, one sort illusive, and the other sort free?
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If our folly does not carry us so far as this, we must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily admit, that the decision of the mind, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believed to be free, is not distinguishable from the imagination
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or memory, and is nothing more than the affirmation, which an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea, by virtue of being an idea, necessarily involves (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xlix.).  Wherefore these decisions of the mind arise in the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the same necessity, as the ideas of things actually existing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore those who believe, that they speak or keep silence or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: act in any way from the free decision of their mind, do but dream
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with their eyes open.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. III.  The activities of the mind arise solely from adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas; the passive states of the mind depend solely on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate ideas.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The first element, which constitutes the essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, is nothing else but the idea of the actually existent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body (II. xi. and xiii.), which (II. xv.) is compounded of many
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other ideas, whereof some are adequate and some inadequate (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxix. Coroll., II. xxxviii. Coroll.).  Whatsoever therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows from the nature of mind, and has mind for its proximate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause, through which it must be understood, must necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow either from an adequate or from an inadequate idea.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as the mind (III. i.) has inadequate ideas, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily passive: wherefore the activities of the mind follow
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely from adequate ideas, and accordingly the mind is only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive in so far as it has inadequate ideas.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Thus we see, that passive states are not attributed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, except in so far as it contains something involving
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negation, or in so far as it is regarded as a part of nature,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which cannot be clearly and distinctly perceived through itself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without other parts: I could thus show, that passive states are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributed to individual things in the same way that they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributed to the mind, and that they cannot otherwise be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived, but my purpose is solely to treat of the human mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IV.  Nothing can be destroyed, except by a cause external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is self--evident, for the definition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of anything affirms the essence of that thing, but does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negative it; in other words, it postulates the essence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, but does not take it away.  So long therefore as we regard
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only the thing itself, without taking into account external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes, we shall not be able to find in it anything which could
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroy it.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. V.  Things are naturally contrary, that is, cannot exist in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same object, in so far as one is capable of destroying the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If they could agree together or co--exist in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object, there would then be in the said object something which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could destroy it; but this, by the foregoing proposition, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd, therefore things, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VI.  Everything, in so far as it is in itself, endeavours
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to persist in its own being.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Individual things are modes whereby the attributes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God are expressed in a given determinate manner (I. xxv. Coroll.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, (I. xxxiv.), they are things which express in a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determinate manner the power of God, whereby God is and acts;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now no thing contains in itself anything whereby it can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed, or which can take away its existence (III. iv.); but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrariwise it is opposed to all that could take away its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence (III. v.).  Therefore, in so far as it can, and in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is in itself, it endeavours to persist in its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VII.  The endeavour, wherewith everything endeavours to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persist in its own being, is nothing else but the actual essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the thing in question.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--From the given essence of any thing certain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequences necessarily follow (I. xxxvi.), nor have things any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power save such as necessarily follows from their nature as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined (I. xxix.); wherefore the power of any given thing,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or the endeavour whereby, either alone or with other things, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acts, or endeavours to act, that is (III. vi.), the power or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour, wherewith it endeavours to persist in its own being,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is nothing else but the given or actual essence of the thing in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: question.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VIII.  The endeavour, whereby a thing endeavours to persist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in its own being, involves no finite time, but an indefinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If it involved a limited time, which should determine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the duration of the thing, it would then follow solely from that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power whereby the thing exists, that the thing could not exist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beyond the limits of that time, but that it must be destroyed;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but this (III. iv.) is absurd.  Wherefore the endeavour wherewith
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a thing exists involves no definite time; but, contrariwise,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: since (III. iv.) it will by the same power whereby it already
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exists always continue to exist, unless it be destroyed by some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external cause, this endeavour involves an indefinite time.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IX.  The mind, both in so far as it has clear and distinct
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas, and also in so far as it has confused ideas, endeavours to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persist in its being for an indefinite period, and of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour it is conscious.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The essence of the mind is constituted by adequate and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate ideas (III. iii.), therefore (III. vii.), both in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it possesses the former, and in so far as it possesses the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter, it endeavours to persist in its own being, and that for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an indefinite time (III. viii.).  Now as the mind (II. xxiii.) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily conscious of itself through the ideas of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of the body, the mind is therefore (III. vii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conscious of its own endeavour.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This endeavour, when referred solely to the mind, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called will, when referred to the mind and body in conjunction it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is called appetite; it is, in fact, nothing else but man's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence, from the nature of which necessarily follow all those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: results which tend to its preservation; and which man has thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been determined to perform.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, between appetite and desire there is no difference,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except that the term desire is generally applied to men, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as they are conscious of their appetite, and may accordingly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be thus defined: Desire is appetite with consciousness thereof.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is thus plain from what has been said, that in no case do we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strive for, wish for, long for, or desire anything, because we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deem it to be good, but on the other hand we deem a thing to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good, because we strive for it, wish for it, long for it, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. X.  An idea, which excludes the existence of our body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be postulated in our mind, but is contrary thereto.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever can destroy our body, cannot be postulated
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein (III. v.).  Therefore neither can the idea of such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing occur in God, in so far as he has the idea of our body (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ix. Coroll.); that is (II. xi., xiii.), the idea of that thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be postulated as in our mind, but contrariwise, since (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xi., xiii.) the first element, that constitutes the essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, is the idea of the human body as actually existing, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows that the first and chief endeavour of our mind is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to affirm the existence of our body: thus, an idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which negatives the existence of our body, is contrary to our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XI.  Whatsoever increases or diminishes, helps or hinders
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of activity in our body, the idea thereof increases or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminishes, helps or hinders the power of thought in our mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from II. vii. or from II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xiv.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Thus we see, that the mind can undergo many changes,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and can pass sometimes to a state of greater perfection,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sometimes to a state of lesser perfection.  These passive states
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of transition explain to us the emotions of pleasure and pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: By pleasure therefore in the following propositions I shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: signify a passive state wherein the mind passes to a greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection.  By pain I shall signify a passive state wherein the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind passes to a lesser perfection.  Further, the emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure in reference to the body and mind together I shall call
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stimulation (titillatio) or merriment (hilaritas), the emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain in the same relation I shall call suffering or melancholy.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But we must bear in mind, that stimulation and suffering are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributed to man, when one part of his nature is more affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than the rest, merriment and melancholy, when all parts are alike
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected.  What I mean by desire I have explained in the note to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. ix. of this part; beyond these three I recognize no other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: primary emotion; I will show as I proceed, that all other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions arise from these three.  But, before I go further, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should like here to explain at greater length Prop. x of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part, in order that we may clearly understand how one idea is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to another.  In the note to II. xvii. we showed that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea, which constitutes the essence of mind, involves the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of body, so long as the body itself exists.  Again, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows from what we pointed out in the Corollary to II. viii.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the present existence of our mind depends solely on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, that the mind involves the actual existence of the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, we showed (II. xvii., xviii. and note) that the power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, whereby it imagines and remembers things, also depends
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the fact, that it involves the actual existence of the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whence it follows, that the present existence of the mind and its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of imagining are removed, as soon as the mind ceases to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirm the present existence of the body.  Now the cause, why the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind ceases to affirm this existence of the body, cannot be the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind itself (III. iv.), nor again the fact that the body ceases
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to exist.  For (by II. vi.) the cause, why the mind affirms the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of the body, is not that the body began to exist;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, for the same reason, it does not cease to affirm the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of the body, because the body ceases to exist; but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xvii.) this result follows from another idea, which excludes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the present existence of our body and, consequently, of our mind,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and which is therefore contrary to the idea constituting the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of our mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XII.  The mind, as far as it can, endeavours to conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those things, which increase or help the power of activity in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--So long as the human body is affected in a mode, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves the nature of any external body, the human mind will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard that external body as present (II. xvii.), and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently (II. vii.), so long as the human mind regards an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body as present, that is (II. xvii. note), conceives it,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the human body is affected in a mode, which involves the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the said external body; thus so long as the mind conceives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, which increase or help the power of activity in our body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body is affected in modes which increase or help its power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity (III. Post. i.); consequently (III. xi.) the mind's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of thinking is for that period increased or helped.  Thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. vi., ix.) the mind, as far as it can, endeavours to imagine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such things.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIII.  When the mind conceives things which diminish or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hinder the body's power of activity, it endeavours, as far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible, to remember things which exclude the existence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first--named things.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--So long as the mind conceives anything of the kind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alluded to, the power of the mind and body is diminished or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constrained (cf. III. xii. Proof); nevertheless it will continue
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to conceive it, until the mind conceives something else, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excludes the present existence thereof (II. xvii.); that is (as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have just shown), the power of the mind and of the body is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished, or constrained, until the mind conceives something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else, which excludes the existence of the former thing conceived:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the mind (III. ix.), as far as it can, will endeavour
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to conceive or remember the latter.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that the mind shrinks from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceiving those things, which diminish or constrain the power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself and of the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--From what has been said we may clearly understand the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of Love and Hate.  Love is nothing else but pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of an external cause: Hate is nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else but pain accompanied by the idea of an external cause.  We
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further see, that he who loves necessarily endeavours to have,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to keep present to him, the object of his love; while he who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hates endeavours to remove and destroy the object of his hatred.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But I will treat of these matters at more length hereafter.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIV.  If the mind has once been affected by two emotions at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same time, it will, whenever it is afterwards affected by one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of these two, be also affected by the other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If the human body has once been affected by two bodies
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at once, whenever afterwards the mind conceives one of them, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will straightway remember the other also (II. xviii.).  But the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind's conceptions indicate rather the emotions of our body than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of external bodies (II. xvi. Coroll. ii.); therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if the body, and consequently the mind (III. Def. iii.) has been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: once affected by two emotions at the same time, it will, whenever
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is afterwards affected by one of the two, be also affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XV.  Anything can, accidentally, be the cause of pleasure,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, or desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Let it be granted that the mind is simultaneously
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by two emotions, of which one neither increases nor
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminishes its power of activity, and the other does either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increase or diminish the said power (III. Post. i.).  From the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foregoing proposition it is evident that, whenever the mind is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
