text: afterwards affected by the former, through its true cause, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by hypothesis) neither increases nor diminishes its power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action, it will be at the same time affected by the latter, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does increase or diminish its power of activity, that is (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xi. note) it will be affected with pleasure or pain.  Thus the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: former of the two emotions will, not through itself, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accidentally, be the cause of pleasure or pain.  In the same way
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also it can be easily shown, that a thing may be accidentally the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of desire.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Simply from the fact that we have regarded a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the emotion of pleasure or pain, though that thing be not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the efficient cause of the emotion, we can either love or hate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--For from this fact alone it arises (III. xiv.), that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind afterwards conceiving the said thing is affected with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the emotion of pleasure or pain, that is (III. xi. note),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according as the power of the mind and body may be increased or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished, &c.; and consequently (III. xii.), according as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind may desire or shrink from the conception of it (III. xiii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), in other words (III. xiii. note), according as it may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love or hate the same.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Hence we understand how it may happen, that we love or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hate a thing without any cause for our emotion being known to us;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely, as a phrase is, from sympathy or antipathy.  We should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: refer to the same category those objects, which affect us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably or painfully, simply because they resemble other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects which affect us in the same way.  This I will show in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: next Prop.  I am aware that certain authors, who were the first
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to introduce these terms "sympathy" and "antipathy," wished to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: signify thereby some occult qualities in things; nevertheless I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think we may be permitted to use the same terms to indicate known
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or manifest qualities.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVI.  Simply from the fact that we conceive, that a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object has some point of resemblance with another object which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wont to affect the mind pleasurably or painfully, although the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point of resemblance be not the efficient cause of the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, we shall still regard the first--named object with love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or hate.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The point of resemblance was in the object (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hypothesis), when we regarded it with pleasure or pain, thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xiv.), when the mind is affected by the image thereof, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will straightway be affected by one or the other emotion, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently the thing, which we perceive to have the same point
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of resemblance, will be accidentally (III. xv.) a cause of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure or pain.  Thus (by the foregoing Corollary), although
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the point in which the two objects resemble one another be not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the efficient cause of the emotion, we shall still regard the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first--named object with love or hate.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVII.  If we conceive that a thing, which is wont to affect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us painfully, has any point of resemblance with another thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is wont to affect us with an equally strong emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, we shall hate the first--named thing, and at the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time we shall love it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The given thing is (by hypothesis) in itself a cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of pain, and (III. xiii. note), in so far as we imagine it with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this emotion, we shall hate it: further, inasmuch as we conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it has some point of resemblance to something else, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wont to affect us with an equally strong emotion of pleasure, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall with an equally strong impulse of pleasure love it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xvi.); thus we shall both hate and love the same thing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This disposition of the mind, which arises from two
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary emotions, is called vacillation; it stands to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions in the same relation as doubt does to the imagination
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xliv. note); vacillation and doubt do not differ one from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other, except as greater differs from less.  But we must bear
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in mind that I have deduced this vacillation from causes, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: give rise through themselves to one of the emotions, and to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other accidentally.  I have done this, in order that they might
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be more easily deduced from what went before; but I do not deny
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that vacillation of the disposition generally arises from an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object, which is the efficient cause of both emotions.  The human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body is composed (II. Post. i.) of a variety of individual parts
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of different nature, and may therefore (Ax.i. after Lemma iii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after II. xiii.) be affected in a variety of different ways by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one and the same body; and contrariwise, as one and the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing can be affected in many ways, it can also in many different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways affect one and the same part of the body.  Hence we can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily conceive, that one and the same object may be the cause of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many and conflicting emotions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVIII. A man is as much affected pleasurably or painfully
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the image of a thing past or future as by the image of a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--So long as a man is affected by the image of anything,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will regard that thing as present, even though it be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: non--existent (II. xvii. and Coroll.), he will not conceive it as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: past or future, except in so far as its image is joined to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: image of time past or future (II. xliv. note).  Wherefore the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: image of a thing, regarded in itself alone, is identical, whether
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it be referred to time past, time future, or time present; that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (II. xvi. Coroll.), the disposition or emotion of the body is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: identical, whether the image be of a thing past, future, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present.  Thus the emotion of pleasure or pain is the same,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether the image be of a thing past or future.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note I.--I call a thing past or future, according as we either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have been or shall be affected thereby.  For instance, according
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we have seen it, or are about to see it, according as it has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: recreated us, or will recreate us, according as it has harmed us,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or will harm us.  For, as we thus conceive it, we affirm its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence; that is, the body is affected by no emotion which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excludes the existence of the thing, and therefore (II. xvii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body is affected by the image of the thing, in the same way
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as if the thing were actually present.  However, as it generally
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happens that those, who have had many experiences, vacillate, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as they regard a thing as future or past, and are usually in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt about its issue (II. xliv. note); it follows that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions which arise from similar images of things are not so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constant, but are generally disturbed by the images of other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, until men become assured of the issue.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note II.--From what has just been said, we understand what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meant by the terms Hope, Fear, Confidence, Despair, Joy, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Disappointment.[5]  Hope is nothing else but an inconstant
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, arising from the image of something future or past,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof we do not yet know the issue.  Fear, on the other hand,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is an inconstant pain also arising from the image of something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning which we are in doubt.  If the element of doubt be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: removed from these emotions, hope becomes Confidence and fear
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: becomes Despair.  In other words, Pleasure or Pain arising from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the image of something concerning which we have hoped or feared.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, Joy is Pleasure arising from the image of something past
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof we have doubted the issue.  Disappointment is the Pain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opposed to Joy.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [5] Conscientiae morsus--thus rendered by Mr. Pollock.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIX.  He who conceives that the object of his love is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed will feel pain; if he conceives that it is preserved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will feel pleasure.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind, as far as possible, endeavours to conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those things which increase or help the body's power of activity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xii.); in other words (III. xii. note), those things which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it loves.  But conception is helped by those things which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: postulate the existence of a thing, and contrariwise is hindered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by those which exclude the existence of a thing (II. xvii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the images of things, which postulate the existence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an object of love, help the mind's endeavour to conceive the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of love, in other words (III. xi. note), affect the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably; contrariwise those things, which exclude the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of an object of love, hinder the aforesaid mental
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour; in other words, affect the mind painfully.  He,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, who conceives that the object of his love is destroyed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will feel pain, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XX.  He who conceives that the object of his hate is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed will also feel pleasure.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind (III. xiii.) endeavours to conceive those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, which exclude the existence of things whereby the body's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of activity is diminished or constrained; that is (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xiii. note), it endeavours to conceive such things as exclude the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of what it hates; therefore the image of a thing,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which excludes the existence of what the mind hates, helps the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aforesaid mental effort, in other words (III. xi. note), affects
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind pleasurably.  Thus he who conceives that the object of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his hate is destroyed will feel pleasure.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXI.  He who conceives, that the object of his love is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected pleasurably or painfully, will himself be affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably or painfully; and the one or the other emotion will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be greater or less in the lover according as it is greater or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less in the thing loved.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The images of things (as we showed in III. xix.) which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: postulate the existence of the object of love, help the mind's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to conceive the said object.  But pleasure postulates
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the existence of something feeling pleasure, so much the more in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as the emotion of pleasure is greater; for it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xi. note) a transition to a greater perfection; therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the image of pleasure in the object of love helps the mental
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour of the lover; that is, it affects the lover
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably, and so much the more, in proportion as this emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may have been greater in the object of love.  This was our first
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point.  Further, in so far as a thing is affected with pain, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is to that extent destroyed, the extent being in proportion to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the amount of pain (III. xi. note); therefore (III. xix.) he who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives, that the object of his love is affected painfully,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will himself be affected painfully, in proportion as the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion is greater or less in the object of love.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXII.  If we conceive that anything pleasurably affects
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some object of our love, we shall be affected with love towards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that thing.  Contrariwise, if we conceive that it affects an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of our love painfully, we shall be affected with hatred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--He, who affects pleasurably or painfully the object of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our love, affects us also pleasurably or painfully--that is, if we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive the loved object as affected with the said pleasure or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain (III. xxi.). But this pleasure or pain is postulated to come
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to us accompanied by the idea of an external cause; therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xiii. note), if we conceive that anyone affects an object
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of our love pleasurably or painfully, we shall be affected with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love or hatred towards him.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Prop. xxi. explains to us the nature of Pity, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may define as pain arising from another's hurt.  What term we can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: use for pleasure arising from another's gain, I know not.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We will call the love towards him who confers a benefit on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, Approval; and the hatred towards him who injures
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, we will call Indignation.  We must further remark, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we not only feel pity for a thing which we have loved (as shown
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in III. xxi.), but also for a thing which we have hitherto
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarded without emotion, provided that we deem that it resembles
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves (as I will show presently).  Thus, we bestow approval
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on one who has benefited anything resembling ourselves, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrariwise, are indignant with him who has done it an injury.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIII.  He who conceives, that an object of his hatred is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: painfully affected, will feel pleasure.  Contrariwise, if he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinks that the said object is pleasurably affected, he will feel
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain.  Each of these emotions will be greater or less, according
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as its contrary is greater or less in the object of hatred.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as an object of hatred is painfully
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected, it is destroyed, to an extent proportioned to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength of the pain (III. xi. note).  Therefore, he (III. xx.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who conceives, that some object of his hatred is painfully
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected, will feel pleasure, to an extent proportioned to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: amount of pain he conceives in the object of his hatred.  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was our first point.  Again, pleasure postulates the existence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the pleasurably affected thing (III. xi. note), in proportion as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the pleasure is greater or less.  If anyone imagines that an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of his hatred is pleasurably affected, this conception
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xiii.) will hinder his own endeavour to persist; in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words (III. xi. note), he who hates will be painfully affected.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This pleasure can scarcely be felt unalloyed, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without any mental conflict.  For (as I am about to show in Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxvii.), in so far as a man conceives that something similar to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself is affected by pain, he will himself be affected in like
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner; and he will have the contrary emotion in contrary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstances.  But here we are regarding hatred only.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIV.  If we conceive that anyone pleasurably affects an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of our hate, we shall feel hatred towards him also.  If we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive that he painfully affects that said object, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feel love towards him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is proved in the same way as III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxii., which see.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--These and similar emotions of hatred are attributable
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to envy, which, accordingly, is nothing else but hatred, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is regarded as disposing a man to rejoice in another's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hurt, and to grieve at another's advantage.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXV.  We endeavour to affirm, concerning ourselves, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning what we love, everything that we can conceive to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affect pleasurably ourselves, or the loved object.  Contrariwise,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we endeavour to negative everything, which we conceive to affect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: painfully ourselves or the loved object.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--That, which we conceive to affect an object of our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love pleasurably or painfully, affects us also pleasurably or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: painfully (III. xxi.).  But the mind (III. xii.) endeavours, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as possible, to conceive those things which affect us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably; in other words (II. xvii. and Coroll.), it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours to regard them as present.  And, contrariwise (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xiii.), it endeavours to exclude the existence of such things as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affect us painfully; therefore, we endeavour to affirm
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning ourselves, and concerning the loved object, whatever
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we conceive to affect ourselves, or the love object pleasurably.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVI.  We endeavour to affirm, concerning that which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hate, everything which we conceive to affect it painfully; and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrariwise, we endeavour to deny, concerning it, everything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we conceive to affect it pleasurably.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition follows from III. xxiii., as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foregoing proposition followed from III. xxi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Thus we see that it may readily happen, that a man may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily think too highly of himself, or a loved object, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrariwise, too meanly of a hated object.  This feeling is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called pride, in reference to the man who thinks too highly of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, and is a species of madness, wherein a man dreams with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his eyes open, thinking that he can accomplish all things that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fall within the scope of his conception, and thereupon accounting
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them real, and exulting in them, so long as he is unable to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive anything which excludes their existence, and determines
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own power of action.  Pride, therefore, is pleasure springing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from a man thinking too highly of himself.  Again, the pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which arises from a man thinking too highly of another is called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over--esteem.  Whereas the pleasure which arises from thinking too
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: little of a man is called disdain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVII.  By the very fact that we conceive a thing, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like ourselves, and which we have not regarded with any emotion,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be affected with any emotion, we are ourselves affected with a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like emotion (affectus).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The images of things are modifications of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, whereof the ideas represent external bodies as present to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us (II. xvii.); in other words (II. x.), whereof the ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involve the nature of our body, and, at the same time, the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the external bodies as present.  If, therefore, the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the external body be similar to the nature of our body, then the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea which we form of the external body will involve a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification of our own body similar to the modification of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external body.  Consequently, if we conceive anyone similar to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves as affected by any emotion, this conception will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: express a modification of our body similar to that emotion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus, from the fact of conceiving a thing like ourselves to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected with any emotion, we are ourselves affected with a like
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion.  If, however, we hate the said thing like ourselves, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall, to that extent, be affected by a contrary, and not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similar, emotion.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note I.--This imitation of emotions, when it is referred to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, is called compassion (cf. III. xxii. note); when it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to desire, it is called emulation, which is nothing else
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but the desire of anything, engendered in us by the fact that we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive that others have the like desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--If we conceive that anyone, whom we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hitherto regarded with no emotion, pleasurably affects something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similar to ourselves, we shall be affected with love towards him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If, on the other hand, we conceive that he painfully affects the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same, we shall be affected with hatred towards him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is proved from the last proposition in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner as III. xxii. is proved from III. xxi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--We cannot hate a thing which we pity, because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its misery affects us painfully.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If we could hate it for this reason, we should rejoice
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in its pain, which is contrary to the hypothesis.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary III.--We seek to free from misery, as far as we can,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a thing which we pity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--That, which painfully affects the object of our pity,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affects us also with similar pain (by the foregoing proposition);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, we shall endeavour to recall everything which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: removes its existence, or which destroys it (cf. III. xiii.); in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words (III. ix. note), we shall desire to destroy it, or we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall be determined for its destruction; thus, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to free from misery a thing which we pity.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note II.--This will or appetite for doing good, which arises
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from pity of the thing whereon we would confer a benefit, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called benevolence, and is nothing else but desire arising from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compassion.  Concerning love or hate towards him who has done
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good or harm to something, which we conceive to be like
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves, see III. xxii. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVIII.  We endeavour to bring about whatsoever we conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to conduce to pleasure; but we endeavour to remove or destroy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever we conceive to be truly repugnant thereto, or to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conduce to pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We endeavour, as far as possible, to conceive that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we imagine to conduce to pleasure (III. xii.); in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words (II. xvii.) we shall endeavour to conceive it as far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible as present or actually existing.  But the endeavour of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, or the mind's power of thought, is equal to, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneous with, the endeavour of the body, or the body's power
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of action.  (This is clear from II. vii. Coroll. and II. xi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.).  Therefore we make an absolute endeavour for its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence, in other words (which by III. ix. note, come to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same thing) we desire and strive for it; this was our first
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point.  Again, if we conceive that something, which we believed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be the cause of pain, that is (III. xiii. note), which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hate, is destroyed, we shall rejoice (III. xx.).  We shall,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (by the first part of this proof), endeavour to destroy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same, or (III. xiii.) to remove it from us, so that we may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not regard it as present; this was our second point.  Wherefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever conduces to pleasure, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIX.  We shall also endeavour to do whatsoever we conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men[6] to regard with pleasure, and contrariwise we shall shrink
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from doing that which we conceive men to shrink from.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [6] By "men" in this and the following propositions, I mean men
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whom we regard without any particular emotion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--From the fact of imagining, that men love or hate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything, we shall love or hate the same thing (III. xxvii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: That is (III. xiii. note), from this mere fact we shall feel
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure or pain at the thing's presence.  And so we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to do whatsoever we conceive men to love or regard with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, etc.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This endeavour to do a thing or leave it undone, solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in order to please men, we call ambition, especially when we so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eagerly endeavour to please the vulgar, that we do or omit
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain things to our own or another's hurt: in other cases it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is generally called kindliness.  Furthermore I give the name of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: praise to the pleasure, with which we conceive the action of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, whereby he has endeavoured to please us; but of blame
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the pain wherewith we feel aversion to his action.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXX.  If anyone has done something which he conceives as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affecting other men pleasurably, he will be affected by pleasure,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of himself as cause; in other words, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will regard himself with pleasure.  On the other hand, if he has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done anything which he conceives as affecting others painfully,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will regard himself with pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--He who conceives, that he affects others with pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or pain, will, by that very fact, himself be affected with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure or pain (III. xxvii.), but, as a man (II. xix. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiii.) is conscious of himself through the modifications whereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is determined to action, it follows that he who conceives,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he affects others pleasurably, will be affected with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure accompanied by the idea of himself as cause; in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, he will regard himself with pleasure.  And so mutatis
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mutandis in the case of pain.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--As love (III. xiii.) is pleasure accompanied by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of an external cause, and hatred is pain accompanied by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of an external cause; the pleasure and pain in question
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be a species of love and hatred.  But, as the terms love and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred are used in reference to external objects, we will employ
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other names for the emotions now under discussion: pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of an external cause[7] we will style
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Honour, and the emotion contrary thereto we will style Shame: I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean in such cases as where pleasure or pain arises from a man's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belief, that he is being praised or blamed: otherwise pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of an external cause[8] is called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--complacency, and its contrary pain is called repentance.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, as it may happen (II. xvii. Coroll.) that the pleasure,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherewith a man conceives that he affects others, may exist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely in his own imagination, and as (III. xxv.) everyone
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours to conceive concerning himself that which he conceives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will affect him with pleasure, it may easily come to pass that a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vain man may be proud and may imagine that he is pleasing to all,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when in reality he may be an annoyance to all.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [7] So Van Vloten and Bruder.  The Dutch version and Camerer read,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "an internal cause."  "Honor" = Gloria.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [8] See previous endnote.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXI.  If we conceive that anyone loves, desires, or hates
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything which we ourselves love, desire, or hate, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereupon regard the thing in question with more steadfast love,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &c.  On the contrary, if we think that anyone shrinks from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something that we love, we shall undergo vacillations of soul.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--From the mere fact of conceiving that anyone loves
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything we shall ourselves love that thing (III. xxvii.): but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are assumed to love it already; there is, therefore, a new
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of love, whereby our former emotion is fostered; hence we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall thereupon love it more steadfastly.  Again, from the mere
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact of conceiving that anyone shrinks from anything, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves shrink from that thing (III. xxvii.).  If we assume
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we at the same time love it, we shall then simultaneously
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love it and shrink from it; in other words, we shall be subject
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to vacillation (III. xvii. note).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--From the foregoing, and also from III. xxviii. it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows that everyone endeavours, as far as possible, to cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others to love what he himself loves, and to hate what he himself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hates: as the poet says:  "As lovers let us share every hope
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and every fear: ironhearted were he who should love what the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other leaves."[9]
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [9] Ovid, "Amores," II. xix. 4,5.  Spinoza transposes the verses.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Speremus pariter, pariter metuamus amantes;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ferreus est, si quis, quod sinit alter, amat."
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This endeavour to bring it about, that our own likes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and dislikes should meet with universal approval, is really
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ambition (see III. xxix. note); wherefore we see that everyone
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by nature desires (appetere), that the rest of mankind should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: live according to his own individual disposition: when such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire is equally present in all, everyone stands in everyone
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else's way, and in wishing to be loved or praised by all, all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: become mutually hateful.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXII.  If we conceive that anyone takes delight in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something, which only one person can possess, we shall endeavour
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to bring it about that the man in question shall not gain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possession thereof.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--From the mere fact of our conceiving that another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: person takes delight in a thing (III. xxvii. and Coroll.) we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall ourselves love that thing and desire to take delight
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein.  But we assumed that the pleasure in question would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prevented by another's delight in its object; we shall,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, endeavour to prevent his possession thereof (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxviii.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We thus see that man's nature is generally so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituted, that he takes pity on those who fare ill, and envies
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who fare well with an amount of hatred proportioned to his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own love for the goods in their possession.  Further, we see that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the same property of human nature, whence it follows that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men are merciful, it follows also that they are envious and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ambitious.  Lastly, if we make appeal to Experience, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: find that she entirely confirms what we have said; more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially if we turn our attention to the first years of our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life.  We find that children, whose body is continually, as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were, in equilibrium, laugh or cry simply because they see others
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laughing or crying; moreover, they desire forthwith to imitate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatever they see others doing, and to possess themselves of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatever they conceive as delighting others: inasmuch as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: images of things are, as we have said, modifications of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, or modes wherein the human body is affected and disposed by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external causes to act in this or that manner.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIII.  When we love a thing similar to ourselves we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour, as far as we can, to bring about that it should love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us in return.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--That which we love we endeavour, as far as we can, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive in preference to anything else (III. xii.).  If the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing be similar to ourselves, we shall endeavour to affect it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably in preference to anything else (III. xxix.).  In
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, we shall endeavour, as far as we can, to bring it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about, that the thing should be affected with pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of ourselves, that is (III. xiii. note),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it should love us in return.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIV.  The greater the emotion with which we conceive a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved object to be affected towards us, the greater will be our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: complacency.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We endeavour (III. xxxiii.), as far as we can, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bring about, that what we love should love us in return: in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, that what we love should be affected with pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of ourself as cause.  Therefore, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as the loved object is more pleasurably affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because of us, our endeavour will be assisted.--that is (III. xi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and note) the greater will be our pleasure.  But when we take
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure in the fact, that we pleasurably affect something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similar to ourselves, we regard ourselves with pleasure (III. 30);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the greater the emotion with which we conceive a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved object to be affected, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXV.  If anyone conceives, that an object of his love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: joins itself to another with closer bonds of friendship than he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself has attained to, he will be affected with hatred towards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the loved object and with envy towards his rival.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In proportion as a man thinks, that a loved object is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: well affected towards him, will be the strength of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--approval (by the last Prop.), that is (III. xxx. note), of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his pleasure; he will, therefore (III. xxviii.), endeavour, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he can, to imagine the loved object as most closely bound
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to him: this endeavour or desire will be increased, if he thinks
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that someone else has a similar desire (III. xxxi.).  But this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour or desire is assumed to be checked by the image of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved object in conjunction with the image of him whom the loved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object has joined to itself; therefore (III. xi. note) he will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for that reason be affected with pain, accompanied by the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the loved object as a cause in conjunction with the image of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rival; that is, he will be (III. xiii.) affected with hatred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards the loved object and also towards his rival (III. xv.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), which latter he will envy as enjoying the beloved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This hatred towards an object of love joined with envy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is called Jealousy, which accordingly is nothing else but a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wavering of the disposition arising from combined love and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred, accompanied by the idea of some rival who is envied.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, this hatred towards the object of love will be greater,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in proportion to the pleasure which the jealous man had been wont
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to derive from the reciprocated love of the said object; and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also in proportion to the feelings he had previously entertained
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards his rival.  If he had hated him, he will forthwith hate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the object of his love, because he conceives it is pleasurably
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by one whom he himself hates: and also because he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compelled to associate the image of his loved one with the image
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of him whom he hates.  This condition generally comes into play
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the case of love for a woman: for he who thinks, that a woman
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whom he loves prostitutes herself to another, will feel pain, not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only because his own desire is restrained, but also because,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being compelled to associate the image of her he loves with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts of shame and the excreta of another, he therefore shrinks
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from her.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We must add, that a jealous man is not greeted by his beloved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the same joyful countenance as before, and this also gives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him pain as a lover, as I will now show.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVI.  He who remembers a thing, in which he has once
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: taken delight, desires to possess it under the same circumstances
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as when he first took delight therein.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Everything, which a man has seen in conjunction with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the object of his love, will be to him accidentally a cause of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure (III. xv.); he will, therefore, desire to possess it,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in conjunction with that wherein he has taken delight; in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, he will desire to possess the object of his love under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same circumstances as when he first took delight therein.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--A lover will, therefore, feel pain if one of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aforesaid attendant circumstances be missing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--For, in so far as he finds some circumstance to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: missing, he conceives something which excludes its existence.  As
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is assumed to be desirous for love's sake of that thing or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstance (by the last Prop.), he will, in so far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives it to be missing, feel pain (III. xix.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This pain, in so far as it has reference to the absence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the object of love, is called Regret.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVII.  Desire arising through pain or pleasure, hatred or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, is greater in proportion as the emotion is greater.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Pain diminishes or constrains a man's power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity (III. xi. note), in other words (III. vii.), diminishes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or constrains the effort, wherewith he endeavours to persist in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own being; therefore (III. v.) it is contrary to the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour: thus all the endeavours of a man affected by pain are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directed to removing that pain.  But (by the definition of pain),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in proportion as the pain is greater, so also is it necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opposed to a greater part of man's power of activity; therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the greater the pain, the greater the power of activity employed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to remove it; that is, the greater will be the desire or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appetite in endeavouring to remove it.  Again, since pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xi. note) increases or aids a man's power of activity, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may easily be shown in like manner, that a man affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure has no desire further than to preserve it, and his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire will be in proportion to the magnitude of the pleasure.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, since hatred and love are themselves emotions of pain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and pleasure, it follows in like manner that the endeavour,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appetite, or desire, which arises through hatred or love, will be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater in proportion to the hatred or love.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVIII.  If a man has begun to hate an object of his love,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so that love is thoroughly destroyed, he will, causes being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equal, regard it with more hatred than if he had never loved it,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and his hatred will be in proportion to the strength of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: former love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If a man begins to hate that which he had loved, more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of his appetites are put under restraint than if he had never
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved it.  For love is a pleasure (III. xiii. note) which a man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours as far as he can to render permanent (III. xxviii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he does so by regarding the object of his love as present, and by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affecting it as far as he can pleasurably; this endeavour is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater in proportion as the love is greater, and so also is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to bring about that the beloved should return his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affection (III. xxxiii.).  Now these endeavours are constrained
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by hatred towards the object of love (III. xiii. Coroll. and III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiii.); wherefore the lover (III. xi. note) will for this cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also be affected with pain, the more so in proportion as his love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has been greater; that is, in addition to the pain caused by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred, there is a pain caused by the fact that he has loved the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object; wherefore the lover will regard the beloved with greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, or in other words, will hate it more than if he had never
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved it, and with the more intensity in proportion as his former
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love was greater.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIX.  He who hates anyone will endeavour to do him an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injury, unless he fears that a greater injury will thereby accrue
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to himself; on the other hand, he who loves anyone will, by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same law, seek to benefit him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--To hate a man is (III. xiii. note) to conceive him as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a cause of pain; therefore he who hates a man will endeavour to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remove or destroy him.  But if anything more painful, or, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, a greater evil, should accrue to the hater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereby--and if the hater thinks he can avoid such evil by not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: carrying out the injury, which he planned against the object of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his hate--he will desire to abstain from inflicting that injury
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xxviii.), and the strength of his endeavour (III. xxxvii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be greater than his former endeavour to do injury, and will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore prevail over it, as we asserted.  The second part of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this proof proceeds in the same manner.  Wherefore he who hates
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, etc.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--By good I here mean every kind of pleasure, and all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that conduces thereto, especially that which satisfies our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longings, whatsoever they may be.  By evil, I mean every kind of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, especially that which frustrates our longings.  For I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown (III. ix. note) that we in no case desire a thing because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we deem it good, but, contrariwise, we deem a thing good because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we desire it: consequently we deem evil that which we shrink
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from; everyone, therefore, according to his particular emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judges or estimates what is good, what is bad, what is better,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is worse, lastly, what is best, and what is worst.  Thus a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miser thinks that abundance of money is the best, and want of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: money the worst; an ambitious man desires nothing so much as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: glory, and fears nothing so much as shame.  To an envious man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing is more delightful than another's misfortune, and nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more painful than another's success.  So every man, according to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his emotions, judges a thing to be good or bad, useful or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useless.  The emotion, which induces a man to turn from that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he wishes, or to wish for that which he turns from, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called timidity, which may accordingly be defined as the fear
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby a man is induced to avoid an evil which he regards as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future by encountering a lesser evil (III. xxviii.).  But if the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil which he fears be shame, timidity becomes bashfulness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, if the desire to avoid a future evil be checked by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear of another evil, so that the man knows not which to choose,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear becomes consternation, especially if both the evils feared
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be very great.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XL.  He, who conceives himself to be hated by another, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believes that he has given him no cause for hatred, will hate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that other in return.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--He who conceives another as affected with hatred, will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereupon be affected himself with hatred (III. xxvii.), that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with pain, accompanied by the idea of an external cause.  But, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the hypothesis, he conceives no cause for this pain except him
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who is his enemy; therefore, from conceiving that he is hated by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some one, he will be affected with pain, accompanied by the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of his enemy; in other words, he will hate his enemy in return.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--He who thinks that he has given just cause for hatred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will (III. xxx. and note) be affected with shame; but this case
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xxv.) rarely happens.  This reciprocation of hatred may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also arise from the hatred, which follows an endeavour to injure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the object of our hate (III. xxxix.).  He therefore who conceives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he is hated by another will conceive his enemy as the cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of some evil or pain; thus he will be affected with pain or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear, accompanied by the idea of his enemy as cause; in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, he will be affected with hatred towards his enemy, as I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said above.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--He who conceives, that one whom he loves hates
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him, will be a prey to conflicting hatred and love.  For, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he conceives that he is an object of hatred, he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to hate his enemy in return.  But, by the hypothesis,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he nevertheless loves him: wherefore he will be a prey to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conflicting hatred and love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--If a man conceives that one, whom he has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hitherto regarded without emotion, has done him any injury from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motives of hatred, he will forthwith seek to repay the injury in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--He who conceives, that another hates him, will (by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last proposition) hate his enemy in return, and (III. xxvi.) will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to recall everything which can affect him painfully;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will moreover endeavour to do him an injury (III. xxxix.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now the first thing of this sort which he conceives is the injury
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done to himself; he will, therefore, forthwith endeavour to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repay it in kind.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The endeavour to injure one whom we hate is called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Anger; the endeavour to repay in kind injury done to ourselves
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is called Revenge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLI.  If anyone conceives that he is loved by another, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believes that he has given no cause for such love, he will love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that other in return.  (Cf. III. xv. Coroll., and III. xvi.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is proved in the same way as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preceding one.  See also the note appended thereto.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--If he believes that he has given just cause for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, he will take pride therein (III. xxx. and note); this is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what most often happens (III. xxv.), and we said that its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary took place whenever a man conceives himself to be hated
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by another.  (See note to preceding proposition.)  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reciprocal love, and consequently the desire of benefiting him
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who loves us (III. xxxix.), and who endeavours to benefit us, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called gratitude or thankfulness.  It thus appears that men are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much more prone to take vengeance than to return benefits.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--He who imagines that he is loved by one whom he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hates, will be a prey to conflicting hatred and love.  This is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proved in the same way as the first corollary of the preceding
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--If hatred be the prevailing emotion, he will endeavour
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to injure him who loves him; this emotion is called cruelty,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially if the victim be believed to have given no ordinary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause for hatred.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLII.  He who has conferred a benefit on anyone from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motives of love or honour will feel pain, if he sees that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: benefit is received without gratitude.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--When a man loves something similar to himself, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours, as far as he can, to bring it about that he should be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved thereby in return (III. xxxiii.).  Therefore he who has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conferred a benefit confers it in obedience to the desire, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he feels of being loved in return; that is (III. xxxiv.) from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the hope of honour or (III. xxx. note) pleasure; hence he will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour, as far as he can, to conceive this cause of honour, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to regard it as actually existing.  But, by the hypothesis, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives something else, which excludes the existence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said cause of honour: wherefore he will thereat feel pain (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xix.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIII.  Hatred is increased by being reciprocated, and can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the other hand be destroyed by love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--He who conceives, that an object of his hatred hates
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him in return, will thereupon feel a new hatred, while the former
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred (by hypothesis) still remains (III. xl.).  But if, on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other hand, he conceives that the object of hate loves him, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will to this extent (III. xxxviii.) regard himself with pleasure,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and (III. xxix.) will endeavour to please the cause of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion.  In other words, he will endeavour not to hate him (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xli.), and not to affect him painfully; this endeavour (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvii.) will be greater or less in proportion to the emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from which it arises.  Therefore, if it be greater than that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which arises from hatred, and through which the man endeavours to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affect painfully the thing which he hates, it will get the better
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of it and banish the hatred from his mind.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIV.  Hatred which is completely vanquished by love passes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into love: and love is thereupon greater than if hatred had not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preceded it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The proof proceeds in the same way as Prop. xxxviii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this Part: for he who begins to love a thing, which he was
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
