text: wont to hate or regard with pain, from the very fact of loving
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feels pleasure.  To this pleasure involved in love is added the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure arising from aid given to the endeavour to remove the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain involved in hatred (III. xxxvii.), accompanied by the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the former object of hatred as cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Though this be so, no one will endeavour to hate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything, or to be affected with pain, for the sake of enjoying
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this greater pleasure; that is, no one will desire that he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be injured, in the hope of recovering from the injury, nor
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long to be ill for the sake of getting well.  For everyone will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always endeavour to persist in his being, and to ward off pain as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as he can.  If the contrary is conceivable, namely, that a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man should desire to hate someone, in order that he might love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him the more thereafter, he will always desire to hate him.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the strength of love is in proportion to the strength of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred, wherefore the man would desire, that the hatred be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continually increased more and more, and, for a similar reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he would desire to become more and more ill, in order that he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: might take a greater pleasure in being restored to health: in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such a case he would always endeavour to be ill, which (III. vi.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLV.  If a man conceives, that anyone similar to himself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hates anything also similar to himself, which he loves, he will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hate that person.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The beloved object feels reciprocal hatred towards him
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who hates it (III. xl.); therefore the lover, in conceiving that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone hates the beloved object, conceives the beloved thing as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by hatred, in other words (III. xiii.), by pain;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently he is himself affected by pain accompanied by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of the hater of the beloved thing as cause; that is, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will hate him who hates anything which he himself loves (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xiii. note).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVI.  If a man has been affected pleasurably or painfully
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by anyone, of a class or nation different from his own, and if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the pleasure or pain has been accompanied by the idea of the said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stranger as cause, under the general category of the class or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nation: the man will feel love or hatred, not only to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual stranger, but also to the whole class or nation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereto he belongs.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is evident from III. xvi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVII.  Joy arising from the fact, that anything we hate is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed, or suffers other injury, is never unaccompanied by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain pain in us.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is evident from III. xxvii.  For in so far as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive a thing similar to ourselves to be affected with pain,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we ourselves feel pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition can also be proved from the Corollary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to II. xvii.  Whenever we remember anything, even if it does not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actually exist, we regard it only as present, and the body is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected in the same manner; wherefore, in so far as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remembrance of the thing is strong, a man is determined to regard
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it with pain; this determination, while the image of the thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in question lasts, is indeed checked by the remembrance of other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things excluding the existence of the aforesaid thing, but is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed: hence, a man only feels pleasure in so far as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said determination is checked: for this reason the joy arising
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the injury done to what we hate is repeated, every time we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remember that object of hatred.  For, as we have said, when the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: image of the thing in question, is aroused, inasmuch as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves the thing's existence, it determines the man to regard
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thing with the same pain as he was wont to do, when it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actually did exist.  However, since he has joined to the image of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thing other images, which exclude its existence, this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determination to pain is forthwith checked, and the man rejoices
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: afresh as often as the repetition takes place.  This is the cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of men's pleasure in recalling past evils, and delight in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrating dangers from which they have escaped.  For when men
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive a danger, they conceive it as still future, and are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to fear it; this determination is checked afresh by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of freedom, which became associated with the idea of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: danger when they escaped therefrom: this renders them secure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: afresh: therefore they rejoice afresh.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVIII.  Love or hatred towards, for instance, Peter is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed, if the pleasure involved in the former, or the pain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involved in the latter emotion, be associated with the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another cause: and will be diminished in proportion as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive Peter not to have been the sole cause of either emotion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This Prop. is evident from the mere definition of love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and hatred (III. xiii. note).  For pleasure is called love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards Peter, and pain is called hatred towards Peter, simply in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as Peter is regarded as the cause of one emotion or the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other.  When this condition of causality is either wholly or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: partly removed, the emotion towards Peter also wholly or in part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vanishes.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIX.  Love or hatred towards a thing, which we conceive to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be free, must, other conditions being similar, be greater than if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it were felt towards a thing acting by necessity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A thing which we conceive as free must (I. Def. vii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be perceived through itself without anything else.  If,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, we conceive it as the cause of pleasure or pain, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall therefore (III. xiii. note) love it or hate it, and shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do so with the utmost love or hatred that can arise from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given emotion.  But if the thing which causes the emotion be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived as acting by necessity, we shall then (by the same Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii. Part I.) conceive it not as the sole cause, but as one of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the causes of the emotion, and therefore our love or hatred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards it will be less.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Hence it follows, that men, thinking themselves to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free, feel more love or hatred towards one another than towards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything else: to this consideration we must add the imitation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of emotions treated of in III. xxvii., xxxiv., xl. and xliii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. L.  Anything whatever can be, accidentally, a cause of hope
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or fear.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is proved in the same way as III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xv., which see, together with the note to III. xviii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Things which are accidentally the causes of hope or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear are called good or evil omens.  Now, in so far as such omens
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are the cause of hope or fear, they are (by the definitions of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hope and fear given in III. xviii. note) the causes also of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure and pain; consequently we, to this extent, regard them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with love or hatred, and endeavour either to invoke them as means
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards that which we hope for, or to remove them as obstacles,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or causes of that which we fear.  It follows, further, from III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxv., that we are naturally so constituted as to believe readily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in that which we hope for, and with difficulty in that which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear; moreover, we are apt to estimate such objects above or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: below their true value.  Hence there have arisen superstitions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby men are everywhere assailed.  However, I do not think it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worth while to point out here the vacillations springing from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hope and fear; it follows from the definition of these emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that there can be no hope without fear, and no fear without hope,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as I will duly explain in the proper place.  Further, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we hope for or fear anything, we regard it with love or hatred;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus everyone can apply by himself to hope and fear what we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said concerning love and hatred.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LI.  Different men may be differently affected by the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object, and the same man may be differently affected at different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: times by the same object.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The human body is affected by external bodies in a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: variety of ways (II. Post. iii.).  Two men may therefore be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differently affected at the same time, and therefore (by Ax. i.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after Lemma iii. after II. xiii.) may be differently affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one and the same object.  Further (by the same Post.) the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body can be affected sometimes in one way, sometimes in another;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently (by the same Axiom) it may be differently affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at different times by one and the same object.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We thus see that it is possible, that what one man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loves another may hate, and that what one man fears another may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not fear; or, again, that one and the same man may love what he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: once hated, or may be bold where he once was timid, and so on.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, as everyone judges according to his emotions what is good,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what bad, what better, and what worse (III. xxxix. note), it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows that men's judgments may vary no less than their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions[10], hence when we compare some with others, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguish them solely by the diversity of their emotions, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: style some intrepid, others timid, others by some other epithet.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For instance, I shall call a man intrepid, if he despises an evil
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which I am accustomed to fear; if I further take into
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consideration, that, in his desire to injure his enemies and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: benefit those whom he loves, he is not restrained by the fear of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an evil which is sufficient to restrain me, I shall call him
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: daring.  Again, a man will appear timid to me, if he fears an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil which I am accustomed to despise; and if I further take
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into consideration that his desire is restrained by the fear of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an evil, which is not sufficient to restrain me, I shall say that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is cowardly; and in like manner will everyone pass judgment.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [10] This is possible, though the human mind is part of the divine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect, as I have shown in II. xiii. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, from this inconstancy in the nature of human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judgment, inasmuch as a man often judges things solely by his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, and inasmuch as the things which he believes cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure or pain, and therefore endeavours to promote or prevent,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are often purely imaginary, not to speak of the uncertainty of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things alluded to in III. xxviii.; we may readily conceive that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man may be at one time affected with pleasure, and at another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with pain, accompanied by the idea of himself as cause.  Thus we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can easily understand what are Repentance and Self--complacency.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Repentance is pain, accompanied by the idea of one's self as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause; Self--complacency is pleasure, accompanied by the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one's self as cause, and these emotions are most intense because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men believe themselves to be free (III. xlix.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LII.  An object which we have formerly seen in conjunction
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with others, and which we do not conceive to have any property
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is not common to many, will not be regarded by us for so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long, as an object which we conceive to have some property
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peculiar to itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--As soon as we conceive an object which we have seen in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conjunction with others, we at once remember those others (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xviii. and note), and thus we pass forthwith from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation of one object to the contemplation of another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object.  And this is the case with the object, which we conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to have no property that is not common to many.  For we thereupon
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assume that we are regarding therein nothing, which we have not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before seen in conjunction with other objects.  But when we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suppose that we conceive an object something special, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have never seen before, we must needs say that the mind, while
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarding that object, has in itself nothing which it can fall to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarding instead thereof; therefore it is determined to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation of that object only.  Therefore an object, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This mental modification, or imagination of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular thing, in so far as it is alone in the mind, is called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wonder; but if it be excited by an object of fear, it is called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Consternation, because wonder at an evil keeps a man so engrossed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the simple contemplation thereof, that he has no power to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think of anything else whereby he might avoid the evil.  If,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: however, the object of wonder be a man's prudence, industry, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything of that sort, inasmuch as the said man, is thereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarded as far surpassing ourselves, wonder is called Veneration;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: otherwise, if a man's anger, envy, &c., be what we wonder at,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the emotion is called Horror.  Again, if it be the prudence,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: industry, or what not, of a man we love, that we wonder at, our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love will on this account be the greater (III. xii.), and when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: joined to wonder or veneration is called Devotion.  We may in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like manner conceive hatred, hope, confidence, and the other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, as associated with wonder; and we should thus be able
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to deduce more emotions than those which have obtained names in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinary speech.  Whence it is evident, that the names of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions have been applied in accordance rather with their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinary manifestations than with an accurate knowledge of their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: To wonder is opposed Contempt, which generally arises from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fact that, because we see someone wondering at, loving, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fearing something, or because something, at first sight, appears
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be like things, which we ourselves wonder at, love, fear, &c.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are, in consequence (III. xv. Coroll. and III. xxvii.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to wonder at, love, or fear that thing.  But if from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the presence, or more accurate contemplation of the said thing,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are compelled to deny concerning it all that can be the cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of wonder, love, fear, &c., the mind then, by the presence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, remains determined to think rather of those qualities
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are not in it, than of those which are in it; whereas, on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other hand, the presence of the object would cause it more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particularly to regard that which is therein.  As devotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: springs from wonder at a thing which we love, so does Derision
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spring from contempt of a thing which we hate or fear, and Scorn
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from contempt of folly, as veneration from wonder at prudence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, we can conceive the emotions of love, hope, honour, &c.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in association with contempt, and can thence deduce other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, which are not distinguished one from another by any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: recognized name.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LIII.  When the mind regards itself and its own power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity, it feels pleasure: and that pleasure is greater in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion to the distinctness wherewith it conceives itself and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its own power of activity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A man does not know himself except through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of his body, and the ideas thereof (II. xix. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiii.).  When, therefore, the mind is able to contemplate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, it is thereby assumed to pass to a greater perfection, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xi. note) to feel pleasure; and the pleasure will be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater in proportion to the distinctness, wherewith it is able
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to conceive itself and its own power of activity.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--This pleasure is fostered more and more, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as a man conceives himself to be praised by others.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For the more he conceives himself as praised by others, the more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will imagine them to be affected with pleasure, accompanied by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of himself (III. xxix. note); thus he is (III. xxvii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself affected with greater pleasure, accompanied by the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of himself.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LIV. The mind endeavours to conceive only such things as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assert its power of activity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The endeavour or power of the mind is the actual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence thereof (III. vii.); but the essence of the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obviously only affirms that which the mind is and can do; not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which it neither is nor can do; therefore the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours to conceive only such things as assert or affirm its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of activity.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LV.  When the mind contemplates its own weakness, it feels
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain thereat.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The essence of the mind only affirms that which the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind is, or can do; in other words, it is the mind's nature to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive only such things as assert its power of activity (last
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.).  Thus, when we say that the mind contemplates its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: weakness, we are merely saying that while the mind is attempting
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to conceive something which asserts its power of activity, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: checked in its endeavour----in other words (III. xi. note), it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feels pain.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--This pain is more and more fostered, if a man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives that he is blamed by others; this may be proved in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same way as the corollary to III. liii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This pain, accompanied by the idea of our own weakness,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is called humility; the pleasure, which springs from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation of ourselves, is called self--love or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--complacency.  And inasmuch as this feeling is renewed as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: often as a man contemplates his own virtues, or his own power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity, it follows that everyone is fond of narrating his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exploits, and displaying the force both of his body and mind, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also that, for this reason, men are troublesome to one another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, it follows that men are naturally envious (III. xxiv.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note, and III. xxxii. note), rejoicing in the shortcomings of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their equals, and feeling pain at their virtues.  For whenever a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man conceives his own actions, he is affected with pleasure (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: liii.), in proportion as his actions display more perfection, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he conceives them more distinctly--that is (II. xl. note), in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as he can distinguish them from others, and regard
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them as something special.  Therefore, a man will take most
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure in contemplating himself, when he contemplates some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quality which he denies to others.  But, if that which he affirms
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of himself be attributable to the idea of man or animals in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general, he will not be so greatly pleased: he will, on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary, feel pain, if he conceives that his own actions fall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: short when compared with those of others.  This pain (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxviii.) he will endeavour to remove, by putting a wrong
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: construction on the actions of his equals, or by, as far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can, embellishing his own.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is thus apparent that men are naturally prone to hatred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and envy, which latter is fostered by their education.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parents are accustomed to incite their children to virtue solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the spur of honour and envy.  But, perhaps, some will scruple
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to assent to what I have said, because we not seldom admire men's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtues, and venerate their possessors.  In order to remove such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubts, I append the following corollary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--No one envies the virtue of anyone who is not his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Envy is a species of hatred (III. xxiv. note) or (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xiii. note) pain, that is (III. xi. note), a modification whereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man's power of activity, or endeavour towards activity, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: checked.  But a man does not endeavour or desire to do anything,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which cannot follow from his nature as it is given; therefore a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man will not desire any power of activity or virtue (which is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same thing) to be attributed to him, that is appropriate to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another's nature and foreign to his own; hence his desire cannot
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be checked, nor he himself pained by the contemplation of virtue
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in some one unlike himself, consequently he cannot envy such an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one.  But he can envy his equal, who is assumed to have the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature as himself.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--When, therefore, as we said in the note to III. lii.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we venerate a man, through wonder at his prudence, fortitude,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &c., we do so, because we conceive those qualities to be peculiar
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to him, and not as common to our nature; we, therefore, no more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: envy their possessor, than we envy trees for being tall, or lions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for being courageous.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LVI.  There are as many kinds of pleasure, of pain, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire, and of every emotion compounded of these, such as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vacillations of spirit, or derived from these, such as love,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred, hope, fear, &c., as there are kinds of objects whereby we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are affected.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Pleasure and pain, and consequently the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compounded thereof, or derived therefrom, are passions, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive states (III. xi. note); now we are necessarily passive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. i.), in so far as we have inadequate ideas; and only in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as we have such ideas are we passive (III. iii.); that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are only necessarily passive (II. xl. note), in so far as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive, or (II. xvii. and note) in so far as we are affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an emotion, which involves the nature of our own body, and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of an external body.  Wherefore the nature of every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive state must necessarily be so explained, that the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the object whereby we are affected be expressed.  Namely, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, which arises from, say, the object A, involves the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of that object A, and the pleasure, which arises from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object B, involves the nature of the object B; wherefore these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two pleasurable emotions are by nature different, inasmuch as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes whence they arise are by nature different.  So again the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of pain, which arises from one object, is by nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from the pain arising from another object, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: similarly, in the case of love, hatred, hope, fear, vacillation,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus, there are necessarily as many kinds of pleasure, pain,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, hatred, &c., as there are kinds of objects whereby we are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected.  Now desire is each man's essence or nature, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as it is conceived as determined to a particular action by any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given modification of itself (III. ix. note); therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according as a man is affected through external causes by this or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that kind of pleasure, pain, love, hatred, &c., in other words,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according as his nature is disposed in this or that manner, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will his desire be of one kind or another, and the nature of one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire must necessarily differ from the nature of another desire,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as widely as the emotions differ, wherefrom each desire arose.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus there are as many kinds of desire, as there are kinds of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, pain, love, &c., consequently (by what has been shown)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there are as many kinds of desire, as there are kinds of objects
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby we are affected.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Among the kinds of emotions, which, by the last
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition, must be very numerous, the chief are luxury,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: drunkenness, lust, avarice, and ambition, being merely species of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love or desire, displaying the nature of those emotions in a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner varying according to the object, with which they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerned.  For by luxury, drunkenness, lust, avarice, ambition,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &c., we simply mean the immoderate love of feasting, drinking,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: venery, riches, and fame.  Furthermore, these emotions, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we distinguish them from others merely by the objects
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherewith they are concerned, have no contraries.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: temperance, sobriety, and chastity, which we are wont to oppose
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to luxury, drunkenness, and lust, are not emotions or passive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states, but indicate a power of the mind which moderates the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last--named emotions.  However, I cannot here explain the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remaining kinds of emotions (seeing that they are as numerous as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the kinds of objects), nor, if I could, would it be necessary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is sufficient for our purpose, namely, to determine the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength of the emotions, and the mind's power over them, to have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a general definition of each emotion.  It is sufficient, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repeat, to understand the general properties of the emotions and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, to enable us to determine the quality and extent of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind's power in moderating and checking the emotions.  Thus,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though there is a great difference between various emotions of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, hatred, or desire, for instance between love felt towards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: children, and love felt towards a wife, there is no need for us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to take cognizance of such differences, or to track out further
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature and origin of the emotions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LVII.  Any emotion of a given individual differs from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of another individual, only in so far as the essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the one individual differs from the essence of the other.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is evident from Ax. i. (which see
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after Lemma iii. Prop. xiii., Part II.).  Nevertheless, we will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prove it from the nature of the three primary emotions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: All emotions are attributable to desire, pleasure, or pain,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as their definitions above given show.  But desire is each man's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature or essence (III. ix. note); therefore desire in one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual differs from desire in another individual, only in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as the nature or essence of the one differs from the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or essence of the other.  Again, pleasure and pain are passive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states or passions, whereby every man's power or endeavour to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persist in his being is increased or diminished, helped or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hindered (III. xi. and note).  But by the endeavour to persist in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its being, in so far as it is attributable to mind and body in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conjunction, we mean appetite and desire (III. ix. note);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore pleasure and pain are identical with desire or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appetite, in so far as by external causes they are increased or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished, helped or hindered, in other words, they are every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's nature; wherefore the pleasure and pain felt by one man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differ from the pleasure and pain felt by another man, only in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as the nature or essence of the one man differs from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of the other; consequently, any emotion of one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual only differs, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Hence it follows, that the emotions of the animals
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are called irrational (for after learning the origin of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind we cannot doubt that brutes feel) only differ from man's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, to the extent that brute nature differs from human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature.  Horse and man are alike carried away by the desire of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: procreation; but the desire of the former is equine, the desire
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the latter is human.  So also the lusts and appetites of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insects, fishes, and birds must needs vary according to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: several natures.  Thus, although each individual lives content
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and rejoices in that nature belonging to him wherein he has his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being, yet the life, wherein each is content and rejoices, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing else but the idea, or soul, of the said individual, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hence the joy of one only differs in nature from the joy of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, to the extent that the essence of one differs from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of another.  Lastly, it follows from the foregoing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition, that there is no small difference between the joy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which actuates, say, a drunkard, and the joy possessed by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: philosopher, as I just mention here by the way.  Thus far I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treated of the emotions attributable to man, in so far as he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive.  It remains to add a few words on those attributable to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him in so far as he is active.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LVIII.  Besides pleasure and desire, which are passivities
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or passions, there are other emotions derived from pleasure and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire, which are attributable to us in so far as we are active.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--When the mind conceives itself and its power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity, it feels pleasure (III. liii.): now the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily contemplates itself, when it conceives a true or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate idea (II. xliii.).  But the mind does conceive certain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas (II. xl. note 2.).  Therefore it feels pleasure in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as it conceives adequate ideas; that is, in so far as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is active (III. i.).  Again, the mind, both in so far as it has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clear and distinct ideas, and in so far as it has confused ideas,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours to persist in its own being (III. ix.); but by such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an endeavour we mean desire (by the note to the same Prop.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, desire is also attributable to us, in so far as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand, or (III. i.) in so far as we are active.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LIX.  Among all the emotions attributable to the mind as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: active, there are none which cannot be referred to pleasure or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All emotions can be referred to desire, pleasure, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, as their definitions, already given, show.  Now by pain we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean that the mind's power of thinking is diminished or checked
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xi. and note); therefore, in so far as the mind feels
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, its power of understanding, that is, of activity, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished or checked (III. i.); therefore, no painful emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be attributed to the mind in virtue of its being active, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only emotions of pleasure and desire, which (by the last Prop.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are attributable to the mind in that condition.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--All actions following from emotion, which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributable to the mind in virtue of its understanding, I set
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down to strength of character (fortitudo), which I divide into
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: courage (animositas) and highmindedness (generositas).  By
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: courage I mean the desire whereby every man strives to preserve
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own being in accordance solely with the dictates of reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: By highmindedness I mean the desire whereby every man endeavours,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely under the dictates of reason, to aid other men and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unite them to himself in friendship.  Those actions, therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which have regard solely to the good of the agent I set down to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: courage, those which aim at the good of others I set down to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highmindedness.  Thus temperance, sobriety, and presence of mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in danger, &c., are varieties of courage; courtesy, mercy, &c.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are varieties of highmindedness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I think I have thus explained, and displayed through their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: primary causes the principal emotions and vacillations of spirit,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which arise from the combination of the three primary emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to wit, desire, pleasure, and pain.  It is evident from what I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said, that we are in many ways driven about by external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes, and that like waves of the sea driven by contrary winds
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we toss to and fro unwitting of the issue and of our fate.  But I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said, that I have only set forth the chief conflicting
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, not all that might be given.  For, by proceeding in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same way as above, we can easily show that love is united to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repentance, scorn, shame, &c.  I think everyone will agree from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what has been said, that the emotions may be compounded one with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another in so many ways, and so many variations may arise
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom, as to exceed all possibility of computation.  However,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for my purpose, it is enough to have enumerated the most
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: important; to reckon up the rest which I have omitted would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more curious than profitable.  It remains to remark concerning
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, that it very often happens that while we are enjoying a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing which we longed for, the body, from the act of enjoyment,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquires a new disposition, whereby it is determined in another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way, other images of things are aroused in it, and the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: begins to conceive and desire something fresh.  For example, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we conceive something which generally delights us with its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: flavour, we desire to enjoy, that is, to eat it.  But whilst we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are thus enjoying it, the stomach is filled and the body is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: otherwise disposed.  If, therefore, when the body is thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: otherwise disposed, the image of the food which is present be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stimulated, and consequently the endeavour or desire to eat it be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stimulated also, the new disposition of the body will feel
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repugnance to the desire or attempt, and consequently the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: presence of the food which we formerly longed for will become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: odious.  This revulsion of feeling is called satiety or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: weariness.  For the rest, I have neglected the outward
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of the body observable in emotions, such, for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, as trembling, pallor, sobbing, laughter, &c., for these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are attributable to the body only, without any reference to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind.  Lastly, the definitions of the emotions require to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supplemented in a few points; I will therefore repeat them,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpolating such observations as I think should here and there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be added.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITIONS OF THE EMOTIONS
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  Desire is the actual essence of man, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived, as determined to a particular activity by some given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification of itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation.--We have said above, in the note to Prop. ix. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this part, that desire is appetite, with consciousness thereof;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further, that appetite is the essence of man, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to act in a way tending to promote its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persistence.  But, in the same note, I also remarked that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strictly speaking, I recognize no distinction between appetite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and desire.  For whether a man be conscious of his appetite or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not, it remains one and the same appetite.  Thus, in order to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avoid the appearance of tautology, I have refrained from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explaining desire by appetite; but I have take care to define it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in such a manner, as to comprehend, under one head, all those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours of human nature, which we distinguish by the terms
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appetite, will, desire, or impulse.  I might, indeed, have said,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that desire is the essence of man, in so far as it is conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as determined to a particular activity; but from such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition (cf. II. xxiii.) it would not follow that the mind can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be conscious of its desire or appetite.  Therefore, in order to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imply the cause of such consciousness, it was necessary to add,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it is determined by some given modification, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For, by a modification of man's essence, we understand every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition of the said essence, whether such disposition be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: innate, or whether it be conceived solely under the attribute of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought, or solely under the attribute of extension, or whether,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lastly, it be referred simultaneously to both these attributes.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: By the term desire, then, I here mean all man's endeavours,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impulses, appetites, and volitions, which vary according to each
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's disposition, and are, therefore, not seldom opposed one to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, according as a man is drawn in different directions, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knows not where to turn.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  Pleasure is the transition of a man from a less to a greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  Pain is the transition of a man from a greater to a less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--I say transition: for pleasure is not perfection
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself.  For, if man were born with the perfection to which he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passes, he would possess the same, without the emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure.  This appears more clearly from the consideration of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the contrary emotion, pain.  No one can deny, that pain consists
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the transition to a less perfection, and not in the less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection itself: for a man cannot be pained, in so far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: partakes of perfection of any degree.  Neither can we say, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain consists in the absence of a greater perfection.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absence is nothing, whereas the emotion of pain is an activity;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore this activity can only be the activity of transition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from a greater to a less perfection--in other words, it is an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity whereby a man's power of action is lessened or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constrained (cf. III. xi. note).  I pass over the definitions of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merriment, stimulation, melancholy, and grief, because these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: terms are generally used in reference to the body, and are merely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kinds of pleasure or pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  Wonder is the conception (imaginatio) of anything, wherein
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind comes to a stand, because the particular concept in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: question has no connection with other concepts (cf. III. lii. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--In the note to II. xviii. we showed the reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: why the mind, from the contemplation of one thing, straightway
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: falls to the contemplation of another thing, namely, because the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: images of the two things are so associated and arranged, that one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows the other.  This state of association is impossible, if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the image of the thing be new; the mind will then be at a stand
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the contemplation thereof, until it is determined by other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes to think of something else.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus the conception of a new object, considered in itself, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the same nature as other conceptions; hence, I do not include
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wonder among the emotions, nor do I see why I should so include
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, inasmuch as this distraction of the mind arises from no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positive cause drawing away the mind from other objects, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely from the absence of a cause, which should determine the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind to pass from the contemplation of one object to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation of another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I, therefore, recognize only three primitive or primary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions (as I said in the note to III. xi.), namely, pleasure,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, and desire.  I have spoken of wonder simply because it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: customary to speak of certain emotions springing from the three
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: primitive ones by different names, when they are referred to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects of our wonder.  I am led by the same motive to add a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of contempt.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  Contempt is the conception of anything which touches the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so little, that its presence leads the mind to imagine those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: qualities which are not in it rather than such as are in it (cf.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. lii. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The definitions of veneration and scorn I here pass over, for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I am not aware that any emotions are named after them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI.  Love is pleasure, accompanied by the idea of an external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--This definition explains sufficiently clearly the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of love; the definition given by those authors who say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that love is the lover's wish to unite himself to the loved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object expresses a property, but not the essence of love; and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as such authors have not sufficiently discerned love's essence,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have been unable to acquire a true conception of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: properties, accordingly their definition is on all hands admitted
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be very obscure.  It must, however, be noted, that when I say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it is a property of love, that the lover should wish to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unite himself to the beloved object, I do not here mean by wish
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consent, or conclusion, or a free decision of the mind (for I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have shown such, in II. xlviii., to be fictitious); neither do I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean a desire of being united to the loved object when it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absent, or of continuing in its presence when it is at hand; for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love can be conceived without either of these desires; but by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wish I mean the contentment, which is in the lover, on account of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the presence of the beloved object, whereby the pleasure of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lover is strengthened, or at least maintained.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VII.  Hatred is pain, accompanied by the idea of an external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--These observations are easily grasped after what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has been said in the explanation of the preceding definition (cf.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also III. xiii. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VIII.  Inclination is pleasure, accompanied by the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something which is accidentally a cause of pleasure.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IX.  Aversion is pain, accompanied by the idea of something which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is accidentally the cause of pain (cf. III. xv. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: X.  Devotion is love towards one whom we admire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Wonder (admiratio) arises (as we have shown, III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lii.) from the novelty of a thing.  If, therefore, it happens
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the object of our wonder is often conceived by us, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cease to wonder at it; thus we see, that the emotion of devotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readily degenerates into simple love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XI.  Derision is pleasure arising from our conceiving the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: presence of a quality, which we despise, in an object which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hate.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--In so far as we despise a thing which we hate, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deny existence thereof (III. lii. note), and to that extent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rejoice (III. xx.).  But since we assume that man hates that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he derides, it follows that the pleasure in question is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without alloy (cf. III. xlvii. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XII.  Hope is an inconstant pleasure, arising from the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something past or future, whereof we to a certain extent doubt
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the issue.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIII.  Fear is an inconstant pain arising from the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something past or future, whereof we to a certain extent doubt
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the issue (cf. III. xviii. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--From these definitions it follows, that there is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no hope unmingled with fear, and no fear unmingled with hope.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For he, who depends on hope and doubts concerning the issue of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything, is assumed to conceive something, which excludes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of the said thing in the future; therefore he, to this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extent, feels pain (cf. III. xix.); consequently, while
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dependent on hope, he fears for the issue.  Contrariwise he, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fears, in other words doubts, concerning the issue of something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he hates, also conceives something which excludes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of the thing in question; to this extent he feels
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, and consequently to this extent he hopes that it will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: turn out as he desires (III. xx.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIV.  Confidence is pleasure arising from the idea of something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: past or future, wherefrom all cause of doubt has been removed.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XV.  Despair is pain arising from the idea of something past or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future, wherefrom all cause of doubt has been removed.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Thus confidence springs from hope, and despair
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from fear, when all cause for doubt as to the issue of an event
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has been removed: this comes to pass, because man conceives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something past or future as present and regards it as such, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else because he conceives other things, which exclude the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of the causes of his doubt.  For, although we can never
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be absolutely certain of the issue of any particular event (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxi. Coroll.), it may nevertheless happen that we feel no doubt
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning it.  For we have shown, that to feel no doubt
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning a thing is not the same as to be quite certain of it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xlix. note).  Thus it may happen that we are affected by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same emotion of pleasure or pain concerning a thing past or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future, as concerning the conception of a thing present; this I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have already shown in III. xviii., to which, with its note, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: refer the reader.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVI.  Joy is pleasure accompanied by the idea of something past,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which has had an issue beyond our hope.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVII.  Disappointment is pain accompanied by the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something past, which has had an issue contrary to our hope.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVIII.  Pity is pain accompanied by the idea of evil, which has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: befallen someone else whom we conceive to be like ourselves (cf.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. xxii. note, and III. xxvii. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Between pity and sympathy (misericordia) there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seems to be no difference, unless perhaps that the former term is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: used in reference to a particular action, and the latter in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reference to a disposition.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIX.  Approval is love towards one who has done good to another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XX.  Indignation is hatred towards one who has done evil to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--I am aware that these terms are employed in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: senses somewhat different from those usually assigned.  But my
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: purpose is to explain, not the meaning of words, but the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things.  I therefore make use of such terms, as may convey my
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meaning without any violent departure from their ordinary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: signification.  One statement of my method will suffice. As for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the cause of the above--named emotions see III. xxvii. Coroll. i.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and III. xxii. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXI.  Partiality is thinking too highly of anyone because of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love we bear him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXII.  Disparagement is thinking too meanly of anyone because we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hate him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Thus partiality is an effect of love, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disparagement an effect of hatred: so that partiality may also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be defined as love, in so far as it induces a man to think too
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highly of a beloved object.  Contrariwise, disparagement may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: defined as hatred, in so far as it induces a man to think too
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meanly of a hated object.  Cf. III. xxvi. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIII.  Envy is hatred, in so far as it induces a man to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pained by another's good fortune, and to rejoice in another's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil fortune.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Envy is generally opposed to sympathy, which, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doing some violence to the meaning of the word, may therefore be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus defined:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIV.  Sympathy (misericordia) is love, in so far as it induces a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man to feel pleasure at another's good fortune, and pain at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another's evil fortune.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Concerning envy see the notes to III. xxiv. and
