title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxii.  These emotions also arise from pleasure or pain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of something external, as cause either in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself or accidentally.  I now pass on to other emotions, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are accompanied by the idea of something within as a cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXV.  Self--approval is pleasure arising from a man's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation of himself and his own power of action.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVI.  Humility is pain arising from a man's contemplation of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own weakness of body or mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Self--complacency is opposed to humility, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as we thereby mean pleasure arising from a contemplation of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our own power of action; but, in so far as we mean thereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure accompanied by the idea of any action which we believe
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we have performed by the free decision of our mind, it is opposed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to repentance, which we may thus define:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVII.  Repentance is pain accompanied by the idea of some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action, which we believe we have performed by the free decision
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of our mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--The causes of these emotions we have set forth in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. li. note, and in III. liii., liv., lv. and note.  Concerning
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the free decision of the mind see II. xxxv. note.  This is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perhaps the place to call attention to the fact, that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing wonderful that all those actions, which are commonly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called wrong, are followed by pain, and all those, which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called right, are followed by pleasure.  We can easily gather
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from what has been said, that this depends in great measure on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: education.  Parents, by reprobating the former class of actions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and by frequently chiding their children because of them, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also by persuading to and praising the latter class, have brought
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it about, that the former should be associated with pain and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter with pleasure.  This is confirmed by experience.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: custom and religion are not the same among all men, but that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which some consider sacred others consider profane, and what some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consider honourable others consider disgraceful.  According as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each man has been educated, he feels repentance for a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action or glories therein.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVIII.  Pride is thinking too highly of one's self from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Thus pride is different from partiality, for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter term is used in reference to an external object, but pride
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is used of a man thinking too highly of himself.  However, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: partiality is the effect of love, so is pride the effect or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: property of self--love, which may therefore be thus defined, love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of self or self--approval, in so far as it leads a man to think
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: too highly of himself.  To this emotion there is no contrary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For no one thinks too meanly of himself because of self--hatred;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I say that no one thinks too meanly of himself, in so far as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives that he is incapable of doing this or that.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever a man imagines that he is incapable of doing, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagines this of necessity, and by that notion he is so disposed,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he really cannot do that which he conceives that he cannot
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do.  For, so long as he conceives that he cannot do it, so long
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is he not determined to do it, and consequently so long is it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible for him to do it.  However, if we consider such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matters as only depend on opinion, we shall find it conceivable
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a man may think too meanly of himself; for it may happen,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a man, sorrowfully regarding his own weakness, should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagine that he is despised by all men, while the rest of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: world are thinking of nothing less than of despising him.  Again,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man may think too meanly of himself, if he deny of himself in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the present something in relation to a future time of which he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uncertain.  As, for instance, if he should say that he is unable
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to form any clear conceptions, or that he can desire and do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing but what is wicked and base, &c.  We may also say, that a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man thinks too meanly of himself, when we see him from excessive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear of shame refusing to do things which others, his equals,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: venture.  We can, therefore, set down as a contrary to pride an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion which I will call self--abasement, for as from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--complacency springs pride, so from humility springs
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--abasement, which I will accordingly thus define:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIX.  Self--abasement is thinking too meanly of one's self by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason of pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--We are nevertheless generally accustomed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: oppose pride to humility, but in that case we pay more attention
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the effect of either emotion than to its nature.  We are wont
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to call proud the man who boasts too much (III. xxx. note), who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: talks of nothing but his own virtues and other people's faults,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who wishes to be first; and lastly who goes through life with a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: style and pomp suitable to those far above him in station.  On
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other hand, we call humble the man who too often blushes, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confesses his faults, who sets forth other men's virtues, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who, lastly, walks with bent head and is negligent of his attire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, these emotions, humility and self--abasement, are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extremely rare.  For human nature, considered in itself, strives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against them as much as it can (see III. xiii., liv.); hence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those, who are believed to be most self--abased and humble, are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generally in reality the most ambitious and envious.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXX.  Honour[11] is pleasure accompanied by the idea of some action
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of our own, which we believe to be praised by others.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [11] Gloria.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXI.  Shame is pain accompanied by the idea of some action of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our own, which we believe to be blamed by others.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--On this subject see the note to III. xxx.  But we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should here remark the difference which exists between shame and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modesty.  Shame is the pain following the deed whereof we are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ashamed.  Modesty is the fear or dread of shame, which restrains
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man from committing a base action.  Modesty is usually opposed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to shamelessness, but the latter is not an emotion, as I will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: duly show; however, the names of the emotions (as I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remarked already) have regard rather to their exercise than to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have now fulfilled the task of explaining the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arising from pleasure and pain.  I therefore proceed to treat of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those which I refer to desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXII.  Regret is the desire or appetite to possess something,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kept alive by the remembrance of the said thing, and at the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time constrained by the remembrance of other things which exclude
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the existence of it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--When we remember a thing, we are by that very
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, as I have already said more than once, disposed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplate it with the same emotion as if it were something
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present; but this disposition or endeavour, while we are awake,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is generally checked by the images of things which exclude the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of that which we remember.  Thus when we remember
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something which affected us with a certain pleasure, we by that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very fact endeavour to regard it with the same emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure as though it were present, but this endeavour is at once
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: checked by the remembrance of things which exclude the existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the thing in question.  Wherefore regret is, strictly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speaking, a pain opposed to that of pleasure, which arises from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the absence of something we hate (cf. III. xlvii. note).  But, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the name regret seems to refer to desire, I set this emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down, among the emotions springing from desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXIII.  Emulation is the desire of something, engendered in us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by our conception that others have the same desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--He who runs away, because he sees others running
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: away, or he who fears, because he sees others in fear; or again,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he who, on seeing that another man has burnt his hand, draws
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards him his own hand, and moves his body as though his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were burnt; such an one can be said to imitate another's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion, but not to emulate him; not because the causes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emulation and imitation are different, but because it has become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: customary to speak of emulation only in him, who imitates that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we deem to be honourable, useful, or pleasant.  As to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of emulation, cf. III. xxvii. and note.  The reason why
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this emotion is generally coupled with envy may be seen from III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxii. and note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXIV.  Thankfulness or Gratitude is the desire or zeal springing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from love, whereby we endeavour to benefit him, who with similar
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feelings of love has conferred a benefit on us.  Cf. III. xxxix.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note and xl.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXV.  Benevolence is the desire of benefiting one whom we pity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Cf. III. xxvii. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXVI.  Anger is the desire, whereby through hatred we are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: induced to injure one whom we hate, III. xxxix.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXVII.  Revenge is the desire whereby we are induced, through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mutual hatred, to injure one who, with similar feelings, has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injured us.  (See III. xl. Coroll. ii and note.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXVIII.  Cruelty or savageness is the desire, whereby a man is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impelled to injure one whom we love or pity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--To cruelty is opposed clemency, which is not a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive state of the mind, but a power whereby man restrains his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anger and revenge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXIX.  Timidity is the desire to avoid a greater evil, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dread, by undergoing a lesser evil.  Cf. III. xxxix. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XL.  Daring is the desire, whereby a man is set on to do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something dangerous which his equals fear to attempt.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLI.  Cowardice is attributed to one, whose desire is checked by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fear of some danger which his equals dare to encounter.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Cowardice is, therefore, nothing else but the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear of some evil, which most men are wont not to fear; hence I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do not reckon it among the emotions springing from desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nevertheless, I have chosen to explain it here, because, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as we look to the desire, it is truly opposed to the emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of daring.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLII.  Consternation is attributed to one, whose desire of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avoiding evil is checked by amazement at the evil which he fears.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Consternation is, therefore, a species of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cowardice.  But, inasmuch as consternation arises from a double
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear, it may be more conveniently defined as a fear which keeps a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man so bewildered and wavering, that he is not able to remove the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil.  I say bewildered, in so far as we understand his desire of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: removing the evil to be constrained by his amazement.  I say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wavering, in so far as we understand the said desire to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constrained by the fear of another evil, which equally torments
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him: whence it comes to pass that he knows not, which he may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avert of the two.  On this subject, see III. xxxix. note, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. lii. note.  Concerning cowardice and daring, see III. li.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLIII.  Courtesy, or deference (Humanitas seu modestia), is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire of acting in a way that should please men, and refraining
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from that which should displease them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLIV.  Ambition is the immoderate desire of power.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Ambition is the desire, whereby all the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (cf. III. xxvii. and xxxi.) are fostered and strengthened;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore this emotion can with difficulty be overcome.  For, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as a man is bound by any desire, he is at the same time
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily bound by this.  "The best men," says Cicero, "are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially led by honour.  Even philosophers, when they write a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: book contemning honour, sign their names thereto," and so on.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLV.  Luxury is excessive desire, or even love of living
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sumptuously.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLVI.  Intemperance is the excessive desire and love of drinking.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLVII.  Avarice is the excessive desire and love of riches.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XLVIII.  Lust is desire and love in the matter of sexual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intercourse.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--Whether this desire be excessive or not, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: still called lust.  These last five emotions (as I have shown in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. lvi.) have on contraries.  For deference is a species of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ambition.  Cf. III. xxix. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, I have already pointed out, that temperance, sobriety,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and chastity indicate rather a power than a passivity of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind.  It may, nevertheless, happen, that an avaricious, an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ambitious, or a timid man may abstain from excess in eating,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: drinking, or sexual indulgence, yet avarice, ambition, and fear
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are not contraries to luxury, drunkenness, and debauchery.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an avaricious man often is glad to gorge himself with food and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: drink at another man's expense.  An ambitious man will restrain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself in nothing, so long as he thinks his indulgences are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secret; and if he lives among drunkards and debauchees, he will,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the mere fact of being ambitious, be more prone to those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vices.  Lastly, a timid man does that which he would not.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though an avaricious man should, for the sake of avoiding death,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cast his riches into the sea, he will none the less remain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avaricious; so, also, if a lustful man is downcast, because he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot follow his bent, he does not, on the ground of abstention,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cease to be lustful.  In fact, these emotions are not so much
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerned with the actual feasting, drinking, &c., as with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appetite and love of such.  Nothing, therefore, can be opposed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these emotions, but high--mindedness and valour, whereof I will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speak presently.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The definitions of jealousy and other waverings of the mind I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pass over in silence, first, because they arise from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compounding of the emotions already described; secondly, because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many of them have no distinctive names, which shows that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sufficient for practical purposes to have merely a general
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of them.  However, it is established from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definitions of the emotions, which we have set forth, that they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all spring from desire, pleasure, or pain, or, rather, that there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is nothing besides these three; wherefore each is wont to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called by a variety of names in accordance with its various
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: relations and extrinsic tokens.  If we now direct our attention
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to these primitive emotions, and to what has been said concerning
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of the mind, we shall be able thus to define the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, in so far as they are referred to the mind only.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: GENERAL DEFINITION OF THE EMOTIONS
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Emotion, which is called a passivity of the soul, is a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confused idea, whereby the mind affirms concerning its body, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any part thereof, a force for existence (existendi vis) greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or less than before, and by the presence of which the mind is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to think of one thing rather than another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Explanation--I say, first, that emotion or passion of the soul
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a confused idea.  For we have shown that the mind is only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive, in so far as it has inadequate or confused ideas.  (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iii.)  I say, further, whereby the mind affirms concerning its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body or any part thereof a force for existence greater than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before.  For all the ideas of bodies, which we possess, denote
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather the actual disposition of our own body (II. xvi. Coroll.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ii.) than the nature of an external body.  But the idea which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitutes the reality of an emotion must denote or express the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition of the body, or of some part thereof, because its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of action or force for existence is increased or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished, helped or hindered.  But it must be noted that, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I say a greater or less force for existence than before, I do not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean that the mind compares the present with the past disposition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body, but that the idea which constitutes the reality of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an emotion affirms something of the body, which, in fact,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves more or less of reality than before.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: And inasmuch as the essence of mind consists in the fact (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xi., xiii.), that it affirms the actual existence of its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, and inasmuch as we understand by perfection the very
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of a thing, it follows that the mind passes to greater or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less perfection, when it happens to affirm concerning its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, or any part thereof, something involving more or less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality than before.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: When, therefore, I said above that the power of the mind is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increased or diminished, I merely meant that the mind had formed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its own body, or of some part thereof, an idea involving more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or less of reality, than it had already affirmed concerning its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own body.  For the excellence of ideas, and the actual power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking are measured by the excellence of the object.  Lastly, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have added by the presence of which the mind is determined to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think of one thing rather than another, so that, besides the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of pleasure and pain, which the first part of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition explains, I might also express the nature of desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PART IV:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Of Human Bondage, or the Strength of the Emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PREFACE
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Human infirmity in moderating and checking the emotions I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: name bondage: for, when a man is a prey to his emotions, he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not his own master, but lies at the mercy of fortune: so much
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so, that he is often compelled, while seeing that which is better
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for him, to follow that which is worse.  Why this is so, and what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is good or evil in the emotions, I propose to show in this part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of my treatise.  But, before I begin, it would be well to make a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: few prefatory observations on perfection and imperfection, good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and evil.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: When a man has purposed to make a given thing, and has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brought it to perfection, his work will be pronounced perfect,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not only by himself, but by everyone who rightly knows, or thinks
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he knows, the intention and aim of its author.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, suppose anyone sees a work (which I assume to be not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet completed), and knows that the aim of the author of that work
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is to build a house, he will call the work imperfect; he will,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the other hand, call it perfect, as soon as he sees that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: carried through to the end, which its author had purposed for it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But if a man sees a work, the like whereof he has never seen
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before, and if he knows not the intention of the artificer, he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plainly cannot know, whether that work be perfect or imperfect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such seems to be the primary meaning of these terms.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, after men began to form general ideas, to think out
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: types of houses, buildings, towers, &c., and to prefer certain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: types to others, it came about, that each man called perfect that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he saw agree with the general idea he had formed of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing in question, and called imperfect that which he saw agree
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less with his own preconceived type, even though it had evidently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been completed in accordance with the idea of its artificer.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This seems to be the only reason for calling natural phenomena,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which, indeed, are not made with human hands, perfect or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfect: for men are wont to form general ideas of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural, no less than of things artificial, and such ideas they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hold as types, believing that Nature (who they think does nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without an object) has them in view, and has set them as types
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before herself.  Therefore, when they behold something in Nature,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which does not wholly conform to the preconceived type which they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have formed of the thing in question, they say that Nature has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fallen short or has blundered, and has left her work incomplete.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus we see that men are wont to style natural phenomena perfect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or imperfect rather from their own prejudices, than from true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of what they pronounce upon.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now we showed in the Appendix to Part I., that Nature does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not work with an end in view.  For the eternal and infinite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Being, which we call God or Nature, acts by the same necessity as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that whereby it exists.  For we have shown, that by the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of its nature, whereby it exists, it likewise works (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvi.).  The reason or cause why God or Nature exists, and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason why he acts, are one and the same.  Therefore, as he does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not exist for the sake of an end, so neither does he act for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sake of an end; of his existence and of his action there is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither origin nor end.  Wherefore, a cause which is called final
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is nothing else but human desire, in so far as it is considered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the origin or cause of anything.  For example, when we say
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that to be inhabited is the final cause of this or that house, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean nothing more than that a man, conceiving the conveniences of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: household life, had a desire to build a house.  Wherefore, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being inhabited, in so far as it is regarded as a final cause, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing else but this particular desire, which is really the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: efficient cause; it is regarded as the primary cause, because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men are generally ignorant of the causes of their desires.  They
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are, as I have often said already, conscious of their own actions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and appetites, but ignorant of the causes whereby they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined to any particular desire.  Therefore, the common
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: saying that Nature sometimes falls short, or blunders, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: produces things which are imperfect, I set down among the glosses
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treated of in the Appendix to Part I.  Perfection and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperfection, then, are in reality merely modes of thinking, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notions which we form from a comparison among one another of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals of the same species; hence I said above (II. Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vi.), that by reality and perfection I mean the same thing.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are wont to refer all the individual things in nature to one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: genus, which is called the highest genus, namely, to the category
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Being, whereto absolutely all individuals in nature belong.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus, in so far as we refer the individuals in nature to this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: category, and comparing them one with another, find that some
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess more of being or reality than others, we, to this extent,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say that some are more perfect than others.  Again, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we attribute to them anything implying negation--as term, end,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infirmity, etc., we, to this extent, call them imperfect, because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they do not affect our mind so much as the things which we call
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect, not because they have any intrinsic deficiency, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because Nature has blundered.  For nothing lies within the scope
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a thing's nature, save that which follows from the necessity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the nature of its efficient cause, and whatsoever follows from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the necessity of the nature of its efficient cause necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comes to pass.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As for the terms good and bad, they indicate no positive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quality in things regarded in themselves, but are merely modes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking, or notions which we form from the comparison of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one with another.  Thus one and the same thing can be at the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time good, bad, and indifferent.  For instance, music is good for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him that is melancholy, bad for him that mourns; for him that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deaf, it is neither good nor bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nevertheless, though this be so, the terms should still be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retained.  For, inasmuch as we desire to form an idea of man as a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: type of human nature which we may hold in view, it will be useful
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for us to retain the terms in question, in the sense I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicated.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In what follows, then, I shall mean by, "good" that, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainly know to be a means of approaching more nearly to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: type of human nature, which we have set before ourselves; by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "bad," that which we certainly know to be a hindrance to us in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: approaching the said type.  Again, we shall that men are more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect, or more imperfect, in proportion as they approach more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or less nearly to the said type.  For it must be specially
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remarked that, when I say that a man passes from a lesser to a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater perfection, or vice versa, I do not mean that he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changed from one essence or reality to another; for instance, a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: horse would be as completely destroyed by being changed into a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, as by being changed into an insect.  What I mean is, that we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive the thing's power of action, in so far as this is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood by its nature, to be increased or diminished.  Lastly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by perfection in general I shall, as I have said, mean reality--in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, each thing's essence, in so far as it exists, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: operates in a particular manner, and without paying any regard to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its duration.  For no given thing can be said to be more perfect,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because it has passed a longer time in existence.  The duration
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things cannot be determined by their essence, for the essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things involves no fixed and definite period of existence;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but everything, whether it be more perfect or less perfect, will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always be able to persist in existence with the same force
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherewith it began to exist; wherefore, in this respect, all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things are equal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITIONS.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  By good I mean that which we certainly know to be useful to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  By evil I mean that which we certainly know to be a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hindrance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to us in the attainment of any good.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Concerning these terms see the foregoing preface towards the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: end.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  Particular things I call contingent in so far as, while
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarding their essence only, we find nothing therein, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily asserts their existence or excludes it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  Particular things I call possible in so far as, while
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarding the causes whereby they must be produced, we know not,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether such causes be determined for producing them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (In I. xxxiii. note. i., I drew no distinction between
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible and contingent, because there was in that place no need
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to distinguish them accurately.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  By conflicting emotions I mean those which draw a man in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different directions, though they are of the same kind, such as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: luxury and avarice, which are both species of love, and are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contraries, not by nature, but by accident.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI.  What I mean by emotion felt towards a thing, future,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present, and past, I explained in III. xviii., notes. i. and ii.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which see.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (But I should here also remark, that we can only distinctly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive distance of space or time up to a certain definite limit;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, all objects distant from us more than two hundred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feet, or whose distance from the place where we are exceeds that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we can distinctly conceive, seem to be an equal distance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from us, and all in the same plane; so also objects, whose time
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of existing is conceived as removed from the present by a longer
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interval than we can distinctly conceive, seem to be all equally
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distant from the present, and are set down, as it were, to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same moment of time.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VII.  By an end, for the sake of which we do something, I mean a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VIII.  By virtue (virtus) and power I mean the same thing; that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (III. vii), virtue, in so far as it is referred to man, is a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's nature or essence, in so far as it has the power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effecting what can only be understood by the laws of that nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOM.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: There is no individual thing in nature, than which there is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not another more powerful and strong.  Whatsoever thing be given,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is something stronger whereby it can be destroyed.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROPOSITIONS.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. I.  No positive quality possessed by a false idea is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: removed by the presence of what is true, in virtue of its being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Falsity consists solely in the privation of knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which inadequate ideas involve (II. xxxv.), nor have they any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positive quality on account of which they are called false (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxiii.); contrariwise, in so far as they are referred to God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are true (II. xxxii.).  Wherefore, if the positive quality
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessed by a false idea were removed by the presence of what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true, in virtue of its being true, a true idea would then be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: removed by itself, which (IV. iii.) is absurd.  Therefore, no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positive quality possessed by a false idea, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This proposition is more clearly understood from II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvi. Coroll. ii.  For imagination is an idea, which indicates
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather the present disposition of the human body than the nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the external body; not indeed distinctly, but confusedly;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whence it comes to pass, that the mind is said to err.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, when we look at the sun, we conceive that it is distant
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from us about two hundred feet; in this judgment we err, so long
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we are in ignorance of its true distance; when its true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distance is known, the error is removed, but not the imagination;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or, in other words, the idea of the sun, which only explains
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tho nature of that luminary, in so far as the body is affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereby: wherefore, though we know the real distance, we shall
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: still nevertheless imagine the sun to be near us.  For, as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said in II. xxxv. note, we do not imagine the sun to be so near
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, because we are ignorant of its true distance, but because the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind conceives the magnitude of the sun to the extent that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body is affected thereby.  Thus, when the rays of the sun falling
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the surface of water are reflected into our eyes, we imagine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sun as if it were in the water, though we are aware of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: real position; and similarly other imaginations, wherein the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind is deceived, whether they indicate the natural disposition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body, or that its power of activity is increased or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished, are not contrary to the truth, and do not vanish at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its presence.  It happens indeed that, when we mistakenly fear an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil, the fear vanishes when we hear the true tidings; but the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary also happens, namely, that we fear an evil which will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainly come, and our fear vanishes when we hear false tidings;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus imaginations do not vanish at the presence of the truth,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in virtue of its being true, but because other imaginations,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stronger than the first, supervene and exclude the present
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of that which we imagined, as I have shown in II. xvii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. II.  We are only passive, in so far as we are apart of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nature, which cannot be conceived by itself without other parts.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We are said to be passive, when something arises in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, whereof we are only a partial cause (III. Def. ii.), that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. Def. i.), something which cannot be deduced solely from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of our nature.  We are passive therefore, in so far as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are a part of Nature, which cannot be conceived by itself without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other parts.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. III.  The force whereby a man persists in existing is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: limited, and is infinitely surpassed by the power of external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is evident from the axiom of this part.  For,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when man is given, there is something else--say A--more powerful;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when A is given, there is something else--say B--more powerful than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: A, and so on to infinity; thus the power of man is limited by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of some other thing, and is infinitely surpassed by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of external causes.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IV.  It is impossible, that man should not be a part of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nature, or that he should be capable of undergoing no changes,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save such as can be understood through his nature only as their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The power, whereby each particular thing, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently man, preserves his being, is the power of God or of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nature (I. xxiv. Coroll.); not in so far as it is infinite, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it can be explained by the actual human essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. vii.).  Thus the power of man, in so far as it is explained
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through his own actual essence, is a part of the infinite power
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God or Nature, in other words, of the essence thereof (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxiv.).  This was our first point.  Again, if it were possible,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that man should undergo no changes save such as can be understood
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely through the nature of man, it would follow that he would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not be able to die, but would always necessarily exist; this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be the necessary consequence of a cause whose power was
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either finite or infinite; namely, either of man's power only,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as he would be capable of removing from himself all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changes which could spring from external causes; or of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite power of Nature, whereby all individual things would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so ordered, that man should be incapable of undergoing any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changes save such as tended towards his own preservation.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the first alternative is absurd (by the last Prop., the proof of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is universal, and can be applied to all individual things).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, if it be possible, that man should not be capable of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undergoing any changes, save such as can be explained solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through his own nature, and consequently that he must always (as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we have shown) necessarily exist; such a result must follow from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the infinite power of God, and consequently (I. xvi.) from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of the divine nature, in so far as it is regarded as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by the idea of any given man, the whole order of nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as conceived under the attributes of extension and thought must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be deducible.  It would therefore follow (I. xxi.) that man is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, which (by the first part of this proof) is absurd.  It
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, therefore, impossible, that man should not undergo any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changes save those whereof he is the adequate cause.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows, that man is necessarily always a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prey to his passions, that he follows and obeys the general order
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of nature, and that he accommodates himself thereto, as much as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of things demands.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. V.  The power and increase of every passion, and its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persistence in existing are not defined by the power, whereby we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves endeavour to persist in existing, but by the power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an external cause compared with our own.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The essence of a passion cannot be explained through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our essence alone (III. Deff. i. and ii.), that is (III. vii.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of a passion cannot be defined by the power, whereby we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves endeavour to persist in existing, but (as is shown in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. xvi.) must necessarily be defined by the power of an external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause compared with our own.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VI.  The force of any passion or emotion can overcome the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest of a man's activities or power, so that the emotion becomes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obstinately fixed to him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The force and increase of any passion and its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persistence in existing are defined by the power of an external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause compared with our own (by the foregoing Prop.); therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. iii.) it can overcome a man's power, &e.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VII.  An emotion can only be controlled or destroyed by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another emotion contrary thereto, and with more power for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: controlling emotion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Emotion, in so far as it is referred to the mind, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an idea, whereby the mind affirms of its body a greater or less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: force of existence than before (cf. the general Definition of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Emotions at the end of Part III.).  When, therefore, the mind is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assailed by any emotion, the body is at the same time affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with a modification whereby its power of activity is increased or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished.  Now this modification of the body (IV. v.) receives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from its cause the force for persistence in its being; which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: force can only be checked or destroyed by a bodily cause (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vi.), in virtue of the body being affected with a modification
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to (III. v.) and stronger than itself (IV. Ax.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore (II. xii.) the mind is affected by the idea of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification contrary to, and stronger than the former
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification, in other words, (by the general definition of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions) the mind will be affected by an emotion contrary to and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stronger than the former emotion, which will exclude or destroy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the existence of the former emotion; thus an emotion cannot be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed nor controlled except by a contrary and stronger
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--An emotion, in so far as it is referred to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, can only be controlled or destroyed through an idea of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification of the body contrary to, and stronger than, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we are undergoing.  For the emotion which we undergo can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only be checked or destroyed by an emotion contrary to, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stronger than, itself, in other words, (by the general Definition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Emotions) only by an idea of a modification of the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to, and stronger than, the modification which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undergo.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VIII.  The knowledge of good and evil is nothing else but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the emotions of pleasure or pain, in so far as we are conscious
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereof.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We call a thing good or evil, when it is of service or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the reverse in preserving our being (IV. Deff. i. and ii.), that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (III. vii.), when it increases or diminishes, helps or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hinders, our power of activity.  Thus, in so far as we perceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a thing affects us with pleasure or pain, we call it good or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil; wherefore the knowledge of good and evil is nothing else
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but the idea of the pleasure or pain, which necessarily follows
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from that pleasurable or painful emotion (II. xxii.).  But this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea is united to the emotion in the same way as mind is united
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to body (II. xxi.); that is, there is no real distinction
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: between this idea and the emotion or idea of the modification of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body, save in conception only.  Therefore the knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good and evil is nothing else but the emotion, in so far as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are conscious thereof.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IX.  An emotion, whereof we conceive the cause to be with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us at the present time, is stronger than if we did not conceive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the cause to be with us.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Imagination or conception is the idea, by which the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind regards a thing as present (II. xvii. note), but which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicates the disposition of the mind rather than the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the external thing (II. xvi. Coroll. ii.).  An emotion is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore a conception, in so far as it indicates the disposition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body.  But a conception (by II. xvii.) is stronger, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as we conceive nothing which excludes the present existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the external object; wherefore an emotion is also stronger or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more intense, when we conceive the cause to be with us at the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present time, than when we do not conceive the cause to be with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--When I said above in III. xviii. that we are affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the image of what is past or future with the same emotion as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if the thing conceived were present, I expressly stated, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this is only true in so far as we look solely to the image of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing in question itself; for the thing's nature is unchanged,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether we have conceived it or not; I did not deny that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: image becomes weaker, when we regard as present to us other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things which exclude the present existence of the future object:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I did not expressly call attention to the fact, because I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: purposed to treat of the strength of the emotions in this part of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: my work.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--The image of something past or future, that is, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a thing which we regard as in relation to time past or time
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future, to the exclusion of time present, is, when other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditions are equal, weaker than the image of something present;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently an emotion felt towards what is past or future is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less intense, other conditions being equal, than an emotion felt
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards something present.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. X.  Towards something future, which we conceive as close at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand, we are affected more intensely, than if we conceive that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its time for existence is separated from the present by a longer
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interval; so too by the remembrance of what we conceive to have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not long passed away we are affected more intensely, than if we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive that it has long passed away.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as we conceive a thing as close at hand, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not long passed away, we conceive that which excludes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: presence of the object less, than if its period of future
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence were more distant from the present, or if it had long
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passed away (this is obvious) therefore (by the foregoing Prop.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are, so far, more intensely affected towards it.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--From the remarks made in Def. vi. of this part it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows that, if objects are separated from the present by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longer period than we can define in conception, though their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dates of occurrence be widely separated one from the other, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all affect us equally faintly.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XI.  An emotion towards that which we conceive as necessary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, when other conditions are equal, more intense than an emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards that which possible, or contingent, or non--necessary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as we conceive a thing to be necessary, we,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to that extent, affirm its existence; on the other hand we deny
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a thing's existence, in so far as we conceive it not to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary (I. xxxiii. note. i.); wherefore (IV. ix.) an emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards that which is necessary is, other conditions being equal,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more intense than an emotion that which is non--necessary.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XII.  An emotion towards a thing, which we know not to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exist at the present time, and which we conceive as possible, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more intense, other conditions being equal, than an emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards a thing contingent.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as we conceive a thing as contingent, we are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by the conception of some further thing, which would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assert the existence of the former (IV. Def. iii.); but, on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other hand, we (by hypothesis) conceive certain things, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exclude its present existence.  But, in so far as we conceive a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing to be possible in the future, we there by conceive things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which assert its existence (IV. iv.), that is (III. xviii.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things which promote hope or fear: wherefore an emotion towards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something possible is more vehement.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--An emotion towards a thing, which we know not to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exist in the present, and which we conceive as contingent, is far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fainter, than if we conceive the thing to be present with us.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Emotion towards a thing, which we conceive to exist,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is more intense than it would be, if we conceived the thing as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future (IV. ix. Coroll.), and is much more vehement, than if the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future time be conceived as far distant from the present (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: x.).  Therefore an emotion towards a thing, whose period of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence we conceive to be far distant from the present, is far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fainter, than if we conceive the thing as present; it is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless, more intense, than if we conceived the thing as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent, wherefore an emotion towards a thing, which we regard
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as contingent, will be far fainter, than if we conceived the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing to be present with us.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIII.  Emotion towards a thing contingent, which we know
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not to exist in the present, is, other conditions being equal,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fainter than an emotion towards a thing past.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as we conceive a thing as contingent, we are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not affected by the image of any other thing, which asserts the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of the said thing (IV. Def. iii.), but, on the other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand (by hypothesis), we conceive certain things excluding its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present existence.  But, in so far as we conceive it in relation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to time past, we are assumed to conceive something, which recalls
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thing to memory, or excites the image thereof (II. xviii. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note), which is so far the same as regarding it as present (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii. Coroll.).  Therefore (IV. ix.) an emotion towards a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent, which we know does not exist in the present, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fainter, other conditions being equal, than an emotion towards a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing past.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIV.  A true knowledge of good and evil cannot check any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion by virtue of being true, but only in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considered as an emotion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--An emotion is an idea, whereby the mind affirms of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body a greater or less force of existing than before (by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general Definition of the Emotions); therefore it has no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positive quality, which can be destroyed by the presence of what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is true; consequently the knowledge of good and evil cannot, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue of being true, restrain any emotion.  But, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such knowledge is an emotion (IV. viii.) if it have more strength
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for restraining emotion, it will to that extent be able to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: restrain the given emotion.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XV.  Desire arising from the knowledge of good and bad can
title: Ethics
