author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be quenched or checked by many of the other desires arising from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the emotions whereby we are assailed.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--From the true knowledge of good and evil, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is an emotion, necessarily arises desire (Def. of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Emotions, i.), the strength of which is proportioned to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength of the emotion wherefrom it arises (III. xxxvii.).  But,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as this desire arises (by hypothesis) from the fact of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our truly understanding anything, it follows that it is also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present with us, in so far as we are active (III. i.), and must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore be understood through our essence only (III. Def. ii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently (III. vii.) its force and increase can be defined
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely by human power.  Again, the desires arising from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions whereby we are assailed are stronger, in proportion as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the said emotions are more vehement; wherefore their force and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increase must be defined solely by the power of external causes,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which, when compared with our own power, indefinitely surpass it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. iii.); hence the desires arising from like emotions may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more vehement, than the desire which arises from a true knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of good and evil, and may, consequently, control or quench it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVI.  Desire arising from the knowledge of good and evil,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as such knowledge regards what is future, may be more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily controlled or quenched, than the desire for what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agreeable at the present moment.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Emotion towards a thing, which we conceive as future,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is fainter than emotion towards a thing that is present (IV. ix.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.).  But desire, which arises from the true knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good and evil, though it be concerned with things which are good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at the moment, can be quenched or controlled by any headstrong
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire (by the last Prop., the proof whereof is of universal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: application).  Wherefore desire arising from such knowledge, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerned with the future, can be more easily controlled or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quenched, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVII.  Desire arising from the true knowledge of good and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil, in so far as such knowledge is concerned with what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contingent, can be controlled far more easily still, than desire
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for things that are present.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This Prop. is proved in the same way as the last Prop.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from IV. xii. Coroll.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--I think I have now shown the reason, why men are moved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by opinion more readily than by true reason, why it is that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true knowledge of good and evil stirs up conflicts in the soul,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and often yields to every kind of passion.  This state of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gave rise to the exclamation of the poet:[12]----
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "The better path I gaze at and approve,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The worse--I follow."
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [12] Ov. Met. vii.20, "Video meliora proboque, Deteriora sequor."
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ecclesiastes seems to have had the same thought in his mind,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when he says, "He who increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow."  I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have not written the above with the object of drawing the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusion, that ignorance is more excellent than knowledge, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a wise man is on a par with a fool in controlling his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, but because it is necessary to know the power and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infirmity of our nature, before we can determine what reason can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do in restraining the emotions, and what is beyond her power.  I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said, that in the present part I shall merely treat of human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infirmity.  The power of reason over the emotions I have settled
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to treat separately.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVIII.  Desire arising from pleasure is, other conditions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being equal, stronger than desire arising from pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Desire is the essence of a man (Def. of the Emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: i.), that is, the endeavour whereby a man endeavours to persist
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in his own being.  Wherefore desire arising from pleasure is, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fact of pleasure being felt, increased or helped; on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary, desire arising from pain is, by the fact of pain being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: felt, diminished or hindered; hence the force of desire arising
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from pleasure must be defined by human power together with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of an external cause, whereas desire arising from pain must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be defined by human power only.  Thus the former is the stronger
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the two.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--In these few remarks I have explained the causes of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human infirmity and inconstancy, and shown why men do not abide
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the precepts of reason.  It now remains for me to show what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: course is marked out for us by reason, which of the emotions are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in harmony with the rules of human reason, and which of them are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary thereto.  But, before I begin to prove my Propositions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in detailed geometrical fashion, it is advisable to sketch them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: briefly in advance, so that everyone may more readily grasp my
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meaning.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As reason makes no demands contrary to nature, it demands,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that every man should love himself, should seek that which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useful to him--I mean, that which is really useful to him, should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire everything which really brings man to greater perfection,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and should, each for himself, endeavour as far as he can to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve his own being.  This is as necessarily true, as that a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole is greater than its part.  (Cf. III. iv.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, as virtue is nothing else but action in accordance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the laws of one's own nature (IV. Def. viii.), and as no one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours to preserve his own being, except in accordance with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the laws of his own nature, it follows, first, that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foundation of virtue is the endeavour to preserve one's own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being, and that happiness consists in man's power of preserving
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own being; secondly, that virtue is to be desired for its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own sake, and that there is nothing more excellent or more useful
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to us, for the sake of which we should desire it; thirdly and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lastly, that suicides are weak--minded, and are overcome by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external causes repugnant to their nature.  Further, it follows
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from Postulate iv., Part II., that we can never arrive at doing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without all external things for the preservation of our being or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: living, so as to have no relations with things which are outside
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves.  Again, if we consider our mind, we see that our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect would be more imperfect, if mind were alone, and could
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand nothing besides itself.  There are, then, many things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: outside ourselves, which are useful to us, and are, therefore, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be desired.  Of such none can be discerned more excellent, than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those which are in entire agreement with our nature.  For if, for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: example, two individuals of entirely the same nature are united,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they form a combination twice as powerful as either of them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: singly.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, to man there is nothing more useful than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man--nothing, I repeat, more excellent for preserving their being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be wished for by men, than that all should so in all points
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree, that the minds and bodies of all should form, as it were,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one single mind and one single body, and that all should, with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one consent, as far as they are able, endeavour to preserve their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being, and all with one consent seek what is useful to them all.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hence, men who are governed by reason--that is, who seek what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useful to them in accordance with reason, desire for themselves
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing, which they do not also desire for the rest of mankind,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, consequently, are just, faithful, and honourable in their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conduct.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the dictates of reason, which I purposed thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: briefly to indicate, before beginning to prove them in greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: detail.  I have taken this course, in order, if possible, to gain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the attention of those who believe, that the principle that every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man is bound to seek what is useful for himself is the foundation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of impiety, rather than of piety and virtue.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, after briefly showing that the contrary is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case, I go on to prove it by the same method, as that whereby I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have hitherto proceeded.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIX.  Every man, by the laws of his nature, necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires or shrinks from that which he deems to be good or bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The knowledge of good and evil is (IV. viii.) the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of pleasure or pain, in so far as we are conscious
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereof; therefore, every man necessarily desires what he thinks
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good, and shrinks from what he thinks bad.  Now this appetite is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing else but man's nature or essence (Cf. the Definition of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Appetite, III. ix. note, and Def. of the Emotions, i.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, every man, solely by the laws of his nature, desires
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the one, and shrinks from the other, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XX.  The more every man endeavours, and is able to seek
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is useful to him--in other words, to preserve his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being--the more is he endowed with virtue; on the contrary, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as a man neglects to seek what is useful to him, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, to preserve his own being, he is wanting in power.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Virtue is human power, which is defined solely by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's essence (IV. Def. viii.), that is, which is defined solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the endeavour made by man to persist in his own being.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore, the more a man endeavours, and is able to preserve his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own being, the more is he endowed with virtue, and, consequently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. iv. and vi.), in so far as a man neglects to preserve his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own being, he is wanting in power.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--No one, therefore, neglects seeking his own good, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserving his own being, unless he be overcome by causes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external and foreign to his nature.  No one, I say, from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of his own nature, or otherwise than under compulsion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from external causes, shrinks from food, or kills himself: which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter may be done in a variety of ways.  A man, for instance,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kills himself under the compulsion of another man, who twists
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: round his right hand, wherewith he happened to have taken up a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sword, and forces him to turn the blade against his own heart;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or, again, he may be compelled, like Seneca, by a tyrant's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: command, to open his own veins--that is, to escape a greater evil
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by incurring, a lesser; or, lastly, latent external causes may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so disorder his imagination, and so affect his body, that it may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assume a nature contrary to its former one, and whereof the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot exist in the mind (III. x.) But that a man, from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of his own nature, should endeavour to become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: non--existent, is as impossible as that something should be made
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out of nothing, as everyone will see for himself, after a little
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reflection.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXI.  No one can desire to be blessed, to act rightly, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to live rightly, without at the same time wishing to be, act, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to live--in other words, to actually exist.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The proof of this proposition, or rather the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition itself, is self--evident, and is also plain from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of desire.  For the desire of living, acting, &c.,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedly or rightly, is (Def. of the Emotions, i.) the essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of man--that is (III. vii.), the endeavour made by everyone to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve his own being.  Therefore, no one can desire, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXII.  No virtue can be conceived as prior to this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to preserve one's own being.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The effort for self--preservation is the essence of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing (III. vii.); therefore, if any virtue could be conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as prior thereto, the essence of a thing would have to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived as prior to itself, which is obviously absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore no virtue, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--The effort for self--preservation is the first and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only foundation of virtue.  For prior to this principle nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be conceived, and without it no virtue can be conceived.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIII.  Man, in so far as he is determined to a particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action because he has inadequate ideas, cannot be absolutely said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to act in obedience to virtue; he can only be so described, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as he is determined for the action because he understands.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as a man is determined to an action through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: having inadequate ideas, he is passive (III. i.), that is (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Deff. i., and iii.), he does something, which cannot be perceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely through his essence, that is (by IV. Def. viii.), which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not follow from his virtue.  But, in so far as he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined for an action because he understands, he is active;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, he does something, which is perceived through his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence alone, or which adequately follows from his virtue.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIV.  To act absolutely in obedience to virtue is in us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same thing as to act, to live, or to preserve one's being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (these three terms are identical in meaning) in accordance with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the dictates of reason on the basis of seeking what is useful to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one's self.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--To act absolutely in obedience to virtue is nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else but to act according to the laws of one's own nature.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we only act, in so far as we understand (III. iii.): therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to act in obedience to virtue is in us nothing else but to act,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to live, or to preserve one's being in obedience to reason, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that on the basis of seeking what is useful for us (IV. xxii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXV.  No one wishes to preserve his being for the sake of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything else.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The endeavour, wherewith everything endeavours to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persist in its being, is defined solely by the essence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing itself (III. vii.); from this alone, and not from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of anything else, it necessarily follows (III. vi.) that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone endeavours to preserve his being.  Moreover, this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition is plain from IV. xxii. Coroll., for if a man should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to preserve his being for the sake of anything else,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the last--named thing would obviously be the basis of virtue,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which, by the foregoing corollary, is absurd.  Therefore no one,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVI.  Whatsoever we endeavour in obedience to reason is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing further than to understand; neither does the mind, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it makes use of reason, judge anything to be useful to it,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save such things as are conducive to understanding.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The effort for self--preservation is nothing else but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of the thing in question (III. vii.), which, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it exists such as it is, is conceived to have force for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continuing in existence (III. vi.) and doing such things as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follow from its given nature (see the Def. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Appetite, III. ix. note).  But the essence of reason is nought
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else but our mind, in so far as it clearly and distinctly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understands (see the definition in II. xl. note. ii.); therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xl.) whatsoever we endeavour in obedience to reason is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing else but to understand.  Again, since this effort of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind wherewith the mind endeavours, in so far as it reasons, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve its own being is nothing else but understanding; this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effort at understanding is (IV. xxii. Coroll.) the first and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: single basis of virtue, nor shall we endeavour to understand
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things for the sake of any ulterior object (IV. xxv.); on the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other hand, the mind, in so far as it reasons, will not be able
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to conceive any good for itself, save such things as are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conducive to understanding.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVII.  We know nothing to be certainly good or evil, save
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such things as really conduce to understanding, or such as are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: able to hinder us from understanding.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind, in so far as it reasons, desires nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beyond understanding, and judges nothing to be useful to itself,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save such things as conduce to understanding (by the foregoing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.).  But the mind (II. xli., xliii. and note) cannot possess
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainty concerning anything, except in so far as it has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas, or (what by II. xl. note, is the same thing) in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as it reasons.  Therefore we know nothing to be good or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil save such things as really conduce, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVIII.  The mind's highest good is the knowledge of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the mind's highest virtue is to know God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind is not capable of understanding anything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: higher than God, that is (I. Def. vi.), than a Being absolutely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, and without which (I. xv.) nothing can either be or be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived; therefore (IV. xxvi. and xxvii.), the mind's highest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: utility or (IV. Def. i.) good is the knowledge of God.  Again,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind is active, only in so far as it understands, and only to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same extent can it be said absolutely to act virtuously.  The
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind's absolute virtue is therefore to understand.  Now, as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have already shown, the highest that the mind can understand is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God; therefore the highest virtue of the mind is to understand
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or to know God.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIX.  No individual thing, which is entirely different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from our own nature, can help or check our power of activity, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely nothing can do us good or harm, unless it has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something in common with our nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The power of every individual thing, and consequently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of man, whereby he exists and operates, can only be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined by an individual thing (I. xxviii.), whose nature (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vi.) must be understood through the same nature as that, through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which human nature is conceived.  Therefore our power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activity, however it be conceived, can be determined and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently helped or hindered by the power of any other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual thing, which has something in common with us, but not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the power of anything, of which the nature is entirely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from our own; and since we call good or evil that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is the cause of pleasure or pain (IV. viii.), that is (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xi. note), which increases or diminishes, helps or hinders, our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of activity; therefore, that which is entirely different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from our nature can neither be to us good nor bad.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXX.  A thing cannot be bad for us through the quality
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it has in common with our nature, but it is bad for us in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as it is contrary to our nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We call a thing bad when it is the cause of pain (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: viii.), that is (by the Def., which see in III. xi. note), when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it diminishes or checks our power of action.  Therefore, if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything were bad for us through that quality which it has in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common with our nature, it would be able itself to diminish or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: check that which it has in common with our nature, which (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iv.) is absurd.  Wherefore nothing can be bad for us through that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quality which it has in common with us, but, on the other hand,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it is bad for us, that is (as we have just shown),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it can diminish or check our power of action, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to our nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXI.  In so far as a thing is in harmony with our nature,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is necessarily good.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as a thing is in harmony with our nature, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be bad for it.  It will therefore necessarily be either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good or indifferent.  If it be assumed that it be neither good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor bad, nothing will follow from its nature (IV. Def. i.), which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tends to the preservation of our nature, that is (by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hypothesis), which tends to the preservation of the thing itself;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but this (III. vi.) is absurd; therefore, in so far as a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in harmony with our nature, it is necessarily good.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows, that, in proportion as a thing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in harmony with our nature, so is it more useful or better for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, and vice versa, in proportion as a thing is more useful for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, so is it more in harmony with our nature.  For, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is not in harmony with our nature, it will necessarily be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different therefrom or contrary thereto.  If different, it can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither be good nor bad (IV. xxix.); if contrary, it will be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to that which is in harmony with our nature, that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to what is good--in short, bad.  Nothing, therefore, can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be good, except in so far as it is in harmony with our nature;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and hence a thing is useful, in proportion as it is in harmony
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with our nature, and vice versa.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXII.  In so far as men are a prey to passion, they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot, in that respect, be said to be naturally in harmony.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Things, which are said to be in harmony naturally, are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood to agree in power (III. vii.), not in want of power or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: negation, and consequently not in passion (III. iii. note);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore men, in so far as they are a prey to their passions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be said to be naturally in harmony.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This is also self--evident; for, if we say that white
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and black only agree in the fact that neither is red, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely affirm that the do not agree in any respect.  So, if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we say that a man and a stone only agree in the fact that both
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are finite--wanting in power, not existing by the necessity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their own nature, or, lastly, indefinitely surpassed by the power
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of external causes--we should certainly affirm that a man and a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stone are in no respect alike; therefore, things which agree
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only in negation, or in qualities which neither possess, really
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree in no respect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIII.  Men can differ in nature, in so far as they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assailed by those emotions, which are passions, or passive states;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to this extent one and the same man is variable and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inconstant.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The nature or essence of the emotions cannot be explained
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely through our essence or nature (III. Deff. i., ii.), but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it must be defined by the power, that is (III. vii.), by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of external causes in comparison with our own; hence it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows, that there are as many kinds of each emotion as there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are external objects whereby we are affected (III. lvi.), and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that men may be differently affected by one and the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object (III. li.), and to this extent differ in nature; lastly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that one and the same man may be differently affected towards
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same object, and may therefore be variable and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inconstant.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIV.  In so far as men are assailed by emotions which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passions, they can be contrary one to another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A man, for instance Peter, can be the cause of Paul's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feeling pain, because he (Peter) possesses something similar to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which Paul hates (III. xvi.), or because Peter has sole
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possession of a thing which Paul also loves (III. xxxii. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note), or for other causes (of which the chief are enumerated in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. lv. note); it may therefore happen that Paul should hate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Peter (Def. of Emotions, vii.), consequently it may easily happen
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also, that Peter should hate Paul in return, and that each should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to do the other an injury, (III. xxxix.), that is (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxx.), that they should be contrary one to another.  But the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of pain is always a passion or passive state (III. lix.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hence men, in so far as they are assailed by emotions which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passions, can be contrary one to another.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--I said that Paul may hate Peter, because he conceives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Peter possesses something which he (Paul) also loves; from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this it seems, at first sight, to follow, that these two men,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through both loving the same thing, and, consequently, through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agreement of their respective natures, stand in one another's way;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if this were so, Props. xxx. and xxxi. of this part would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: untrue.  But if we give the matter our unbiased attention, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall see that the discrepancy vanishes.  For the two men are not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in one another's way in virtue of the agreement of their natures,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, through both loving the same thing, but in virtue of one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differing from the other.  For, in so far as each loves the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing, the love of each is fostered thereby (III. xxxi.), that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def. of the Emotions, vi.) the pleasure of each is fostered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereby.  Wherefore it is far from being the case, that they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at variance through both loving the same thing, and through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agreement in their natures.  The cause for their opposition lies,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as I have said, solely in the fact that they are assumed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differ.  For we assume that Peter has the idea of the loved
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object as already in his possession, while Paul has the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the loved object as lost.  Hence the one man will be affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with pleasure, the other will be affected with pain, and thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they will be at variance one with another.  We can easily show in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like manner, that all other causes of hatred depend solely on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differences, and not on the agreement between men's natures.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXV.  In so far only as men live in obedience to reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do they always necessarily agree in nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as men are assailed by emotions that are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passions, they can be different in nature (IV. xxxiii.), and at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: variance one with another.  But men are only said to be active,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as they act in obedience to reason (III. iii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, what so ever follows from human nature in so far as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is defined by reason must (III. Def. ii.) be understood solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through human nature as its proximate cause.  But, since every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man by the laws of his nature desires that which he deems good,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and endeavours to remove that which he deems bad (IV. xix.); and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further, since that which we, in accordance with reason, deem
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good or bad, necessarily is good or bad (II. xli.); it follows
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that men, in so far as they live in obedience to reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily do only such things as are necessarily good for human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, and consequently for each individual man (IV. xxxi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.); in other words, such things as are in harmony with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each man's nature.  Therefore, men in so far as they live in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to reason, necessarily live always in harmony one with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--There is no individual thing in nature, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more useful to man, than a man who lives in obedience to reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For that thing is to man most useful, which is most in harmony
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with his nature (IV. xxxi. Coroll.); that is, obviously, man.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But man acts absolutely according to the laws of his nature, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he lives in obedience to reason (III. Def. ii.), and to this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extent only is always necessarily in harmony with the nature of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another man (by the last Prop.); wherefore among individual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things nothing is more useful to man, than a man who lives in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to reason.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--As every man seeks most that which is useful to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him, so are men most useful one to another.  For the more a man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seeks what is useful to him and endeavours to preserve himself,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the more is he endowed with virtue (IV. xx.), or, what is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same thing (IV. Def. viii.), the more is he endowed with power to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: act according to the laws of his own nature, that is to live in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to reason.  But men are most in natural harmony, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they live in obedience to reason (by the last Prop.); therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the foregoing Coroll.) men will be most useful one to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, when each seeks most that which is useful to him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--What we have just shown is attested by experience so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conspicuously, that it is in the mouth of nearly everyone: "Man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is to man a God."  Yet it rarely happens that men live in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to reason, for things are so ordered among them, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are generally envious and troublesome one to another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nevertheless they are scarcely able to lead a solitary life, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the definition of man as a social animal has met with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general assent; in fact, men do derive from social life much
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more convenience than injury.  Let satirists then laugh their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fill at human affairs, let theologians rail, and let misanthropes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: praise to their utmost the life of untutored rusticity, let them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heap contempt on men and praises on beasts; when all is said,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they will find that men can provide for their wants much more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily by mutual help, and that only by uniting their forces can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they escape from the dangers that on every side beset them: not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to say how much more excellent and worthy of our knowledge it is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to study the actions of men than the actions of beasts.  But I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will treat of this more at length elsewhere.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVI.  The highest good of those who follow virtue is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all, and therefore all can equally rejoice therein.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--To act virtuously is to act in obedience with reason
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. xxiv.), and whatsoever we endeavour to do in obedience to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason is to understand (IV. xxvi.); therefore (IV. xxviii.) the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest good for those who follow after virtue is to know God;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is (II. xlvii. and note) a good which is common to all and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can be possessed by all men equally, in so far as they are of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same nature.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Someone may ask how it would be, if the highest good of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who follow after virtue were not common to all?  Would it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not then follow, as above (IV. xxxiv.), that men living in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to reason, that is (IV. xxxv.), men in so far as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree in nature, would be at variance one with another?  To such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an inquiry, I make answer, that it follows not accidentally but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the very nature of reason, that main's highest good is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all, inasmuch as it is deduced from the very essence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, in so far as defined by reason; and that a man could
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither be, nor be conceived without the power of taking pleasure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in this highest good.  For it belongs to the essence of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind (II. xlvii.), to have an adequate knowledge of the eternal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and infinite essence of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVII.  The good which every man, who follows after
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue, desires for himself he will also desire for other men,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and so much the more, in proportion as he has a greater knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Men, in so far as they live in obedience to reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are most useful to their fellow men (IV. xxxv; Coroll. i.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (IV. xix.), we shall in obedience to reason necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to bring about that men should live in obedience to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason.  But the good which every man, in so far as he is guided
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by reason, or, in other words, follows after virtue, desires for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, is to understand (IV. xxvi.); wherefore the good, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each follower of virtue seeks for himself, he will desire also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for others.  Again, desire, in so far as it is referred to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, is the very essence of the mind (Def. of the Emotions, i.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now the essence of the mind consists in knowledge (II. xi.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which involves the knowledge of God (II. xlvii.), and without it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (I. xv.), can neither be, nor be conceived; therefore, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as the mind's essence involves a greater knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, so also will be greater the desire of the follower of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue, that other men should possess that which he seeks as good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for himself.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Another Proof.--The good, which a man desires for himself and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loves, he will love more constantly, if he sees that others love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it also (III. xxxi.); he will therefore endeavour that others
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should love it also; and as the good in question is common to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all, and therefore all can rejoice therein, he will endeavour,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the same reason, to bring about that all should rejoice
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein, and this he will do the more (III. xxxvii.), in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as his own enjoyment of the good is greater.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note I.--He who, guided by emotion only, endeavours to cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others to love what he loves himself, and to make the rest of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: world live according to his own fancy, acts solely by impulse,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and is, therefore, hateful, especially, to those who take delight
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in something different, and accordingly study and, by similar
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impulse, endeavour, to make men live in accordance with what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleases themselves.  Again, as the highest good sought by men
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the guidance of emotion is often such, that it can only be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessed by a single individual, it follows that those who love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it are not consistent in their intentions, but, while they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: delight to sing its praises, fear to be believed.  But he, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours to lead men by reason, does not act by impulse but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: courteously and kindly, and his intention is always consistent.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, whatsoever we desire and do, whereof we are the cause in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as we possess the idea of God, or know God, I set down to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Religion.  The desire of well--doing, which is engendered by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life according to reason, I call piety.  Further, the desire,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby a man living according to reason is bound to associate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others with himself in friendship, I call honour[13]; by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: honourable I mean that which is praised by men living according
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to reason, and by base I mean that which is repugnant to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gaining of friendship.  I have also shown in addition what are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the foundations of a state; and the difference between true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue and infirmity may be readily gathered from what I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said; namely, that true virtue is nothing else but living in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with reason; while infirmity is nothing else but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's allowing himself to be led by things which are external to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, and to be by them determined to act in a manner demanded
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the general disposition of things rather than by his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature considered solely in itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [13] Honestas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the matters which I engaged to prove in Prop. xviii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this Part, whereby it is plain that the law against the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: slaughtering of animals is founded rather on vain superstition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and womanish pity than on sound reason.  The rational quest of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is useful to us further teaches us the necessity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associating ourselves with our fellow men, but not with beasts,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or things, whose nature is different from our own; we have the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same rights in respect to them as they have in respect to us.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nay, as everyone's right is defined by his virtue, or power, men
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have far greater rights over beasts than beasts have over men.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Still I do not deny that beasts feel: what I deny is, that we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may not consult our own advantage and use them as we please,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treating them in the way which best suits us; for their nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not like ours, and their emotions are naturally different from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human emotions (III. lvii. note).  It remains for me to explain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what I mean by just and unjust, sin and merit.  On these points
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: see the following note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note II.--In the Appendix to Part I. I undertook to explain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: praise and blame, merit and sin, justice and injustice.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Concerning praise and blame I have spoken in III. xxix. note:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the time has now come to treat of the remaining terms.  But I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must first say a few words concerning man in the state of nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and in society.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Every man exists by sovereign natural right, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, by sovereign natural right performs those actions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which follow from the necessity of his own nature; therefore by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign natural right every man judges what is good and what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad, takes care of his own advantage according to his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition (IV. xix. and IV. xx.), avenges the wrongs done to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him (III. xl. Coroll. ii.), and endeavours to preserve that which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he loves and to destroy that which he hates (III. xxviii.).  Now,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if men lived under the guidance of reason, everyone would remain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in possession of this his right, without any injury being done to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his neighbour (IV. xxxv. Coroll. i.).  But seeing that they are a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prey to their emotions, which far surpass human power or virtue
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. vi.), they are often drawn in different directions, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being at variance one with another (IV. xxxiii. xxxiv.), stand in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need of mutual help (IV. xxxv. note).  Wherefore, in order that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men may live together in harmony, and may aid one another, it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary that they should forego their natural right, and, for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sake of security, refrain from all actions which can injure
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their fellow--men.  The way in which this end can be obtained, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that men who are necessarily a prey to their emotions (IV. iv.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), inconstant, and diverse, should be able to render each
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other mutually secure, and feel mutual trust, is evident from IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii. and III. xxxix.  It is there shown, that an emotion can only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be restrained by an emotion stronger than, and contrary to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, and that men avoid inflicting injury through fear of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: incurring a greater injury themselves.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: On this law society can be established, so long as it keeps
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in its own hand the right, possessed by everyone, of avenging
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injury, and pronouncing on good and evil; and provided it also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses the power to lay down a general rule of conduct, and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pass laws sanctioned, not by reason, which is powerless in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: restraining emotion, but by threats (IV. xvii. note).  Such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: society established with laws and the power of preserving itself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is called a State, while those who live under its protection are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called citizens.  We may readily understand that there is in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state of nature nothing, which by universal consent is pronounced
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good or bad; for in the state of nature everyone thinks solely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of his own advantage, and according to his disposition, with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reference only to his individual advantage, decides what is good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or bad, being bound by no law to anyone besides himself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: In the state of nature, therefore, sin is inconceivable; it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can only exist in a state, where good and evil are pronounced on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by common consent, and where everyone is bound to obey the State
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority.  Sin, then, is nothing else but disobedience, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore punished by the right of the State only.  Obedience, on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the other hand, is set down as merit, inasmuch as a man is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought worthy of merit, if he takes delight in the advantages
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which a State provides.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, in the state of nature, no one is by common consent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: master of anything, nor is there anything in nature, which can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said to belong to one man rather than another: all things are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all.  Hence, in the state of nature, we can conceive no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wish to render to every man his own, or to deprive a man of that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which belongs to him; in other words, there is nothing in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state of nature answering to justice and injustice.  Such ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are only possible in a social state, when it is decreed by common
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consent what belongs to one man and what to another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: From all these considerations it is evident, that justice and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injustice, sin and merit, are extrinsic ideas, and not attributes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which display the nature of the mind.  But I have said enough.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVIII.  Whatsoever disposes the human body, so as to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: render it capable of being affected in an increased number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways, or of affecting external bodies in an increased number of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways, is useful to man; and is so, in proportion as the body is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereby rendered more capable of being affected or affecting
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other bodies in an increased number of ways; contrariwise,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever renders the body less capable in this respect is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hurtful to man.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever thus increases the capabilities of the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increases also the mind's capability of perception (II. xiv.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, whatsoever thus disposes the body and thus renders it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable, is necessarily good or useful (IV. xxvi. xxvii.); and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is so in proportion to the extent to which it can render the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable; contrariwise (II. xiv., IV. xxvi. xxvii.), it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hurtful, if it renders the body in this respect less capable.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIX.  Whatsoever brings about the preservation of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion of motion and rest, which the parts of the human body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mutually possess, is good; contrariwise, whatsoever causes a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: change in such proportion is bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The human body needs many other bodies for its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preservation (II. Post. iv.).  But that which constitutes the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: specific reality (forma) of a human body is, that its parts
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: communicate their several motions one to another in a certain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fixed proportion (Def. before Lemma iv. after II. xiii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore, whatsoever brings about the preservation of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion between motion and rest, which the parts of the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body mutually possess, preserves the specific reality of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human body, and consequently renders the human body capable of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being affected in many ways and of affecting external bodies in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many ways; consequently it is good (by the last Prop.).  Again,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever brings about a change in the aforesaid proportion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes the human body to assume another specific character, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words (see Preface to this Part towards the end, though the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point is indeed self--evident), to be destroyed, and consequently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: totally incapable of being affected in an increased numbers of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways; therefore it is bad.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The extent to which such causes can injure or be of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: service to the mind will be explained in the Fifth Part.  But I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would here remark that I consider that a body undergoes death,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when the proportion of motion and rest which obtained mutually
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: among its several parts is changed.  For I do not venture to deny
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a human body, while keeping the circulation of the blood and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other properties, wherein the life of a body is thought to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consist, may none the less be changed into another nature totally
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from its own.  There is no reason, which compels me to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: maintain that a body does not die, unless it becomes a corpse;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nay, experience would seem to point to the opposite conclusion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It sometimes happens, that a man undergoes such changes, that I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should hardly call him the same.  As I have heard tell of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain Spanish poet, who had been seized with sickness, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though he recovered therefrom yet remained so oblivious of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: past life, that he would not believe the plays and tragedies he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had written to be his own: indeed, he might have been taken for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a grown--up child, if he had also forgotten his native tongue.  If
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this instance seems incredible, what shall we say of infants? A
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man of ripe age deems their nature so unlike his own, that he can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only be persuaded that he too has been an infant by the analogy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of other men.  However, I prefer to leave such questions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undiscussed, lest I should give ground to the superstitious for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: raising new issues.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XL.  Whatsoever conduces to man's social life, or causes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men to live together in harmony, is useful, whereas whatsoever
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brings discord into a State is bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--For whatsoever causes men to live together in harmony
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also causes them to live according to reason (IV. xxxv.), and is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (IV. xxvi. xxvii.) good, and (for the same reason)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever brings about discord is bad.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLI.  Pleasure in itself is not bad but good:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrariwise, pain in itself is bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Pleasure (III. xi. and note) is emotion, whereby the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body's power of activity is increased or helped; pain is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion, whereby the body's power of activity is diminished or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: checked; therefore (IV. xxxviii.) pleasure in itself is good,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLII.  Mirth cannot be excessive, but is always good;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrariwise, Melancholy is always bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Mirth (see its Def. in III. xi. note) is pleasure,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which, in so far as it is referred to the body, consists in all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts of the body being affected equally: that is (III. xi.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body's power of activity is increased or aided in such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner, that the several parts maintain their former proportion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of motion and rest; therefore Mirth is always good (IV. xxxix.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and cannot be excessive.  But Melancholy (see its Def. in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same note to III. xi.) is pain, which, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the body, consists in the absolute decrease or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hindrance of the body's power of activity; therefore (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxviii.) it is always bad.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIII.  Stimulation may be excessive and bad; on the other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand, grief may be good, in so far as stimulation or pleasure is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Localized pleasure or stimulation (titillatio) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, which, in so far as it is referred to the body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consists in one or some of its parts being affected more than the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest (see its Definition, III. xi. note); the power of this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion may be sufficient to overcome other actions of the body
title: Ethics
