author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. vi.), and may remain obstinately fixed therein, thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rendering it incapable of being affected in a variety of other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways: therefore (IV. xxxviii.) it may be bad.  Again, grief,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is pain, cannot as such be good (IV. xli.).  But, as its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: force and increase is defined by the power of an external cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compared with our own (IV. v.), we can conceive infinite degrees
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and modes of strength in this emotion (IV. iii.); we can,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, conceive it as capable of restraining stimulation, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preventing its becoming excessive, and hindering the body's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capabilities; thus, to this extent, it will be good.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIV.  Love and desire may be excessive.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Love is pleasure, accompanied by the idea of an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external cause (Def. of Emotions, vi.); therefore stimulation,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of an external cause is love (III. xi.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note); hence love maybe excessive.  Again, the strength of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire varies in proportion to the emotion from which it arises
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xxxvii.).  Now emotion may overcome all the rest of men's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions (IV. vi.); so, therefore, can desire, which arises from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same emotion, overcome all other desires, and become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excessive, as we showed in the last proposition concerning
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stimulation.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Mirth, which I have stated to be good, can be conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more easily than it can be observed.  For the emotions, whereby
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are daily assailed, are generally referred to some part of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body which is affected more than the rest; hence the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are generally excessive, and so fix the mind in the contemplation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of one object, that it is unable to think of others; and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although men, as a rule, are a prey to many emotions--and very few
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are found who are always assailed by one and the same--yet there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are cases, where one and the same emotion remains obstinately
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fixed.  We sometimes see men so absorbed in one object, that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although it be not present, they think they have it before them;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when this is the case with a man who is not asleep, we say he is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: delirious or mad; nor are those persons who are inflamed with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, and who dream all night and all day about nothing but their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mistress, or some woman, considered as less mad, for they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made objects of ridicule.  But when a miser thinks of nothing but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gain or money, or when an ambitious man thinks of nothing but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: glory, they are not reckoned to be mad, because they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generally harmful, and are thought worthy of being hated.  But,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in reality, Avarice, Ambition, Lust, &c., are species of madness,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though they may not be reckoned among diseases.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLV.  Hatred can never be good.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--When we hate a man, we endeavour to destroy him (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxix.), that is (IV. xxxvii.), we endeavour to do something that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is bad.  Therefore, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: N.B.  Here, and in what follows, I mean by hatred only hatred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards men.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary I.--Envy, derision, contempt, anger, revenge, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other emotions attributable to hatred, or arising therefrom, are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad; this is evident from III. xxxix. and IV. xxxvii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary II.--Whatsoever we desire from motives of hatred is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: base, and in a State unjust.  This also is evident from III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxix., and from the definitions of baseness and injustice in IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvii. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Between derision (which I have in Coroll. I. stated to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be bad) and laughter I recognize a great difference.  For
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laughter, as also jocularity, is merely pleasure; therefore, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as it be not excessive, it is in itself good (IV. xli.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Assuredly nothing forbids man to enjoy himself, save grim and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gloomy superstition.  For why is it more lawful to satiate one's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hunger and thirst than to drive away one's melancholy? I reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and have convinced myself as follows: No deity, nor anyone else,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save the envious, takes pleasure in my infirmity and discomfort,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor sets down to my virtue the tears, sobs, fear, and the like,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which axe signs of infirmity of spirit; on the contrary, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater the pleasure wherewith we are affected, the greater the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection whereto we pass; in other words, the more must we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily partake of the divine nature.  Therefore, to make use
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of what comes in our way, and to enjoy it as much as possible
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (not to the point of satiety, for that would not be enjoyment) is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the part of a wise man.  I say it is the part of a wise man to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: refresh and recreate himself with moderate and pleasant food and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: drink, and also with perfumes, with the soft beauty of growing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plants, with dress, with music, with many sports, with theatres,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the like, such as every man may make use of without injury to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his neighbour.  For the human body is composed of very numerous
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parts, of diverse nature, which continually stand in need of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fresh and varied nourishment, so that the whole body may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally capable of performing all the actions, which follow from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the necessity of its own nature; and, consequently, so that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind may also be equally capable of understanding many things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneously.  This way of life, then, agrees best with our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: principles, and also with general practice; therefore, if there
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be any question of another plan, the plan we have mentioned is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the best, and in every way to be commended.  There is no need for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: me to set forth the matter more clearly or in more detail.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVI.  He, who lives under the guidance of reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours, as far as possible, to render back love, or kindness,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for other men's hatred, anger, contempt, &c., towards him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All emotions of hatred are bad (IV. xlv. Coroll. i.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore he who lives under the guidance of reason will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour, as far as possible, to avoid being assailed by such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions (IV. xix.); consequently, he will also endeavour to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prevent others being so assailed (IV. xxxvii.).  But hatred is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increased by being reciprocated, and can be quenched by love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xliii.), so that hatred may pass into love (III. xliv.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore he who lives under the guidance of reason will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to repay hatred with love, that is, with kindness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--He who chooses to avenge wrongs with hatred is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assuredly wretched.  But he, who strives to conquer hatred with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, fights his battle in joy and confidence; he withstands
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many as easily as one, and has very little need of fortune's aid.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Those whom he vanquishes yield joyfully, not through failure, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through increase in their powers; all these consequences follow
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so plainly from the mere definitions of love and understanding,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that I have no need to prove them in detail.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVII.  Emotions of hope and fear cannot be in themselves
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Emotions of hope and fear cannot exist without pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For fear is pain (Def. of the Emotions, xiii.), and hope (Def. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Emotions, Explanation xii. and xiii.) cannot exist without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear; therefore (IV. xli.) these emotions cannot be good in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves, but only in so far as they can restrain excessive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure (IV. xliii.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We may add, that these emotions show defective
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge and an absence of power in the mind; for the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason confidence, despair, joy, and disappointment are signs of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a want of mental power.  For although confidence and joy are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurable emotions, they nevertheless imply a preceding pain,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, hope and fear.  Wherefore the more we endeavour to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guided by reason, the less do we depend on hope; we endeavour to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free ourselves from fear, and, as far as we can, to dominate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fortune, directing our actions by the sure counsels of wisdom.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLVIII.  The emotions of over--esteem and disparagement are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--These emotions (see Def. of the Emotions, xxi. xxii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are repugnant to reason; and are therefore (IV. xxvi. xxvii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLIX.  Over--esteem is apt to render its object proud.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If we see that any one rates us too highly, for love's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sake, we are apt to become elated (III. xli.), or to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably affected (Def. of the Emotions, xxx.); the good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we hear of ourselves we readily believe (III. xxv.); and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, for love's sake, rate ourselves too highly; in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, we are apt to become proud.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. L.  Pity, in a man who lives under the guidance of reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in itself bad and useless.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Pity (Def. of the Emotions, xviii.) is a pain, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (IV. xli.) is in itself bad.  The good effect which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows, namely, our endeavour to free the object of our pity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from misery, is an action which we desire to do solely at the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dictation of reason (IV. xxxvii.); only at the dictation of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason are we able to perform any action, which we know for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain to be good (IV. xxvii.); thus, in a man who lives under
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the guidance of reason, pity in itself is useless and bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--He who rightly realizes, that all things follow from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the necessity of the divine nature, and come to pass in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with the eternal laws and rules of nature, will not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: find anything worthy of hatred, derision, or contempt, nor will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he bestow pity on anything, but to the utmost extent of human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue he will endeavour to do well, as the saying is, and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rejoice.  We may add, that he, who is easily touched with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compassion, and is moved by another's sorrow or tears, often does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something which he afterwards regrets; partly because we can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never be sure that an action caused by emotion is good, partly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because we are easily deceived by false tears.  I am in this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: place expressly speaking of a man living under the guidance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason.  He who is moved to help others neither by reason nor by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compassion, is rightly styled inhuman, for (III. xxvii.) he seems
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unlike a man.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LI.  Approval is not repugnant to reason, but can agree
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therewith and arise therefrom.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Approval is love towards one who has done good to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another (Def. of the Emotions, xix.); therefore it may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the mind, in so far as the latter is active (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lix.), that is (III. iii.), in so far as it understands;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, it is in agreement with reason, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Another Proof.--He, who lives under the guidance of reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires for others the good which he seeks for himself (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvii.); wherefore from seeing someone doing good to his fellow
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own endeavour to do good is aided; in other words, he will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feel pleasure (III. xi. note) accompanied by the idea of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: benefactor.  Therefore he approves of him.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Indignation as we defined it (Def. of the Emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xx.) is necessarily evil (IV. xlv.); we may, however, remark
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that, when the sovereign power for the sake of preserving peace
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: punishes a citizen who has injured another, it should not be said
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be indignant with the criminal, for it is not incited by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred to ruin him, it is led by a sense of duty to punish him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LII.  Self--approval may arise from reason, and that which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises from reason is the highest possible.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Self--approval is pleasure arising from a man's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation of himself and his own power of action (Def. of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Emotions, xxv.).  But a man's true power of action or virtue is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason herself (III. iii.), as the said man clearly and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly contemplates her (II. xl. xliii.); therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--approval arises from reason.  Again, when a man is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplating himself, he only perceived clearly and distinctly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or adequately, such things as follow from his power of action
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. Def. ii.), that is (III. iii.), from his power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding; therefore in such contemplation alone does the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest possible self--approval arise.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Self--approval is in reality the highest object for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we can hope.  For (as we showed in IV. xxv.) no one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours to preserve his being for the sake of any ulterior
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object, and, as this approval is more and more fostered and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strengthened by praise (III. liii. Coroll.), and on the contrary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. lv. Coroll.) is more and more disturbed by blame, fame
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: becomes the most powerful of incitements to action, and life
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under disgrace is almost unendurable.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LIII.  Humility is not a virtue, or does not arise from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Humility is pain arising from a man's contemplation of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own infirmities (Def. of the Emotions, xxvi.).  But, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as a man knows himself by true reason, he is assumed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand his essence, that is, his power (III. vii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore, if a man in self--contemplation perceives any infirmity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in himself, it is not by virtue of his understanding himself, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. lv.) by virtue of his power of activity being checked.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, if we assume that a man perceives his own infirmity by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue of understanding something stronger than himself, by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of which he determines his own power of activity, this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the same as saying that we conceive that a man understands
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself distinctly (IV. xxvi.), because[14] his power of activity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is aided.  Wherefore humility, or the pain which arises from a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's contemplation of his own infirmity, does not arise from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation or reason, and is not a virtue but a passion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [14] Land reads: "Quod ipsius agendi potentia juvatur"--which I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have translated above.  He suggests as alternative readings to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 'quod', 'quo' (= whereby) and 'quodque' (= and that).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LIV.  Repentance is not a virtue, or does not arise from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason; but he who repents of an action is doubly wretched or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infirm.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The first part of this proposition is proved like the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foregoing one.  The second part is proved from the mere
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of the emotion in question (Def. of the Emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxvii.).  For the man allows himself to be overcome, first, by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil desires; secondly, by pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--As men seldom live under the guidance of reason, these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two emotions, namely, Humility and Repentance, as also Hope and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Fear, bring more good than harm; hence, as we must sin, we had
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: better sin in that direction.  For, if all men who are a prey to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion were all equally proud, they would shrink from nothing,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and would fear nothing; how then could they be joined and linked
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: together in bonds of union?  The crowd plays the tyrant, when it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not in fear; hence we need not wonder that the prophets, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consulted the good, not of a few, but of all, so strenuously
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commended Humility, Repentance, and Reverence.  Indeed those who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are a prey to these emotions may be led much more easily than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others to live under the guidance of reason, that is, to become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free and to enjoy the life of the blessed.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LV.  Extreme pride or dejection indicates extreme ignorance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of self.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is evident from Def. of the Emotions, xxviii. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxix.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LVI.  Extreme pride or dejection indicates extreme
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infirmity of spirit.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The first foundation of virtue is self--preservation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. xxii. Coroll.) under the guidance of reason (IV. xxiv.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He, therefore, who is ignorant of himself, is ignorant of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foundation of all virtues, and consequently of all virtues.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, to act virtuously is merely to act under the guidance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason (IV. xxiv.): now he, that acts under the guidance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, must necessarily know that he so acts (II. xliii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore he who is in extreme ignorance of himself, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently of all virtues, acts least in obedience to virtue;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in other words (IV. Def. viii.), is most infirm of spirit.  Thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extreme pride or dejection indicates extreme infirmity of spirit.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it most clearly follows, that the proud and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the dejected specially fall a prey to the emotions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Yet dejection can be more easily corrected than pride;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the latter being a pleasurable emotion, and the former a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: painful emotion, the pleasurable is stronger than the painful
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. xviii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LVII.  The proud man delights in the company of flatterers
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and parasites, but hates the company of the high--minded.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Pride is pleasure arising from a man's over estimation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of himself (Def. of the Emotions, xxviii. and vi.); this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: estimation the proud man will endeavour to foster by all the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means in his power (III. xiii. note); he will therefore delight
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the company of flatterers and parasites (whose character is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: too well known to need definition here), and will avoid the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: company of high--minded men, who value him according to his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deserts.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--It would be too long a task to enumerate here all the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil results of pride, inasmuch as the proud are a prey to all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the emotions, though to none of them less than to love and pity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I cannot, however, pass over in silence the fact, that a man may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be called proud from his underestimation of other people; and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, pride in this sense may be defined as pleasure arising
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the false opinion, whereby a man may consider himself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: superior to his fellows.  The dejection, which is the opposite
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: quality to this sort of pride, may be defined as pain arising
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the false opinion, whereby a man may think himself inferior
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to his fellows.  Such being the ease, we can easily see that a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proud man is necessarily envious (III. xli. note), and only takes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure in the company, who fool his weak mind to the top of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bent, and make him insane instead of merely foolish.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Though dejection is the emotion contrary to pride, yet is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dejected man very near akin to the proud man.  For, inasmuch as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his pain arises from a comparison between his own infirmity and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other men's power or virtue, it will be removed, or, in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, he will feel pleasure, if his imagination be occupied in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplating other men's faults; whence arises the proverb,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "The unhappy are comforted by finding fellow--sufferers."
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Contrariwise, he will be the more pained in proportion as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinks himself inferior to others; hence none are so prone to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: envy as the dejected, they are specially keen in observing men's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions, with a view to fault--finding rather than correction, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order to reserve their praises for dejection, and to glory
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein, though all the time with a dejected air.  These effects
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow as necessarily from the said emotion, as it follows from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of a triangle, that the three angles are equal to two
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right angles.  I have already said that I call these and similar
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions bad, solely in respect to what is useful to man.  The
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of nature have regard to nature's general order, whereof man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is but a part.  I mention this, in passing, lest any should think
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that I have wished to set forth the faults and irrational deeds
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of men rather than the nature and properties of things.  For, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I said in the preface to the third Part, I regard human emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and their properties as on the same footing with other natural
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phenomena.  Assuredly human emotions indicate the power and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ingenuity, of nature, if not of human nature, quite as fully as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other things which we admire, and which we delight to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplate.  But I pass on to note those qualities in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, which bring advantage to man, or inflict injury upon
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LVIII.  Honour (gloria) is not repugnant to reason, but may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arise therefrom.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is evident from Def. of the Emotions, xxx., and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also from the definition of an honourable man (IV. xxxvii. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note--Empty honour, as it is styled, is self--approval,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fostered only by the good opinion of the populace; when this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good opinion ceases there ceases also the self--approval, in other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, the highest object of each man's love (IV. lii. note);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, he whose honour is rooted in popular approval must,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day by day, anxiously strive, act, and scheme in order to retain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his reputation.  For the populace is variable and inconstant, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that, if a reputation be not kept up, it quickly withers away.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Everyone wishes to catch popular applause for himself, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readily represses the fame of others.  The object of the strife
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being estimated as the greatest of all goods, each combatant is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seized with a fierce desire to put down his rivals in every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible way, till he who at last comes out victorious is more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proud of having done harm to others than of having done good to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself.  This sort of honour, then, is really empty, being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The points to note concerning shame may easily be inferred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from what was said on the subject of mercy and repentance.  I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will only add that shame, like compassion, though not a virtue,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is yet good, in so far as it shows, that the feeler of shame is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: really imbued with the desire to live honourably; in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way as suffering is good, as showing that the injured part is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mortified.  Therefore, though a man who feels shame is sorrowful,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is yet more perfect than he, who is shameless, and has no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire to live honourably.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the points which I undertook to remark upon
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the emotions of pleasure and pain; as for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires, they are good or bad according as they spring from good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or evil emotions.  But all, in so far as they are engendered in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us by emotions wherein the mind is passive, are blind (as is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident from what was said in IV. xliv. note), and would be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useless, if men could easily, be induced to live by the guidance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of reason only, as I will now briefly, show.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LIX.  To all the actions, whereto we are determined by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion wherein the mind is passive; we can be determined
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without emotion by reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--To act rationally, is nothing else (III. iii. and Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ii.) but to perform those actions, which follow from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity, of our nature considered in itself alone.  But pain is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bad, in so far as it diminishes or checks the power of action
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. xli.); wherefore we cannot by pain be determined to any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action, which we should be unable to perform under the guidance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of reason.  Again, pleasure is bad only in so far as it hinders a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's capability for action (IV. xli. xliii.); therefore to this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extent we could not be determined by it to any action, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could not perform under the guidance of reason.  Lastly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, in so far as it is good, is in harmony with reason (for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it consists in the fact that a man's capability for action is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increased or aided); nor is the mind passive therein, except in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as a man's power of action is not increased to the extent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of affording him an adequate conception of himself and his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions (III. iii., and note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore, if a man who is pleasurably affected be brought to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such a state of perfection, that he gains an adequate conception
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of himself and his own actions, he will be equally, nay more,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable of those actions, to which he is determined by emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherein the mind is passive.  But all emotions are attributable
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to pleasure, to pain, or to desire (Def. of the Emotions, iv.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explanation); and desire (Def. of the Emotions, i.) is nothing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else but the attempt to act; therefore, to all actions, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Another Proof.--A given action is called bad, in so far as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises from one being affected by hatred or any evil emotion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But no action, considered in itself alone, is either good or bad
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (as we pointed out in the preface to Pt. IV.), one and the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action being sometimes good, sometimes bad; wherefore to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action which is sometimes bad, or arises from some evil emotion,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we may be led by reason (IV. xix.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--An example will put this point in a clearer light.  The
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action of striking, in so far as it is considered physically, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as we merely look to the fact that a man raises his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arm, clenches his fist, and moves his whole arm violently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: downwards, is a virtue or excellence which is conceived as proper
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the structure of the human body.  If, then, a man, moved by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anger or hatred, is led to clench his fist or to move his arm,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this result takes place (as we showed in Pt. II.), because one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the same action can be associated with various mental images
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things; therefore we may be determined to the performance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one and the same action by confused ideas, or by clear and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinct ideas.  Hence it is evident that every desire which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: springs from emotion, wherein the mind is passive, would become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useless, if men could be guided by reason.  Let us now see why
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire which arises from emotion, wherein the mind is passive, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called by us blind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LX.  Desire arising from a pleasure or pain, that is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributable to the whole body, but only to one or certain parts
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereof, is without utility in respect to a man as a whole.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Let it be assumed, for instance, that A, a part of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, is so strengthened by some external cause, that it prevails
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over the remaining parts (IV. vi.).  This part will not endeavour
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to do away with its own powers, in order that the other parts of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body may perform its office; for this it would be necessary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for it to have a force or power of doing away with its own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: powers, which (III. vi.) is absurd.  The said part, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, the mind also, will endeavour to preserve its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: condition.  Wherefore desire arising from a pleasure of the kind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aforesaid has no utility in reference to a man as a whole.  If it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be assumed, on the other hand, that the part, A, be checked so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the remaining parts prevail, it may be proved in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner that desire arising from pain has no utility in respect to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man as a whole.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--As pleasure is generally (IV. xliv. note) attributed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one part of the body, we generally desire to preserve our being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with out taking into consideration our health as a whole: to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it may be added, that the desires which have most hold over
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us (IV. ix.) take account of the present and not of the future.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXI.  Desire which springs from reason cannot be excessive.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Desire (Def. of the Emotions, i.) considered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely is the actual essence of man, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived as in any way determined to a particular activity by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some given modification of itself.  Hence desire, which arises
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from reason, that is (III. iii.), which is engendered in us in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as we act, is the actual essence or nature of man, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as it is conceived as determined to such activities as are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequately conceived through man's essence only (III. Def. ii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now, if such desire could be excessive, human nature considered
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in itself alone would be able to exceed itself, or would be able
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to do more than it can, a manifest contradiction.  Therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such desire cannot be excessive.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXII.  In so far as the mind conceives a thing under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dictates of reason, it is affected equally, whether the idea be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a thing future, past, or present.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Whatsoever the mind conceives under the guidance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, it conceives under the form of eternity or necessity (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xliv. Coroll. ii.), and is therefore affected with the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certitude (II. xliii. and note).  Wherefore, whether the thing be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present, past, or future, the mind conceives it under the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity and is affected with the same certitude; and whether
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea be of something present, past, or future, it will in all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cases be equally true (II. xli.); that is, it will always
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess the same properties of an adequate idea (II. Def. iv.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, in so far as the mind conceives things under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dictates of reason, it is affected in the same manner, whether
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea be of a thing future, past, or present.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--If we could possess an adequate knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: duration of things, and could determine by reason their periods
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of existence, we should contemplate things future with the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion as things present; and the mind would desire as though
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it were present the good which it conceived as future;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently it would necessarily neglect a lesser good in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present for the sake of a greater good in the future, and would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in no wise desire that which is good in the present but a source
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of evil in the future, as we shall presently show.  However, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can have but a very inadequate knowledge of the duration of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things (II. xxxi.); and the periods of their existence (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xliv. note.) we can only determine by imagination, which is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so powerfully affected by the future as by the present.  Hence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such true knowledge of good and evil as we possess is merely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abstract or general, and the judgment which we pass on the order
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things and the connection of causes, with a view to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determining what is good or bad for us in the present, is rather
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imaginary than real.  Therefore it is nothing wonderful, if the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire arising from such knowledge of good and evil, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it looks on into the future, be more readily checked than the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire of things which are agreeable at the present time.  (Cf.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV. xvi.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXIII.  He who is led by fear, and does good in order to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: escape evil, is not led by reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All the emotions which are attributable to the mind as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: active, or in other words to reason, are emotions of pleasure and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire (III. lix.); therefore, he who is led by fear, and does
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good in order to escape evil, is not led by reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Superstitions persons, who know better how to rail at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vice than how to teach virtue, and who strive not to guide men by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, but so to restrain them that they would rather escape
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil than love virtue, have no other aim but to make others as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wretched as themselves; wherefore it is nothing wonderful, if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they be generally troublesome and odious to their fellow--men.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Under desire which springs from reason, we seek
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good directly, and shun evil indirectly.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Desire which springs from reason can only spring from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a pleasurable emotion, wherein the mind is not passive (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lix.), in other words, from a pleasure which cannot be excessive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. lxi.), and not from pain; wherefore this desire springs
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the knowledge of good, not of evil (IV. viii.); hence under
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the guidance of reason we seek good directly and only by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: implication shun evil.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This Corollary may be illustrated by the example of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sick and a healthy man.  The sick man through fear of death eats
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what he naturally shrinks from, but the healthy man takes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure in his food, and thus gets a better enjoyment out of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life, than if he were in fear of death, and desired directly to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avoid it.  So a judge, who condemns a criminal to death, not from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred or anger but from love of the public well--being, is guided
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely by reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXIV.  The knowledge of evil is an inadequate knowledge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The knowledge of evil (IV. viii.) is pain, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we are conscious thereof.  Now pain is the transition to a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lesser perfection (Def. of the Emotions, iii.) and therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be understood through man's nature (III. vi., and vii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore it is a passive state (III. Def. ii.) which (III. iii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: depends on inadequate ideas; consequently the knowledge thereof
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xxix.), namely, the knowledge of evil, is inadequate.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that, if the human mind possessed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only adequate ideas, it would form no conception of evil.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXV.  Under the guidance of reason we should pursue the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater of two goods and the lesser of two evils.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A good which prevents our enjoyment of a greater good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in reality an evil; for we apply the terms good and bad to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, in so far as we compare them one with another (see
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preface to this Part); therefore, evil is in reality a lesser
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good; hence under the guidance of reason we seek or pursue only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the greater good and the lesser evil.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--We may, under the guidance of reason, pursue the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lesser evil as though it were the greater good, and we may shun
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the lesser good, which would be the cause of the greater evil.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For the evil, which is here called the lesser, is really good,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the lesser good is really evil, wherefore we may seek the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: former and shun the latter.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXVI.  We may, under the guidance of reason, seek a greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good in the future in preference to a lesser good in the present,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and we may seek a lesser evil in the present in preference to a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater evil in the future.[15]
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [15] "Maltim praesens minus prae majori futuro." (Van Vloten).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bruder reads: "Malum praesens minus, quod causa est faturi
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alicujus mali." The last word of the latter is an obvious
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: misprint, and is corrected by the Dutch translator into "majoris
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: boni." (Pollock, p. 268, note.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If the mind could have an adequate knowledge of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future, it would be affected towards what is future in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way as towards what is present (IV. lxii.); wherefore, looking
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely to reason, as in this proposition we are assumed to do,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is no difference, whether the greater good or evil be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assumed as present, or assumed as future; hence (IV. lxv.) we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may seek a greater good in the future in preference to a lesser
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good in the present, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--We may, under the guidance of reason, seek a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lesser evil in the present, because it is the cause of a greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good in the future, and we may shun a lesser good in the present,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because it is the cause of a greater evil in the future.  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary is related to the foregoing Proposition as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary to IV. lxv. is related to the said IV. lxv.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--If these statements be compared with what we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pointed out concerning the strength of the emotions in this Part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: up to Prop. xviii., we shall readily see the difference between a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, who is led solely by emotion or opinion, and a man, who is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: led by reason.  The former, whether will or no, performs actions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof he is utterly ignorant; the latter is his own master and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only performs such actions, as he knows are of primary importance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in life, and therefore chiefly desires; wherefore I call the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: former a slave, and the latter a free man, concerning whose
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition and manner of life it will be well to make a few
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observations.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXVII.  A free man thinks of death least of all things;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and his wisdom is a meditation not of death but of life.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--A free man is one who lives under the guidance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, who is not led by fear (IV. lxiii.), but who directly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires that which is good (IV. lxiii. Coroll.), in other words
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. xxiv.), who strives to act, to live, and to preserve his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being on the basis of seeking his own true advantage; wherefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such an one thinks of nothing less than of death, but his wisdom
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a meditation of life.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXVIII.  If men were born free, they would, so long as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remained free, form no conception of good and evil.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--I call free him who is led solely by reason; he,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, who is born free, and who remains free, has only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas; therefore (IV. lxiv. Coroll.) he has no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception of evil, or consequently (good and evil being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: correlative) of good.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--It is evident, from IV. iv., that the hypothesis of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this Proposition is false and inconceivable, except in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we look solely to the nature of man, or rather to God; not in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as the latter is infinite, but only in so far as he is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of man's existence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This, and other matters which we have already proved, seem to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have been signifieded by Moses in the history of the first man.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For in that narrative no other power of God is conceived, save
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that whereby he created man, that is the power wherewith he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: provided solely for man's advantage; it is stated that God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forbade man, being free, to eat of the tree of the knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good and evil, and that, as soon as man should have eaten of it,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he would straightway fear death rather than desire to live.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, it is written that when man had found a wife, who was in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entire harmony with his nature, he knew that there could be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing in nature which could be more useful to him; but that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after he believed the beasts to be like himself, he straightway
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: began to imitate their emotions (III. xxvii.), and to lose his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freedom; this freedom was afterwards recovered by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: patriarchs, led by the spirit of Christ; that is, by the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, whereon alone it depends, that man may be free, and desire
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for others the good which he desires for himself, as we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown above (IV. xxxvii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXIX.  The virtue of a free man is seen to be as great,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when it declines dangers, as when it overcomes them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Emotion can only be checked or removed by an emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to itself, and possessing more power in restraining
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion (IV. vii.).  But blind daring and fear are emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which can be conceived as equally great (IV. v. and iii.):
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hence, no less virtue or firmness is required in checking daring
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than in checking fear (III. lix. note); in other words (Def. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Emotions, xl. and xli.), the free man shows as much virtue,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when he declines dangers, as when he strives to overcome them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--The free man is as courageous in timely retreat as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in combat; or, a free man shows equal courage or presence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, whether he elect to give battle or to retreat.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--What courage (animositas) is, and what I mean thereby,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I explained in III. lix. note.  By danger I mean everything,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which can give rise to any evil, such as pain, hatred, discord,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXX.  The free man, who lives among the ignorant, strives,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as far as he can, to avoid receiving favours from them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Everyone judges what is good according to his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition (III. xxxix. note); wherefore an ignorant man, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has conferred a benefit on another, puts his own estimate upon
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, and, if it appears to be estimated less highly by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: receiver, will feel pain (III. xlii.).  But the free man only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires to join other men to him in friendship (IV. xxxvii.), not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repaying their benefits with others reckoned as of like value,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but guiding himself and others by the free decision of reason,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and doing only such things as he knows to be of primary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: importance.  Therefore the free man, lest he should become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hateful to the ignorant, or follow their desires rather than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, will endeavour, as far as he can, to avoid receiving
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their favours.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--I say, as far as he can.  For though men be ignorant,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet are they men, and in cases of necessity could afford us human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aid, the most excellent of all things: therefore it is often
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary to accept favours from them, and consequently to repay
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such favours in kind; we must, therefore, exercise caution in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: declining favours, lest we should have the appearance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: despising those who bestow them, or of being, from avaricious
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motives, unwilling to requite them, and so give ground for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: offence by the very fact of striving to avoid it.  Thus, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: declining favours, we must look to the requirements of utility
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and courtesy.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXXI.  Only free men are thoroughly grateful one to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Only free men are thoroughly useful one to another,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and associated among themselves by the closest necessity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: friendship (IV. xxxv., and Coroll. i.), only such men endeavour,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with mutual zeal of love, to confer benefits on each other (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvii.), and, therefore, only they are thoroughly grateful one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to another.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The goodwill, which men who are led by blind desire
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have for one another, is generally a bargaining or enticement,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than pure goodwill.  Moreover, ingratitude is not an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion.  Yet it is base, inasmuch as it generally shows, that a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man is affected by excessive hatred, anger, pride, avarice, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He who, by reason of his folly, knows not how to return benefits,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not ungrateful, much less he who is not gained over by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gifts of a courtesan to serve her lust, or by a thief to conceal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his thefts, or by any similar persons.  Contrariwise, such an one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shows a constant mind, inasmuch as he cannot by any gifts be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corrupted, to his own or the general hurt.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXXII.  The free man never acts fraudulently, but always in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good faith.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--If it be asked: What should a man's conduct be in a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case where he could by breaking faith free himself from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: danger of present death? Would not his plan of self--preservation
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: completely persuade him to deceive? This may be answered by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pointing out that, if reason persuaded him to act thus, it would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persuade all men to act in a similar manner, in which case reason
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would persuade men not to agree in good faith to unite their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forces, or to have laws in common, that is, not to have any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general laws, which is absurd.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. LXXIII.  The man, who is guided by reason, is more free in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a State, where he lives under a general system of law, than in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solitude, where he is independent.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The man, who is guided by reason, does not obey
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through fear (IV. lxiii.): but, in so far as he endeavours to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve his being according to the dictates of reason, that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (IV. lxvi. note), in so far as he endeavours to live in freedom,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he desires to order his life according to the general good (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxvii.), and, consequently (as we showed in IV. xxxvii. note.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ii.), to live according to the laws of his country.  Therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the free man, in order to enjoy greater freedom, desires to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess the general rights of citizenship.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--These and similar observations, which we have made on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's true freedom, may be referred to strength, that is, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: courage and nobility of character (III. lix. note).  I do not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think it worth while to prove separately all the properties of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength; much less need I show, that he that is strong hates no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, is angry with no man, envies no man, is indignant with no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, despises no man, and least of all things is proud.  These
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: propositions, and all that relate to the true way of life and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion, are easily proved from IV. xxxvii. and IV. xlvi.;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, that hatred should be overcome with love, and that every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man should desire for others the good which he seeks for himself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We may also repeat what we drew attention to in the note to IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: l., and in other places; namely, that the strong man has ever
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first in his thoughts, that all things follow from the necessity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the divine nature; so that whatsoever he deems to be hurtful
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and evil, and whatsoever, accordingly, seems to him impious,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: horrible, unjust, and base, assumes that appearance owing to his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own disordered, fragmentary, and confused view of the universe.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore he strives before all things to conceive things as they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: really are, and to remove the hindrances to true knowledge, such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as are hatred, anger, envy, derision, pride, and similar
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, which I have mentioned above.  Thus he endeavours, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we said before, as far as in him lies, to do good, and to go on
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his way rejoicing.  How far human virtue is capable of attaining
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to such a condition, and what its powers may be, I will prove in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the following Part.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: APPENDIX.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: What have said in this Part concerning the right way of life
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has not been arranged, so as to admit of being seen at one view,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but has been set forth piece--meal, according as I thought each
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
