text: Proposition could most readily be deduced from what preceded it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I propose, therefore, to rearrange my remarks and to bring them
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under leading heads.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  All our endeavours or desires so follow from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of our nature, that they can be understood either
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through it alone, as their proximate cause, or by virtue of our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being a part of nature, which cannot be adequately conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through itself without other individuals.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  Desires, which follow from our nature in such a manner,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they can be understood through it alone, are those which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the mind, in so far as the latter is conceived to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consist of adequate ideas: the remaining desires are only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the mind, in so far as it conceives things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequately, and their force and increase are generally defined
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not by the power of man, but by the power of things external to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us: wherefore the former are rightly called actions, the latter
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passions, for the former always indicate our power, the latter,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the other hand, show our infirmity and fragmentary knowledge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  Our actions, that is, those desires which are defined
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by man's power or reason, are always good.  The rest may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either good or bad.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  Thus in life it is before all things useful to perfect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the understanding, or reason, as far as we can, and in this alone
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's highest happiness or blessedness consists, indeed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness is nothing else but the contentment of spirit, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises from the intuitive knowledge of God: now, to perfect the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding is nothing else but to understand God, God's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributes, and the actions which follow from the necessity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his nature.  Wherefore of a man, who is led by reason, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ultimate aim or highest desire, whereby he seeks to govern all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his fellows, is that whereby he is brought to the adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conception of himself and of all things within the scope of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intelligence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  Therefore, without intelligence there is not rational
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life: and things are only good, in so far as they aid man in his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enjoyment of the intellectual life, which is defined by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intelligence.  Contrariwise, whatsoever things hinder man's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfecting of his reason, and capability to enjoy the rational
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life, are alone called evil.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VI.  As all things whereof man is the efficient cause are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily good, no evil can befall man except through external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes; namely, by virtue of man being a part of universal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, whose laws human nature is compelled to obey, and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conform to in almost infinite ways.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VII.  It is impossible, that man should not be a part of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, or that he should not follow her general order; but if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he be thrown among individuals whose nature is in harmony with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own, his power of action will thereby be aided and fostered,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas, if he be thrown among such as are but very little in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony with his nature, he will hardly be able to accommodate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself to them without undergoing a great change himself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: VIII.  Whatsoever in nature we deem to be evil, or to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable of injuring our faculty for existing and enjoying the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rational life, we may endeavour to remove in whatever way seems
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: safest to us; on the other hand, whatsoever we deem to be good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or useful for preserving our being, and enabling us to enjoy the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rational life, we may appropriate to our use and employ as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think best.  Everyone without exception may, by sovereign right
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of nature, do whatsoever he thinks will advance his own interest.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IX.  Nothing can be in more harmony with the nature of any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given thing than other individuals of the same species;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (cf. vii.) for man in the preservation of his being and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the enjoyment of the rational life there is nothing more useful
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than his fellow--man who is led by reason.  Further, as we know
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not anything among individual things which is more excellent than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man led by reason, no man can better display the power of his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: skill and disposition, than in so training men, that they come at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last to live under the dominion of their own reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: X.  In so far as men are influenced by envy or any kind of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred, one towards another, they are at variance, and are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore to be feared in proportion, as they are more powerful
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than their fellows.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XI.  Yet minds are not conquered by force, but by love and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: high--mindedness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XII.  It is before all things useful to men to associate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their ways of life, to bind themselves together with such bonds
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as they think most fitted to gather them all into unity, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generally to do whatsoever serves to strengthen friendship.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIII.  But for this there is need of skill and watchfulness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For men are diverse (seeing that those who live under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guidance of reason are few), yet are they generally envious and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more prone to revenge than to sympathy.  No small force of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: character is therefore required to take everyone as he is, and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: restrain one's self from imitating the emotions of others.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who carp at mankind, and are more skilled in railing at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vice than in instilling virtue, and who break rather than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strengthen men's dispositions, are hurtful both to themselves and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others.  Thus many from too great impatience of spirit, or from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: misguided religious zeal, have preferred to live among brutes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than among men; as boys or youths, who cannot peaceably
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endure the chidings of their parents, will enlist as soldiers and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: choose the hardships of war and the despotic discipline in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preference to the comforts of home and the admonitions of their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: father: suffering any burden to be put upon them, so long as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they may spite their parents.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIV.  Therefore, although men are generally governed in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything by their own lusts, yet their association in common
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brings many more advantages than drawbacks.  Wherefore it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: better to bear patiently the wrongs they may do us, and to strive
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to promote whatsoever serves to bring about harmony and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: friendship.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XV.  Those things, which beget harmony, are such as are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributable to justice, equity, and honourable living.  For men
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brook ill not only what is unjust or iniquitous, but also what is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reckoned disgraceful, or that a man should slight the received
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: customs of their society.  For winning love those qualities are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially necessary which have regard to religion and piety (cf.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV. xxxvii. notes. i. ii.; xlvi. note; and lxxiii. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVI.  Further, harmony is often the result of fear: but such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony is insecure.  Further, fear arises from infirmity of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spirit, and moreover belongs not to the exercise of reason: the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same is true of compassion, though this latter seems to bear a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain resemblance to piety.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVII.  Men are also gained over by liberality, especially
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such as have not the means to buy what is necessary to sustain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life.  However, to give aid to every poor man is far beyond the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power and the advantage of any private person.  For the riches of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any private person are wholly inadequate to meet such a call.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, an individual man's resources of character are too limited
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for him to be able to make all men his friends.  Hence providing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the poor is a duty, which falls on the State as a whole, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has regard only to the general advantage.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XVIII.  In accepting favours, and in returning gratitude our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: duty must be wholly different (cf. IV. lxx. note; lxxi. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XIX.  Again, meretricious love, that is, the lust of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generation arising from bodily beauty, and generally every sort
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of love, which owns anything save freedom of soul as its cause,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readily passes into hate; unless indeed, what is worse, it is a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: species of madness; and then it promotes discord rather than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony (cf. III. xxxi. Coroll.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XX.  As concerning marriage, it is certain that this is in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony with reason, if the desire for physical union be not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: engendered solely by bodily beauty, but also by the desire to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beget children and to train them up wisely; and moreover, if the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love of both, to wit, of the man and of the woman, is not caused
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by bodily beauty only, but also by freedom of soul.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXI.  Furthermore, flattery begets harmony; but only by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means of the vile offence of slavishness or treachery.  None are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more readily taken with flattery than the proud, who wish to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first, but are not.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXII.  There is in abasement a spurious appearance of piety
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and religion.  Although abasement is the opposite to pride, yet
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is he that abases himself most akin to the proud (IV. lvii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIII.  Shame also brings about harmony, but only in such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matters as cannot be hid.  Further, as shame is a species of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain, it does not concern the exercise of reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIV.  The remaining emotions of pain towards men are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directly opposed to justice, equity, honour, piety, and religion;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, although indignation seems to bear a certain resemblance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to equity, yet is life but lawless, where every man may pass
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judgment on another's deeds, and vindicate his own or other men's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXV.  Correctness of conduct (modestia), that is, the desire
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of pleasing men which is determined by reason, is attributable to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piety (as we said in IV. xxxvii. note. i.).  But, if it spring
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from emotion, it is ambition, or the desire whereby, men, under
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the false cloak of piety, generally stir up discords and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seditions.  For he who desires to aid his fellows either in word
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or in deed, so that they may together enjoy the highest good, he,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I say, will before all things strive to win them over with love:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not to draw them into admiration, so that a system may be called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after his name, nor to give any cause for envy.  Further, in his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conversation he will shrink from talking of men's faults, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be careful to speak but sparingly of human infirmity: but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will dwell at length on human virtue or power, and the way
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby it may be perfected.  Thus will men be stirred not by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear, nor by aversion, but only by the emotion of joy, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour, so far as in them lies, to live in obedience to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVI.  Besides men, we know of no particular thing in nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in whose mind we may rejoice, and whom we can associate with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves in friendship or any sort of fellowship; therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever there be in nature besides man, a regard for our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantage does not call on us to preserve, but to preserve or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroy according to its various capabilities, and to adapt to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our use as best we may.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVII.  The advantage which we derive from things external to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, besides the experience and knowledge which we acquire from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observing them, and from recombining their elements in different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forms, is principally the preservation of the body; from this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point of view, those things are most useful which can so feed and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nourish the body, that all its parts may rightly fulfil their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: functions.  For, in proportion as the body is capable of being
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected in a greater variety of ways, and of affecting external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies in a great number of ways, so much the more is the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable of thinking (IV. xxxviii., xxxix.).  But there seem to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very few things of this kind in nature; wherefore for the due
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nourishment of the body we must use many foods of diverse nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For the human body is composed of very many parts of different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, which stand in continual need of varied nourishment, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the whole body may be equally capable of doing everything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that can follow from its own nature, and consequently that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind also may be equally capable of forming many perceptions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXVIII.  Now for providing these nourishments the strength of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each individual would hardly suffice, if men did not lend one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another mutual aid.  But money has furnished us with a token for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything: hence it is with the notion of money, that the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the multitude is chiefly engrossed: nay, it can hardly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive any kind of pleasure, which is not accompanied with the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of money as cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXIX.  This result is the fault only of those, who seek
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: money, not from poverty or to supply their necessary wants, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because they have learned the arts of gain, wherewith they bring
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves to great splendour.  Certainly they nourish their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies, according to custom, but scantily, believing that they
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lose as much of their wealth as they spend on the preservation of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their body.  But they who know the true use of money, and who fix
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the measure of wealth solely with regard to their actual needs,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: live content with little.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXX.  As, therefore, those things are good which assist the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: various parts of the body, and enable them to perform their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: functions; and as pleasure consists in an increase of, or aid
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to, man's power, in so far as he is composed of mind and body;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it follows that all those things which bring pleasure are good.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But seeing that things do not work with the object of giving us
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure, and that their power of action is not tempered to suit
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our advantage, and, lastly, that pleasure is generally referred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to one part of the body more than to the other parts; therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most emotions of pleasure (unless reason and watchfulness be at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand), and consequently the desires arising therefrom, may become
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excessive.  Moreover we may add that emotion leads us to pay most
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard to what is agreeable in the present, nor can we estimate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is future with emotions equally vivid.  (IV. xliv. note, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lx. note.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXI.  Superstition, on the other hand, seems to account as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good all that brings pain, and as bad all that brings pleasure.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, as we said above (IV. xlv. note), none but the envious
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: take delight in my infirmity and trouble.  For the greater the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure whereby we are affected, the greater is the perfection
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereto we pass, and consequently the more do we partake of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divine nature: no pleasure can ever be evil, which is regulated
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by a true regard for our advantage.  But contrariwise he, who is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: led by fear and does good only to avoid evil, is not guided by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXII.  But human power is extremely limited, and is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinitely surpassed by the power of external causes; we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not, therefore, an absolute power of shaping to our use those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things which are without us.  Nevertheless, we shall bear with an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equal mind all that happens to us in contravention to the claims
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of our own advantage, so long as we are conscious, that we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done our duty, and that the power which we possess is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sufficient to enable us to protect ourselves completely;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remembering that we are a part of universal nature, and that we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow her order.  If we have a clear and distinct understanding
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this, that part of our nature which is defined by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intelligence, in other words the better part of ourselves, will
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assuredly acquiesce in what befalls us, and in such acquiescence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will endeavour to persist.  For, in so far as we are intelligent
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beings, we cannot desire anything save that which is necessary,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor yield absolute acquiescence to anything, save to that which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is true: wherefore, in so far as we have a right understanding
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of these things, the endeavour of the better part of ourselves is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in harmony with the order of nature as a whole.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PART V:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Of the Power of the Understanding, or of Human Freedom
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PREFACE
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: At length I pass to the remaining portion of my Ethics, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is concerned with the way leading to freedom.  I shall therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treat therein of the power of the reason, showing how far the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason can control the emotions, and what is the nature of Mental
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Freedom or Blessedness; we shall then be able to see, how much
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more powerful the wise man is than the ignorant.  It is no part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of my design to point out the method and means whereby the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding may be perfected, nor to show the skill whereby the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body may be so tended, as to be capable of the due performance of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its functions.  The latter question lies in the province of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Medicine, the former in the province of Logic.  Here, therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I repeat, I shall treat only of the power of the mind, or of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason; and I shall mainly show the extent and nature of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion over the emotions, for their control and moderation.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: That we do not possess absolute dominion over them, I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: already shown.  Yet the Stoics have thought, that the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: depended absolutely on our will, and that we could absolutely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: govern them.  But these philosophers were compelled, by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: protest of experience, not from their own principles, to confess,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that no slight practice and zeal is needed to control and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moderate them: and this someone endeavoured to illustrate by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: example (if I remember rightly) of two dogs, the one a house--dog
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the other a hunting--dog.  For by long training it could be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brought about, that the house--dog should become accustomed to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hunt, and the hunting--dog to cease from running after hares.  To
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this opinion Descartes not a little inclines.  For he maintained,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the soul or mind is specially united to a particular part of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the brain, namely, to that part called the pineal gland, by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aid of which the mind is enabled to feel all the movements which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are set going in the body, and also external objects, and which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind by a simple act of volition can put in motion in various
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways.  He asserted, that this gland is so suspended in the midst
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the brain, that it could be moved by the slightest motion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the animal spirits: further, that this gland is suspended in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: midst of the brain in as many different manners, as the animal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spirits can impinge thereon; and, again, that as many different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: marks are impressed on the said gland, as there are different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external objects which impel the animal spirits towards it;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whence it follows, that if the will of the soul suspends the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gland in a position, wherein it has already been suspended once
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: before by the animal spirits driven in one way or another, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gland in its turn reacts on the said spirits, driving and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determining them to the condition wherein they were, when
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repulsed before by a similar position of the gland.  He further
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: asserted, that every act of mental volition is united in nature
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to a certain given motion of the gland.  For instance, whenever
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone desires to look at a remote object, the act of volition
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes the pupil of the eye to dilate, whereas, if the person in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: question had only thought of the dilatation of the pupil, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mere wish to dilate it would not have brought about the result,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as the motion of the gland, which serves to impel the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: animal spirits towards the optic nerve in a way which would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dilate or contract the pupil, is not associated in nature with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the wish to dilate or contract the pupil, but with the wish to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: look at remote or very near objects.  Lastly, he maintained that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although every motion of the aforesaid gland seems to have been
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: united by nature to one particular thought out of the whole
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of our thoughts from the very beginning of our life, yet
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it can nevertheless become through habituation associated with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other thoughts; this he endeavours to prove in the Passions de
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: l'ame, I.50.  He thence concludes, that there is no soul so weak,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it cannot, under proper direction, acquire absolute power
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over its passions.  For passions as defined by him are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "perceptions, or feelings, or disturbances of the soul, which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the soul as species, and which (mark the expression)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are produced, preserved, and strengthened through some movement
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the spirits." (Passions de l'ame, I.27).  But, seeing that we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can join any motion of the gland, or consequently of the spirits,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to any volition, the determination of the will depends entirely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on our own powers; if, therefore, we determine our will with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sure and firm decisions in the direction to which we wish our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions to tend, and associate the motions of the passions which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we wish to acquire with the said decisions, we shall acquire an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolute dominion over our passions.  Such is the doctrine of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this illustrious philosopher (in so far as I gather it from his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own words); it is one which, had it been less ingenious, I could
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hardly believe to have proceeded from so great a man.  Indeed, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: am lost in wonder, that a philosopher, who had stoutly asserted,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he would draw no conclusions which do not follow from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self--evident premisses, and would affirm nothing which he did not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearly and distinctly perceive, and who had so often taken to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: task the scholastics for wishing to explain obscurities through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occult qualities, could maintain a hypothesis, beside which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occult qualities are commonplace.  What does he understand, I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ask, by the union of the mind and the body? What clear and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinct conception has he got of thought in most intimate union
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with a certain particle of extended matter? Truly I should like
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him to explain this union through its proximate cause.  But he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had so distinct a conception of mind being distinct from body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he could not assign any particular cause of the union
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: between the two, or of the mind itself, but was obliged to have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: recourse to the cause of the whole universe, that is to God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, I should much like to know, what degree of motion the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind can impart to this pineal gland, and with what force can it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hold it suspended? For I am in ignorance, whether this gland can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be agitated more slowly or more quickly by the mind than by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: animal spirits, and whether the motions of the passions, which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have closely united with firm decisions, cannot be again
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disjoined therefrom by physical causes; in which case it would
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow that, although the mind firmly intended to face a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: danger, and had united to this decision the motions of boldness,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet at the sight of the danger the gland might become suspended
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in a way, which would preclude the mind thinking of anything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except running away.  In truth, as there is no common standard of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: volition and motion, so is there no comparison possible between
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the powers of the mind and the power or strength of the body;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently the strength of one cannot in any wise be determined
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the strength of the other.  We may also add, that there is no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gland discoverable in the midst of the brain, so placed that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can thus easily be set in motion in so many ways, and also that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all the nerves are not prolonged so far as the cavities of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brain.  Lastly, I omit all the assertions which he makes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the will and its freedom, inasmuch as I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abundantly proved that his premisses are false.  Therefore, since
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of the mind, as I have shown above, is defined by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding only, we shall determine solely by the knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind the remedies against the emotions, which I believe all
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have had experience of, but do not accurately observe or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly see, and from the same basis we shall deduce all those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusions, which have regard to the mind's blessedness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AXIOMS.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  If two contrary actions be started in the same subject, a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: change must necessarily take place, either in both, or in one of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the two, and continue until they cease to be contrary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II.  The power of an effect is defined by the power of its cause,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as its essence is explained or defined by the essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (This axiom is evident from III. vii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROPOSITIONS.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. I.  Even as thoughts and the ideas of things are arranged
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and associated in the mind, so are the modifications of body or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the images of things precisely in the same way arranged and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associated in the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The order and connection of ideas is the same (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii.) as the order and connection of things, and vice versa the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order and connection of things is the same (II. vi. Coroll. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii.) as the order and connection of ideas.  Wherefore, even as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the order and connection of ideas in the mind takes place
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the order and association of modifications of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body (II. xviii.), so vice versa (III. ii.) the order and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: connection of modifications of the body takes place in accordance
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the manner, in which thoughts and the ideas of things are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arranged and associated in the mind.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. II.  If we remove a disturbance of the spirit, or emotion,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the thought of an external cause, and unite it to other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thoughts, then will the love or hatred towards that external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause, and also the vacillations of spirit which arise from these
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, be destroyed.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--That, which constitutes the reality of love or hatred,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is pleasure or pain, accompanied by the idea of an external cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def. of the Emotions, vi. vii.); wherefore, when this cause is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: removed, the reality of love or hatred is removed with it;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore these emotions and those which arise therefrom are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. III.  An emotion, which is a passion, ceases to be a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passion, as soon as we form a clear and distinct idea thereof.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--An emotion, which is a passion, is a confused idea (by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the general Def. of the Emotions).  If, therefore, we form a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clear and distinct idea of a given emotion, that idea will only
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be distinguished from the emotion, in so far as it is referred to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind only, by reason (II. xxi., and note); therefore (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iii.), the emotion will cease to be a passion.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary--An emotion therefore becomes more under our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: control, and the mind is less passive in respect to it, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as it is more known to us.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IV.  There is no modification of the body, whereof we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot form some clear and distinct conception.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Properties which are common to all things can only be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived adequately (II. xxxviii.); therefore (II. xii. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lemma ii. after II. xiii.) there is no modification of the body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof we cannot form some clear and distinct conception.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that there is no emotion, whereof
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we cannot form some clear and distinct conception.  For an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion is the idea of a modification of the body (by the general
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Def. of the Emotions), and must therefore (by the preceding
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.) involve some clear and distinct conception.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Seeing that there is nothing which is not followed by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an effect (I. xxxvi.), and that we clearly and distinctly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand whatever follows from an idea, which in us is adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xl.), it follows that everyone has the power of clearly and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly understanding himself and his emotions, if not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely, at any rate in part, and consequently of bringing it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about, that he should become less subject to them.  To attain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this result, therefore, we must chiefly direct our efforts to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquiring, as far as possible, a clear and distinct knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: every emotion, in order that the mind may thus, through emotion,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be determined to think of those things which it clearly and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly perceives, and wherein it fully acquiesces: and thus
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the emotion itself may be separated from the thought of an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external cause, and may be associated with true thoughts; whence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it will come to pass, not only that love, hatred, &c. will be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed (V. ii.), but also that the appetites or desires, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are wont to arise from such emotion, will become incapable of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being excessive (IV. lxi.).  For it must be especially remarked,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the appetite through which a man is said to be active, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that through which he is said to be passive is one and the same.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For instance, we have shown that human nature is so constituted,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that everyone desires his fellow--men to live after his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fashion (III. xxxi. note); in a man, who is not guided by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, this appetite is a passion which is called ambition, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not greatly differ from pride; whereas in a man, who lives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the dictates of reason, it is an activity or virtue which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called piety (IV. xxxvii. note. i. and second proof).  In like
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner all appetites or desires are only passions, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they spring from inadequate ideas; the same results are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accredited to virtue, when they are aroused or generated by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas.  For all desires, whereby we are determined to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any given action, may arise as much from adequate as from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate ideas (IV. lix.).  Than this remedy for the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (to return to the point from which I started), which consists in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a true knowledge thereof, nothing more excellent, being within
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our power, can be devised.  For the mind has no other power save
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that of thinking and of forming adequate ideas, as we have shown
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above (III. iii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. V.  An emotion towards a thing, which we conceive simply,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and not as necessary, or as contingent, or as possible, is, other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditions being equal, greater than any other emotion.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--An emotion towards a thing, which we conceive to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free, is greater than one towards what we conceive to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary (III. xlix.), and, consequently, still greater than one
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards what we conceive as possible, or contingent (IV. xi.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But to conceive a thing as free can be nothing else than to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive it simply, while we are in ignorance of the causes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby it has been determined to action (II. xxxv. note);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, an emotion towards a thing which we conceive simply
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, other conditions being equal, greater than one, which we feel
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards what is necessary, possible, or contingent, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, it is the greatest of all.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VI.  The mind has greater power over the emotions and is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less subject thereto, in so far as it understands all things as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind understands all things to be necessary (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxix.) and to be determined to existence and operation by an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite chain of causes; therefore (by the foregoing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proposition), it thus far brings it about, that it is less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject to the emotions arising therefrom, and (III. xlviii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feels less emotion towards the things themselves.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The more this knowledge, that things are necessary, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: applied to particular things, which we conceive more distinctly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and vividly, the greater is the power of the mind over the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, as experience also testifies.  For we see, that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pain arising from the loss of any good is mitigated, as soon as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the man who has lost it perceives, that it could not by any means
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have been preserved.  So also we see that no one pities an
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infant, because it cannot speak, walk, or reason, or lastly,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because it passes so many years, as it were, in unconsciousness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whereas, if most people were born full--grown and only one here
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and there as an infant, everyone would pity the infants; because
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infancy would not then be looked on as a state natural and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary, but as a fault or delinquency in Nature; and we may
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note several other instances of the same sort.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VII.  Emotions which are aroused or spring from reason, if
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we take account of time, are stronger than those, which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributable to particular objects that we regard as absent.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--We do not regard a thing as absent, by reason of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion wherewith we conceive it, but by reason of the body,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being affected by another emotion excluding the existence of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said thing (II. xvii.).  Wherefore, the emotion, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the thing which we regard as absent, is not of a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature to overcome the rest of a man's activities and power (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vi.), but is, on the contrary, of a nature to be in some sort
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: controlled by the emotions, which exclude the existence of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external cause (IV. ix.).  But an emotion which springs from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason is necessarily referred to the common properties of things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (see the def. of reason in II. xl. note. ii.), which we always
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard as present (for there can be nothing to exclude their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present existence), and which we always conceive in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner (II. xxxviii.).  Wherefore an emotion of this kind always
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remains the same; and consequently (V. Ax. i.) emotions, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are contrary thereto and are not kept going by their external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes, will be obliged to adapt themselves to it more and more,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: until they are no longer contrary to it; to this extent the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion which springs from reason is more powerful.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. VIII.  An emotion is stronger in proportion to the number
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of simultaneous concurrent causes whereby it is aroused.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Many simultaneous causes are more powerful than a few
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. vii.): therefore (IV. v.), in proportion to the increased
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of simultaneous causes whereby it is aroused, an emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: becomes stronger.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note--This proposition is also evident from V. Ax. ii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. IX.  An emotion, which is attributable to many and diverse
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes which the mind regards as simultaneous with the emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, is less hurtful, and we are less subject thereto and less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected towards each of its causes, than if it were a different
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and equally powerful emotion attributable to fewer causes or to a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: single cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--An emotion is only bad or hurtful, in so far as it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hinders the mind from being able to think (IV. xxvi. xxvii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, an emotion, whereby the mind is determined to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplation of several things at once, is less hurtful than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another equally powerful emotion, which so engrosses the mind in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the single contemplation of a few objects or of one, that it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unable to think of anything else; this was our first point.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, as the mind's essence, in other words, its power (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vii.), consists solely in thought (II. xi.), the mind is less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive in respect to an emotion, which causes it to think of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: several things at once, than in regard to an equally strong
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion, which keeps it engrossed in the contemplation of a few
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or of a single object: this was our second point.  Lastly, this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion (III. xlviii.), in so far as it is attributable to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: several causes, is less powerful in regard to each of them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. X.  So long as we are not assailed by emotions contrary to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our nature, we have the power of arranging and associating the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of our body according to the intellectual order.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The emotions, which are contrary to our nature, that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (IV. xxx.), which are bad, are bad in so far as they impede
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind from understanding (IV. xxvii.).  So long, therefore, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are not assailed by emotions contrary to our nature, the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind's power, whereby it endeavours to understand things (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxvi.), is not impeded, and therefore it is able to form clear
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and distinct ideas and to deduce them one from another (II. xl.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note. ii. and II. xlvii. note); consequently we have in such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cases the power of arranging and associating the modifications of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body according to the intellectual order.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--By this power of rightly arranging and associating the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodily modifications we can guard ourselves from being easily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected by evil emotions.  For (V. vii.) a greater force is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: needed for controlling the emotions, when they are arranged and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associated according to the intellectual order, than when they,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are uncertain and unsettled.  The best we can do, therefore, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as we do not possess a perfect knowledge of our emotions, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to frame a system of right conduct, or fixed practical precepts,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to commit it to memory, and to apply it forthwith[16] to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular circumstances which now and again meet us in life, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that our imagination may become fully imbued therewith, and that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it may be always ready to our hand.  For instance, we have laid
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down among the rules of life (IV. xlvi. and note), that hatred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be overcome with love or high--mindedness, and not required
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with hatred in return.  Now, that this precept of reason may be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always ready to our hand in time of need, we should often think
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over and reflect upon the wrongs generally committed by men, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in what manner and way they may be best warded off by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: high--mindedness: we shall thus associate the idea of wrong with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of this precept, which accordingly will always be ready
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for use when a wrong is done to us (II. xviii.).  If we keep also
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in readiness the notion of our true advantage, and of the good
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which follows from mutual friendships, and common fellowships;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further, if we remember that complete acquiescence is the result
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the right way of life ( IV. lii.), and that men, no less than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything else, act by the necessity of their nature: in such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case I say the wrong, or the hatred, which commonly arises
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom, will engross a very small part of our imagination and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be easily overcome; or, if the anger which springs from a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: grievous wrong be not overcome easily, it will nevertheless be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: overcome, though not without a spiritual conflict, far sooner
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than if we had not thus reflected on the subject beforehand.  As
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is indeed evident from V. vi. vii. viii.  We should, in the same
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way, reflect on courage as a means of overcoming fear; the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinary dangers of life should frequently be brought to mind and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagined, together with the means whereby through readiness of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: resource and strength of mind we can avoid and overcome them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But we must note, that in arranging our thoughts and conceptions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we should always bear in mind that which is good in every
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual thing (IV. lxiii. Coroll. and III. lix.), in order
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we may always be determined to action by an emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure.  For instance, if a man sees that he is too keen in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pursuit of honour, let him think over its right use, the end for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it should be pursued, and the means whereby he may attain
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it.  Let him not think of its misuse, and its emptiness, and the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fickleness of mankind, and the like, whereof no man thinks except
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through a morbidness of disposition; with thoughts like these do
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the most ambitious most torment themselves, when they despair of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gaining the distinctions they hanker after, and in thus giving
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vent to their anger would fain appear wise.  Wherefore it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain that those, who cry out the loudest against the misuse of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: honour and the vanity of the world, are those who most greedily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: covet it.  This is not peculiar to the ambitious, but is common
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to all who are ill--used by fortune, and who are infirm in spirit.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For a poor man also, who is miserly, will talk incessantly of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: misuse of wealth and of the vices of the rich; whereby he merely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: torments himself, and shows the world that he is intolerant, not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only of his own poverty, but also of other people's riches.  So,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: again, those who have been ill received by a woman they love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think of nothing but the inconstancy, treachery, and other stock
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faults of the fair sex; all of which they consign to oblivion,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directly they are again taken into favour by their sweetheart.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus he who would govern his emotions and appetite solely by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love of freedom strives, as far as he can, to gain a knowledge of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the virtues and their causes, and to fill his spirit with the joy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which arises from the true knowledge of them: he will in no wise
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire to dwell on men's faults, or to carp at his fellows, or to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revel in a false show of freedom.  Whosoever will diligently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observe and practise these precepts (which indeed are not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: difficult) will verily, in a short space of time, be able, for
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the most part, to direct his actions according to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commandments of reason.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [16] Continuo.  Rendered "constantly" by Mr. Pollock on the ground
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the classical meaning of the word does not suit the context.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XI.  In proportion as a mental image is referred to more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: objects, so is it more frequent, or more often vivid, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: occupies the mind more.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In proportion as a mental image or an emotion is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to more objects, so are there more causes whereby it can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be aroused and fostered, all of which (by hypothesis) the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplates simultaneously in association with the given emotion;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the emotion is more frequent, or is more often in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: full vigour, and (V. viii.) occupies the mind more.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XII.  The mental images of things are more easily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associated with the images referred to things which we clearly
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and distinctly understand, than with others.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Things, which we clearly and distinctly understand,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are either the common properties of things or deductions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom (see definition of Reason, II. xl. note ii.), and are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently (by the last Prop.) more often aroused in us.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore it may more readily happen, that we should contemplate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other things in conjunction with these than in conjunction with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something else, and consequently (II. xviii.) that the images of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the said things should be more often associated with the images
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of these than with the images of something else.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIII.  A mental image is more often vivid, in proportion as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is associated with a greater number of other images.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In proportion as an image is associated with a greater
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of other images, so (II. xviii.) are there more causes
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby it can be aroused.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIV.  The mind can bring it about, that all bodily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications or images of things may be referred to the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--There is no modification of the body, whereof the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may not form some clear and distinct conception (V. iv.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore it can bring it about, that they should all be referred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the idea of God (I. xv.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XV.  He who clearly and distinctly understands himself and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his emotions loves God, and so much the more in proportion as he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more understands himself and his emotions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--He who clearly and distinctly understands himself and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his emotions feels pleasure (III. liii.), and this pleasure is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the last Prop.) accompanied by the idea of God; therefore
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def. of the Emotions, vi.) such an one loves God, and (for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same reason) so much the more in proportion as he more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understands himself and his emotions.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVI.  This love towards God must hold the chief place in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--For this love is associated with all the modifications
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the body (V. xiv.) and is fostered by them all (V. xv.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (V. xi.), it must hold the chief place in the mind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVII.  God is without passions, neither is he affected by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any emotion of pleasure or pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--All ideas, in so far as they are referred to God, are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true (II. xxxii.), that is (II. Def. iv.) adequate; and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (by the general Def. of the Emotions) God is without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passions.  Again, God cannot pass either to a greater or to a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lesser perfection (I. xx. Coroll. ii.); therefore (by Def. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Emotions, ii. iii.) he is not affected by any emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure or pain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Strictly speaking, God does not love or hate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone.  For God (by the foregoing Prop.) is not affected by any
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of pleasure or pain, consequently (Def. of the Emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vi. vii.) he does not love or hate anyone.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XVIII.  No one can hate God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The idea of God which is in us is adequate and perfect
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xlvi. xlvii.); wherefore, in so far as we contemplate God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are active (III. iii.); consequently (III. lix.) there can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no pain accompanied by the idea of God, in other words (Def. of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Emotions, vii.), no one can hate God.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Love towards God cannot be turned into hate.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--It may be objected that, as we understand God as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause of all things, we by that very fact regard God as the cause
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of pain.  But I make answer, that, in so far as we understand the
title: Ethics
