author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes of pain, it to that extent (V. iii.) ceases to be a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passion, that is, it ceases to be pain (III. lix.); therefore,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as we understand God to be the cause of pain, we to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that extent feel pleasure.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XIX.  He, who loves God, cannot endeavour that God should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love him in return.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--For, if a man should so endeavour, he would desire (V.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii. Coroll.) that God, whom he loves, should not be God, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently he would desire to feel pain (III. xix.); which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurd (III. xxviii.).  Therefore, he who loves God, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XX.  This love towards God cannot be stained by the emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of envy or jealousy: contrariwise, it is the more fostered, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as we conceive a greater number of men to be joined to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God by the same bond of love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This love towards God is the highest good which we can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seek for under the guidance of reason (IV. xxviii.), it is common
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to all men (IV. xxxvi.), and we desire that all should rejoice
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein (IV. xxxvii.); therefore (Def. of the Emotions, xxiii.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it cannot be stained by the emotion envy, nor by the emotion of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: jealousy (V. xviii. see definition of Jealousy, III. xxxv. note);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but, contrariwise, it must needs be the more fostered, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as we conceive a greater number of men to rejoice
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--We can in the same way show, that there is no emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directly contrary to this love, whereby this love can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed; therefore we may conclude, that this love towards God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the most constant of all the emotions, and that, in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is referred to the body, it cannot be destroyed, unless the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body be destroyed also.  As to its nature, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the mind only, we shall presently inquire.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have now gone through all the remedies against the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, or all that the mind, considered in itself alone, can
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do against them.  Whence it appears that the mind's power over
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the emotions consists:----
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I.  In the actual knowledge of the emotions (V. iv. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. In the fact that it separates the emotions from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought of an external cause, which we conceive confusedly (V.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ii. and V. iv. note).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III.  In the fact, that, in respect to time, the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to things, which we distinctly understand, surpass those
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to what we conceive in a confused and fragmentary manner
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (V. vii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV.  In the number of causes whereby those modifications[17]
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are fostered, which have regard to the common properties of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things or to God (V. ix. xi.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17] Affectiones.  Camerer reads affectus----emotions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: V.  Lastly, in the order wherein the mind can arrange and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: associate, one with another, its own emotions (V. x. note and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xii. xiii. xiv.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, in order that this power of the mind over the emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may be better understood, it should be specially observed that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the emotions are called by us strong, when we compare the emotion
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of one man with the emotion of another, and see that one man is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more troubled than another by the same emotion; or when we are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comparing the various emotions of the same man one with another,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and find that he is more affected or stirred by one emotion than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by another.  For the strength of every emotion is defined by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comparison of our own power with the power of an external cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now the power of the mind is defined by knowledge only, and its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infirmity or passion is defined by the privation of knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only: it therefore follows, that that mind is most passive,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whose greatest part is made up of inadequate ideas, so that it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may be characterized more readily by its passive states than by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its activities: on the other hand, that mind is most active,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whose greatest part is made up of adequate ideas, so that,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although it may contain as many inadequate ideas as the former
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, it may yet be more easily characterized by ideas
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attributable to human virtue, than by ideas which tell of human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infirmity.  Again, it must be observed, that spiritual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unhealthiness and misfortunes can generally be traced to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excessive love for something which is subject to many variations,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and which we can never become masters of.  For no one is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solicitous or anxious about anything, unless he loves it;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither do wrongs, suspicions, enmities, &c. arise, except in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard to things whereof no one can be really master.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We may thus readily conceive the power which clear and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinct knowledge, and especially that third kind of knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xlvii. note), founded on the actual knowledge of God,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses over the emotions: if it does not absolutely destroy
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them, in so far as they are passions (V. iii. and iv. note); at
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any rate, it causes them to occupy a very small part of the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (V. xiv.).  Further, it begets a love towards a thing immutable
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and eternal (V. xv.), whereof we may really enter into possession
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. xlv.); neither can it be defiled with those faults which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are inherent in ordinary love; but it may grow from strength to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength, and may engross the greater part of the mind, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deeply penetrate it.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: And now I have finished with all that concerns this present
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life: for, as I said in the beginning of this note, I have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: briefly described all the remedies against the emotions.  And
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this everyone may readily have seen for himself, if he has
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attended to what is advanced in the present note, and also to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definitions of the mind and its emotions, and, lastly, to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Propositions i. and iii. of Part III.  It is now, therefore, time
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to pass on to those matters, which appertain to the duration of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind, without relation to the body.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXI.  The mind can only imagine anything, or remember what
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is past, while the body endures.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind does not express the actual existence of its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, nor does it imagine the modifications of the body as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual, except while the body endures (II. viii. Coroll.); and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently (II. xxvi.), it does not imagine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any body as actually existing, except while its own body endures.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot imagine anything (for definition of Imagination, see II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii. note),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or remember things past, except while the body endures (see
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of Memory, II. xviii. note).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXII.  Nevertheless in God there is necessarily an idea,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which expresses the essence of this or that human body under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: form of eternity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--God is the cause, not only of the existence of this or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that human body, but also of its essence (I. xxv.).  This
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence, therefore, must necessarily be conceived through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very essence of God (I. Ax. iv.), and be thus conceived by a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain eternal necessity (I. xvi.); and this conception must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily exist in God (II. iii.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIII.  The human mind cannot be absolutely destroyed with
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body, but there remains of it something which is eternal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--There is necessarily in God a concept or idea, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expresses the essence of the human body (last Prop.), which,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, is necessarily something appertaining to the essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the human mind (II. xiii.).  But we have not assigned to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human mind any duration, definable by time, except in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it expresses the actual existence of the body, which is explained
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through duration, and may be defined by time--that is (II. viii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Coroll.), we do not assign to it duration, except while the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endures.  Yet, as there is something, notwithstanding, which is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived by a certain eternal necessity through the very essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God (last Prop.); this something, which appertains to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of the mind, will necessarily be eternal.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--This idea, which expresses the essence of the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the form of eternity, is, as we have said, a certain mode
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of thinking, which belongs to the essence of the mind, and is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily eternal.  Yet it is not possible that we should
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remember that we existed before our body, for our body can bear
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no trace of such existence, neither can eternity be defined in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: terms of time, or have any relation to time.  But,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notwithstanding, we feel and know that we are eternal.  For the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind feels those things that it conceives by understanding, no
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less than those things that it remembers.  For the eyes of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, whereby it sees and observes things, are none other than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proofs.  Thus, although we do not remember that we existed before
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the body, yet we feel that our mind, in so far as it involves the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of the body, under the form of eternity, is eternal, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that thus its existence cannot be defined in terms of time, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explained through duration.  Thus our mind can only be said to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endure, and its existence can only be defined by a fixed time, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as it involves the actual existence of the body.  Thus far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only has it the power of determining the existence of things by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time, and conceiving them under the category of duration.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIV.  The more we understand particular things, the more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do we understand God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This is evident from I. xxv. Coroll.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXV.  The highest endeavour of the mind, and the highest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue is to understand things by the third kind of knowledge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The third kind of knowledge proceeds from an adequate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea of certain attributes of God to an adequate knowledge of the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of things (see its definition II. xl. note. ii.); and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in proportion as we understand things more in this way, we better
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand God (by the last Prop.); therefore (IV. xxviii.) the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest virtue of the mind, that is (IV. Def. viii.) the power, or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, or (III. vii.) highest endeavour of the mind, is to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand things by the third kind of knowledge.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVI.  In proportion as the mind is more capable of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding things by the third kind of knowledge, it desires
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more to understand things by that kind.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof--This is evident.  For, in so far as we conceive the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind to be capable of conceiving things by this kind of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge, we, to that extent, conceive it as determined thus to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive things; and consequently (Def. of the Emotions, i.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind desires so to do, in proportion as it is more capable
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereof.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVII.  From this third kind of knowledge arises the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest possible mental acquiescence.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The highest virtue of the mind is to know God (IV.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxviii.), or to understand things by the third kind of knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (V. xxv.), and this virtue is greater in proportion as the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knows things more by the said kind of knowledge (V. xxiv.):
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, he who knows things by this kind of knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passes to the summit of human perfection, and is therefore (Def.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Emotions, ii.) affected by the highest pleasure, such
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure being accompanied by the idea of himself and his own
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue; thus (Def. of the Emotions, xxv.), from this kind of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge arises the highest possible acquiescence.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXVIII.  The endeavour or desire to know things by the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: third kind of knowledge cannot arise from the first, but from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: second kind of knowledge.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This proposition is self--evident.  For whatsoever we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand clearly and distinctly, we understand either through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, or through that which is conceived through itself; that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, ideas which are clear and distinct in us, or which are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the third kind of knowledge (II. xl. note. ii.)
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot follow from ideas that are fragmentary and confused, and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are referred to knowledge of the first kind, but must follow from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas, or ideas of the second and third kind of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge; therefore (Def. of the Emotions, i.), the desire of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowing things by the third kind of knowledge cannot arise from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the first, but from the second kind.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXIX.  Whatsoever the mind understands under the form of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity, it does not understand by virtue of conceiving the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present actual existence of the body, but by virtue of conceiving
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of the body under the form of eternity.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In so far as the mind conceives the present existence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its body, it to that extent conceives duration which can be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determined by time, and to that extent only has it the power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceiving things in relation to time (V. xxi. II. xxvi.).  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity cannot be explained in terms of duration (I. Def. viii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and explanation).  Therefore to this extent the mind has not the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of conceiving things under the form of eternity, but it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses such power, because it is of the nature of reason to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive things under the form of eternity (II. xliv. Coroll.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ii.), and also because it is of the nature of the mind to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive the essence of the body under the form of eternity (V.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxiii.), for besides these two there is nothing which belongs to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of mind (II. xiii.).  Therefore this power of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceiving things under the form of eternity only belongs to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind in virtue of the mind's conceiving the essence of the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the form of eternity.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Things are conceived by us as actual in two ways; either as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing in relation to a given time and place, or as contained in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God and following from the necessity of the divine nature.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whatsoever we conceive in this second way as true or real, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive under the form of eternity, and their ideas involve the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal and infinite essence of God, as we showed in II. xlv. and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note, which see.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXX.  Our mind, in so far as it knows itself and the body
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the form of eternity, has to that extent necessarily a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of God, and knows that it is in God, and is conceived
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Eternity is the very essence of God, in so far as this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves necessary existence (I. Def. viii.).  Therefore to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive things under the form of eternity, is to conceive things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as they are conceived through the essence of God as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: real entities, or in so far as they involve existence through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of God; wherefore our mind, in so far as it conceives
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself and the body under the form of eternity, has to that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extent necessarily a knowledge of God, and knows, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXI.  The third kind of knowledge depends on the mind, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its formal cause, in so far as the mind itself is eternal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind does not conceive anything under the form of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity, except in so far as it conceives its own body under the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: form of eternity (V. xxix.); that is, except in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal (V. xxi. xxiii.); therefore (by the last Prop.), in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it is eternal, it possesses the knowledge of God, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge is necessarily adequate (II. xlvi.); hence the mind,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it is eternal, is capable of knowing everything
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which can follow from this given knowledge of God (II. xl.), in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, of knowing things by the third kind of knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (see Def. in II. xl. note. ii.), whereof accordingly the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. Def. i.), in so far as it is eternal, is the adequate or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: formal cause of such knowledge.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--In proportion, therefore, as a man is more potent in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this kind of knowledge, he will be more completely conscious of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself and of God; in other words, he will be more perfect and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessed, as will appear more clearly in the sequel.  But we must
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: here observe that, although we are already certain that the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is eternal, in so far as it conceives things under the form of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternity, yet, in order that what we wish to show may be more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readily explained and better understood, we will consider the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind itself, as though it had just begun to exist and to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand things under the form of eternity, as indeed we have
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done hitherto; this we may do without any danger of error, so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as we are careful not to draw any conclusion, unless our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: premisses are plain.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXII.  Whatsoever we understand by the third kind of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge, we take delight in, and our delight is accompanied by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of God as cause.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--From this kind of knowledge arises the highest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible mental acquiescence, that is (Def of the Emotions,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxv.), pleasure, and this acquiescence is accompanied by the idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the mind itself (V. xxvii.), and consequently (V. xxx.) the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea also of God as cause.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--From the third kind of knowledge necessarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises the intellectual love of God.  From this kind of knowledge
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises pleasure accompanied by the idea of God as cause, that is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Def. of the Emotions, vi.), the love of God; not in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we imagine him as present (V. xxix.), but in so far as we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand him to be eternal; this is what I call the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellectual love of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIII.  The intellectual love of God, which arises from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the third kind of knowledge, is eternal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The third kind of knowledge is eternal (V. xxxi. I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ax. iii.); therefore (by the same Axiom) the love which arises
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefrom is also necessarily eternal.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Although this love towards God has (by the foregoing
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop.) no beginning, it yet possesses all the perfections of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, just as though it had arisen as we feigned in the Coroll.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the last Prop.  Nor is there here any difference, except that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mind possesses as eternal those same perfections which we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feigned to accrue to it, and they are accompanied by the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God as eternal cause.  If pleasure consists in the transition to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a greater perfection, assuredly blessedness must consist in the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind being endowed with perfection itself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIV.  The mind is, only while the body endures, subject
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to those emotions which are attributable to passions.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Imagination is the idea wherewith the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contemplates a thing as present (II. xvii. note); yet this idea
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indicates rather the present disposition of the human body than
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of the external thing (II. xvi. Coroll. ii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore emotion (see general Def. of Emotions) is imagination,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it indicates the present disposition of the body;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (V. xxi.) the mind is, only while the body endures,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject to emotions which are attributable to passions.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that no love save intellectual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love is eternal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--If we look to men's general opinion, we shall see that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are indeed conscious of the eternity of their mind, but that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they confuse eternity with duration, and ascribe it to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination or the memory which they believe to remain after
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: death.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXV.  God loves himself with an infinite intellectual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--God is absolutely infinite (I. Def. vi.), that is (II.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Def. vi.), the nature of God rejoices in infinite perfection;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and such rejoicing is (II. iii.) accompanied by the idea of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, that is (I. xi. and Def. i.), the idea of his own cause:
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: now this is what we have (in V. xxxii. Coroll.) described as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellectual love.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVI.  The intellectual love of the mind towards God is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that very love of God whereby God loves himself, not in so far as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is infinite, but in so far as he can be explained through the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of the human mind regarded under the form of eternity;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in other words, the intellectual love of the mind towards God is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part of the infinite love wherewith God loves himself.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This love of the mind must be referred to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: activities of the mind (V. xxxii. Coroll. and III. iii.); it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, indeed, an activity whereby the mind regards itself
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of God as cause (V. xxxii. and Coroll.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is (I. xxv. Coroll. and II. xi. Coroll.), an activity
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby God, in so far as he can be explained through the human
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, regards himself accompanied by the idea of himself;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (by the last Prop.), this love of the mind is part of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the infinite love wherewith God loves himself.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that God, in so far as he loves
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, loves man, and, consequently, that the love of God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards men, and the intellectual love of the mind towards God
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are identical.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--From what has been said we clearly understand, wherein
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our salvation, or blessedness, or freedom, consists: namely, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the constant and eternal love towards God, or in God's love
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: towards men.  This love or blessedness is, in the Bible, called
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Glory, and not undeservedly.  For whether this love be referred
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to God or to the mind, it may rightly be called acquiescence of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spirit, which (Def. of the Emotions, xxv. xxx.) is not really
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguished from glory.  In so far as it is referred to God, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (V. xxxv.) pleasure, if we may still use that term,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of itself, and, in so far as it is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the mind, it is the same (V. xxvii.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, since the essence of our mind consists solely in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge, whereof the beginning and the foundation is God (I.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xv., and II. xlvii. note), it becomes clear to us, in what manner
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and way our mind, as to its essence and existence, follows from
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the divine nature and constantly depends on God.  I have thought
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it worth while here to call attention to this, in order to show
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by this example how the knowledge of particular things, which I
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have called intuitive or of the third kind (II. xl. note. ii.),
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is potent, and more powerful than the universal knowledge, which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have styled knowledge of the second kind.  For, although in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Part I. I showed in general terms, that all things (and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, also, the human mind) depend as to their essence
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and existence on God, yet that demonstration, though legitimate
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and placed beyond the chances of doubt, does not affect our mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so much, as when the same conclusion is derived from the actual
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of some particular thing, which we say depends on God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVII.  There is nothing in nature, which is contrary to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this intellectual love, or which can take it away.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--This intellectual love follows necessarily from the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of the mind, in so far as the latter is regarded through
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of God as an eternal truth (V. xxxiii. and xxix.).
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If, therefore, there should be anything which would be contrary
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to this love, that thing would be contrary to that which is true;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, that, which should be able to take away this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, would cause that which is true to be false; an obvious
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absurdity.  Therefore there is nothing in nature which, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The Axiom of Part IV. has reference to particular
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, in so far as they are regarded in relation to a given
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time and place: of this, I think, no one can doubt.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXVIII.  In proportion as the mind understands more things
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the second and third kind of knowledge, it is less subject to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those emotions which are evil, and stands in less fear of death.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The mind's essence consists in knowledge (II. xi.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, in proportion as the mind understands more things by
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the second and third kinds of knowledge, the greater will be the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part of it that endures (V. xxix. and xxiii.), and, consequently
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the last Prop.), the greater will be the part that is not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: touched by the emotions, which are contrary to our nature, or in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, evil (IV. xxx.).  Thus, in proportion as the mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understands more things by the second and third kinds of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge, the greater will be the part of it, that remains
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unimpaired, and, consequently, less subject to emotions, &c.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Hence we understand that point which I touched on in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IV. xxxix. note, and which I promised to explain in this Part;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, that death becomes less hurtful, in proportion as the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind's clear and distinct knowledge is greater, and,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, in proportion as the mind loves God more.  Again,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: since from the third kind of knowledge arises the highest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible acquiescence (V. xxvii.), it follows that the human mind
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can attain to being of such a nature, that the part thereof which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we have shown to perish with the body (V. xxi.) should be of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: little importance when compared with the part which endures.  But
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I will soon treat of the subject at greater length.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XXXIX.  He, who possesses a body capable of the greatest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of activities, possesses a mind whereof the greatest part
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is eternal.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--He, who possesses a body capable of the greatest
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of activities, is least agitated by those emotions which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are evil (IV. xxxviii.)--that is (IV. xxx.), by those emotions
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are contrary to our nature; therefore (V. x.), he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses the power of arranging and associating the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of the body according to the intellectual order,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, consequently, of bringing it about, that all the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications of the body should be referred to the idea of God;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whence it will come to pass that (V. xv.) he will be affected
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with love towards God, which (V. xvi.) must occupy or constitute
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the chief part of the mind; therefore (V. xxxiii.), such a man
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will possess a mind whereof the chief part is eternal.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Since human bodies are capable of the greatest number
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of activities, there is no doubt but that they may be of such a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, that they may be referred to minds possessing a great
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of themselves and of God, and whereof the greatest or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chief part is eternal, and, therefore, that they should scarcely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear death.  But, in order that this may be understood more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearly, we must here call to mind, that we live in a state of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perpetual variation, and, according as we are changed for the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: better or the worse, we are called happy or unhappy.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For he, who, from being an infant or a child, becomes a
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corpse, is called unhappy; whereas it is set down to happiness,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if we have been able to live through the whole period of life
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with a sound mind in a sound body.  And, in reality, he, who, as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the case of an infant or a child, has a body capable of very
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: few activities, and depending, for the most part, on external
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes, has a mind which, considered in itself alone, is scarcely
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conscious of itself, or of God, or of things; whereas, he, who
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has a body capable of very many activities, has a mind which,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considered in itself alone, is highly conscious of itself, of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, and of things.  In this life, therefore, we primarily
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to bring it about, that the body of a child, in so far
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as its nature allows and conduces thereto, may be changed into
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something else capable of very many activities, and referable to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a mind which is highly conscious of itself, of God, and of things;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and we desire so to change it, that what is referred to its
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination and memory may become insignificant, in comparison
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with its intellect, as I have already said in the note to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last Proposition.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XL.  In proportion as each thing possesses more of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection, so is it more active, and less passive; and, vice
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: versa, in proportion as it is more active, so is it more perfect.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--In proportion as each thing is more perfect, it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses more of reality (II. Def. vi.), and, consequently (III.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iii. and note), it is to that extent more active and less
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive.  This demonstration may be reversed, and thus prove
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that, in proportion as a thing is more active, so is it more
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfect.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Corollary.--Hence it follows that the part of the mind which
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endures, be it great or small, is more perfect than the rest.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For the eternal part of the mind (V. xxiii. xxix.) is the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, through which alone we are said to act (III. iii.);
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the part which we have shown to perish is the imagination (V.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxi.), through which only we are said to be passive (III. iii.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and general Def. of the Emotions); therefore, the former, be it
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great or small, is more perfect than the latter.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--Such are the doctrines which I had purposed to set
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth concerning the mind, in so far as it is regarded without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: relation to the body; whence, as also from I. xxi. and other
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: places, it is plain that our mind, in so far as it understands,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is an eternal mode of thinking, which is determined by another
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal mode of thinking, and this other by a third, and so on to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinity; so that all taken together at once constitute the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal and infinite intellect of God.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLI.  Even if we did not know that our mind is eternal, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should still consider as of primary importance piety and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion, and generally all things which, in Part IV., we showed
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be attributable to courage and high--mindedness.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--The first and only foundation of virtue, or the rule
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of right living is (IV. xxii. Coroll. and xxiv.) seeking one's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own true interest.  Now, while we determined what reason
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prescribes as useful, we took no account of the mind's eternity,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which has only become known to us in this Fifth Part.  Although
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we were ignorant at that time that the mind is eternal, we
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless stated that the qualities attributable to courage
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and high--mindedness are of primary importance.  Therefore, even
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if we were still ignorant of this doctrine, we should yet put the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aforesaid precepts of reason in the first place.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--The general belief of the multitude seems to be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different.  Most people seem to believe that they are free, in so
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as they may obey their lusts, and that they cede their
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights, in so far as they are bound to live according to the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commandments of the divine law.  They therefore believe that
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piety, religion, and, generally, all things attributable to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: firmness of mind, are burdens, which, after death, they hope to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lay aside, and to receive the reward for their bondage, that is,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for their piety and religion; it is not only by this hope, but
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also, and chiefly, by the fear of being horribly punished after
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: death, that they are induced to live according to the divine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commandments, so far as their feeble and infirm spirit will carry
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If men had not this hope and this fear, but believed that the
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind perishes with the body, and that no hope of prolonged life
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remains for the wretches who are broken down with the burden of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piety, they would return to their own inclinations, controlling
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything in accordance with their lusts, and desiring to obey
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fortune rather than themselves.  Such a course appears to me not
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less absurd than if a man, because he does not believe that he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can by wholesome food sustain his body for ever, should wish to
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cram himself with poisons and deadly fare; or if, because he
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sees that the mind is not eternal or immortal, he should prefer
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be out of his mind altogether, and to live without the use of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason; these ideas are so absurd as to be scarcely worth
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: refuting.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROP. XLII.  Blessedness is not the reward of virtue, but virtue
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself; neither do we rejoice therein, because we control our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lusts, but, contrariwise, because we rejoice therein, we are able
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to control our lusts.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Proof.--Blessedness consists in love towards God (V. xxxvi and
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note), which love springs from the third kind of knowledge (V.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxxii. Coroll.); therefore this love (III. iii. lix.) must be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: referred to the mind, in so far as the latter is active;
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore (IV. Def. viii.) it is virtue itself.  This was our
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first point.  Again, in proportion as the mind rejoices more in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this divine love or blessedness, so does it the more understand
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (V. xxxii.); that is (V. iii. Coroll.), so much the more power
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has it over the emotions, and (V. xxxviii.) so much the less is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it subject to those emotions which are evil; therefore, in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as the mind rejoices in this divine love or
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness, so has it the power of controlling lusts.  And,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: since human power in controlling the emotions consists solely in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the understanding, it follows that no one rejoices in
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness, because he has controlled his lusts, but,
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrariwise, his power of controlling his lusts arises from this
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness itself.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Note.--I have thus completed all I wished to set forth
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: touching the mind's power over the emotions and the mind's
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freedom.  Whence it appears, how potent is the wise man, and how
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much he surpasses the ignorant man, who is driven only by his
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lusts.  For the ignorant man is not only distracted in various
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ways by external causes without ever gaining the true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquiescence of his spirit, but moreover lives, as it were
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unwitting of himself, and of God, and of things, and as soon as
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he ceases to suffer, ceases also to be.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whereas the wise man, in so far as he is regarded as such, is
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: scarcely at all disturbed in spirit, but, being conscious of
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, and of God, and of things, by a certain eternal
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity, never ceases to be, but always possesses true
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquiescence of his spirit.
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: If the way which I have pointed out as leading to this result
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seems exceedingly hard, it may nevertheless be discovered.  Needs
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must it be hard, since it is so seldom found.  How would it be
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible, if salvation were ready to our hand, and could without
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great labour be found, that it should be by almost all men
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neglected? But all things excellent are as difficult as they are
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rare.

title: Ethics

text: whom we regard without any particular emotion.

title: Ethics

title: Ethics

text: [10] This is possible, though the human mind is part of the divine
title: Ethics
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect, as I have shown in II. xiii. note.
title: Ethics

title: Ethics

title: Ethics

title: Ethics

title: Ethics
